16 Chapter 2. Related Work
With regard to social media, features are commonly based on the user’s proﬁle and on message
metadata.
Proﬁle-based features are meant to help identify some signs that can assist with fake news
classiﬁcation. For example, a user who follows a large number of accounts but has few followers,
a recently-created account with a large number of posts, or accounts that mark a high number
of messages as “favorites” or “liked” are all patterns that have been observed in connection
with dissemination of fake news content [ 84]. Features in this group include a user’s number
of followers and friends, their geographical location, number of messages posted, account age,
and veriﬁcation status (i.e., if the account has been veriﬁed as authentic by the social media
platform) [4, 36, 45, 87].
Posts on social media have metadata and message-speciﬁc content that can also be explored
and has proven useful as a basis for creating features. These include the presence of links [ 52],
number of times a post was marked as “liked” or “favorite” [ 89], and time of publication [ 87].
Speciﬁcally for Twitter, commonly used features include the number of mentions of another user
and hashtags [52, 60].
Finally, some studies employ network-based features, aiming to explore propagation properties
of fake news content in social media platforms. These studies leverage patterns that emerge
in fake news sharing, such as echo chambers and ﬁlter bubbles, where users in a social media
platform have their media exposure limited to content aligned with their predeﬁned beliefs. This
presents psychological factors that directly impact in user consumption and acceptance of fake
news content [ 85]. Other studies attempt to model the propagation tree of these messages [ 92,98],
and also include features such as the number of times a message was replicated or replied to, or
the propagation times [51, 87].
Itshouldbenotedthatalthoughnetwork-basedfeatureshavebeenemployedbyseveralstudies,
their use evidently depends on the spreading of fake news across the network. Nevertheless, it
has been shown that it is not easy to revert the impact of incorrect information once a person
has been exposed to it [ 74]. Therefore, it is essential to identify fake news content as early as
possible [52, 103].
Other studies make use of purpose-speciﬁc features that attempt to leverage additional
patterns. As an example, Reis et al. [ 73], observing that fake news creation and publishing as
a proﬁtable business has on occasion taken place in speciﬁc locations, explore the information
potentially provided by the location of domains that host fake news content.
2.2.3 Classiﬁcation Models and Results
For machine learning-based fake news classiﬁcation, a common approach is the use of supervised
learning techniques, ranging from more traditional algorithms to deep neural networks. Their
results are commonly evaluated with widely used classiﬁcation metrics, including accuracy,
precision, recall, and F-score. Many studies work with binary classiﬁcation [ 60,67,75,89], while
2.2. State of the Art 17
some tackle the problem through a multiclass perspective [33, 72, 91, 93].
Support Vector Machines have shown good results in several studies. Rubin et al. [ 75] make
use of SVM-based algorithms with combinations of vector text representations and obtain F-scores
between 0.82 and 0.87. Pérez-Rosas et al. [ 67] test diﬀerent sets of linguistic-based features with
an SVM model and achieve 0.78 accuracy with readability-related features. Additionally, they
test content from diﬀerent domains and ﬁnd a large diﬀerence in cross-domain classiﬁcation
performance, with high accuracy in some domains (0.91 for politics content) and low in others
(0.51 for sports content). Decision Trees and Random Forests are also widely used, with Random
Forests frequently ﬁguring among the best performers for classiﬁcation [ 68,86]. A common
approach adopted by several studies is to compare the performance of diﬀerent classiﬁers on the
same data sets in order to evaluate which provide the best results. Zhou et al. [ 103] combine
Logistic Regression, Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines, Random Forests, and XGBoost, and
obtain a general accuracy of 0.88, with Random Forest and XGBoost as the best performing
algorithms. Similarly, Reis et al. [ 73] compare traditional algorithms and also obtain the best
results from Random Forest and XGBoost, with an F1-score of 0.81.
Some studies also employ deep learning for classiﬁcation, since this family of techniques
has shown good results in natural language processing problems, especially Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNNs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). This approach diﬀers from
more traditional methods in that while those require manually created features, deep neural
networks obtain latent features from data [ 85]. Wang [ 93] utilizes a CNN model with text vector
representations combined with metadata features and obtains a best accuracy of 0.27 on a
six-label classiﬁcation task. Ruchansky et al. [ 76] has proposed a model that combines three
diﬀerent characteristics of fake news consumption, based on text, response, and source. They
use a RNN model that receives temporal data related to user engagement, ﬁnd it is able to
extract meaningful representations of fake news content and users, and obtain an accuracy of
0.89 on a Twitter data set from [ 52]. Volkova et al. [ 91] build CNN and RNN models to classify
tweets in a binary and in a four-label setting, using bag of words and word embeddings as text
representations combined with network and semantic features, and obtain 0.95 accuracy in the
binary classiﬁcation task.
In this chapter we have explored fundamental concepts in machine learning and natural
language processing that are at the foundation of our research into automatic fake news
identiﬁcation. Additionally, our literature review prompts a number of conclusions that help
deﬁne the course of this work. From the discussion of existing data sets, we ﬁnd creating a
new data set with recently collected data helps to ensure that we obtain up-to-date and more
complete information. Additionally, we discuss the importance of maintaining a data set that
is representative of the real-world scenario of fake news distribution in social media. We have
also explored diﬀerent approaches to feature creation in the context of fake news identiﬁcation
and their common categorization into content-based, social context-based, and network-based
features. Finally, we have seen common algorithms used for fake news classiﬁcation in diﬀerent
contexts—from social media posts to news articles and an overview of the best results that have

3.2 Data Preparation
After the data had been collected, several steps of cleaning and processing were necessary. Initially,
the data was exported from Netlytic in several CSV ﬁles. Some of these contained errors that
needed to be manually handled, including malformed separation in CSV ﬁelds, mismatch between
headers and data ﬁelds, line ending inconsistencies, and invalid characters that were unable to be

hydration process. This process involves querying the Twitter API with the list of identiﬁers for
the desired tweets, and have it return the complete publicly available data for each tweet, a task
for which we used the Hydrator desktop tool6. The additional data from this process was also
incorporated into the Netlytic data, and formed the complete initial data set from 2020, which
amounted to a total of 21,675,705 unique tweets.

and 20 words, values which were close to the median values from the beginning of the collection

3.2.1 Sentiment Analysis
Sentiment analysis is a task of natural language processing which aims to uncover the feelings and
emotions contained in a piece of text. There are three main approaches to performing sentiment
analysis: lexicon, rule, and learning-based [ 18]. In the lexicon-based approach, a dictionary of
words orn-grams with their corresponding sentiment labels is used as the basis for detecting
sentiment in text. The sentiments represented by these words are aggregated in some form, such
as averaging, to compute the overall sentiment for the entire text. In order to help overcome
some of the shortcomings of this simple method, rules can also be used as an additional step.
These rules aim to enhance the identiﬁcation of sentiments by taking into account the order of
co-occurrence of words. As an example, a rule for detecting negation can consider the presence
of the word “not” to reverse the sentiment of the succeeding words, therefore giving a positive
sentiment to the expression “not bad”. Another straightforward rule is considering the intensity
of the sentiment, distinguishing diﬀerent sentiment values between “really good” and “extremely
good”, for example. Finally, the learning-based approach relies on machine learning models
instead of dictionaries and decision rules. In this approach, the system learns to distinguish what
tokens represent diﬀerent sentiments based on previously labeled examples it is fed.
We performed sentiment analysis on the tweets using three diﬀerent Python libraries:
TextBlob [ 50], VADER [ 39], and Stanza [ 70]. TextBlob is a library for processing textual
data, and includes rule-based sentiment analysis. Its main appeal is combining ease of use
with powerful functionality, based on the established NLTK and pattern libraries. VADER is a
lexicon and rule-based sentiment analysis tool speciﬁcally attuned to sentiments expressed in
social media, which makes it an interesting library to test for this project. Its desirable features
include interpreting negations, slang, punctuation, and emoji when computing the sentiment
of a document. Stanza is an NLP library maintained by the Stanford NLP Group, the team
behind the popular CoreNLP library. Unlike the other two libraries mentioned, Stanza uses
deep learning techniques for NLP tasks, and provides models trained on data sets which include
24 Chapter 3. The Data
Twitter posts for sentiment analysis.
One of the most elementary tasks in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given
piece of text. Polarity is a measure that represents the sentiment of some text, and ranges
from negative, to neutral, to positive. TextBlob and VADER provide a compound score, from
-1 to 1, indicating how negative or how positive the input text is. In order to standardize the
classiﬁcation of positive, neutral, and negative text, we used the following typical threshold
values [39]:
•positive : compound polarity ≥0.05;
•neutral: compound polarity >−0.05and compound polarity <0.05;
•negative : compound polarity ≤−0.05.
On the other hand, Stanza outputs instead a categorical value of positive, neutral, or negative
per sentence. In order to obtain a similar compound score, we assigned 1 to positive sentences,
0 to neutral sentences, and -1 to negative sentences. These values were summed up and the
resulting value was used with the thresholds shown above to arrive at the ﬁnal polarity for the
whole tweet.
The result of the sentiment analysis was uneven, as shown in ﬁgure 3.3. Stanza seems more
likely to classify tweets as negative, and classify few as neutral or positive. TextBlob and VADER
both have a high amount of positively-classiﬁed tweets—however, while VADER classiﬁes many
as negative, TextBlob favors a neutral classiﬁcation. Overall, only 24.7% of tweets were classiﬁed
the same by all libraries. Thus, to ensure consistency and to provide security that sentiment-based
features would reﬂect the actual meaning contained in tweets, the 2020 data set was ﬁltered to
tweets where the same polarity category was identiﬁed by all three libraries, leaving 3,252,751
tweets in the data set after this processing step.
3.2.2 Named Entity Recognition
Before trying to distinguish what constitutes real and fabricated information (which is composed
of facts), one question must be answered ﬁrst: What is a fact? One simple answer is that a fact is
something that occurs at a given time, somewhere, and with or to something or someone [ 21]. In
other words, a fact should answer the questions of “who,” “where,” and “when”. These answers
can be associated with named entities in the text, which are, simply put, real-world objects
that can be indicated by a proper name, and numeric expressions. They are classiﬁed into
diﬀerent categories, including person, organization, location, and time [ 62], and therefore can
help provide the aforementioned answers that characterize a fact. The complete list of 18 entity
types commonly used for NER and their descriptions [96] is shown in table 3.3.
There are automated ways of extracting named entities from the text, in a sub-task of the
Information Extraction ﬁeld called Named Entity Recognition (NER). We used two Python

3.2.3 Data Labeling
When considering whether to work with one of published data sets dedicated to fake news
detection or to create our own data set, we opted for the latter. Collecting data ourselves
provided more ﬂexibility in how that data was obtained, enabling keyword-based collection
or account-based collection in response to diﬀerent needs, as well as changing the context as
necessary.
In addition to that, performing the data collection ourselves allowed us to avoid as much as
possible the data set decay problem (described in section 2.2.1), which is a common challenge
to be faced in this ﬁeld of study. Tweets are removed over time, either by their own authors
or, more recently, by Twitter in its eﬀorts to counter the spread of fake news and misuse of its
platform7. Since Twitter terms of service restrict the redistribution of tweet content to third
parties8, and only allow distributing data sets composed of identiﬁer codes, these data sets
have to be “hydrated” to provide the complete data, which makes it important to work with
recently collected data in order to access as much of it as possible. Even in our 2020 data set, by
the end of December (approximately three months after the beginning of the data collection),
approximately 19% of the tweets had already been deleted or came from subsequently suspended
accounts.
Manually annotating tweets for the reliability of their contents is a massive undertaking with
substantial eﬀort and, in many cases, expert knowledge required in order to create a sizable data
set. In this research we evaluated a manual labeling process. The ﬁrst step in this process was
searching fact-checking websites such as PolitiFact and Snopes for validated information related
to our data set context, the 2020 US presidential election and its candidates. Then we ﬁltered
our data set based on keywords associated with that veriﬁed information. Finally, we manually
labeled each tweet based on its contents and its stance regarding the veriﬁed information. As

3.3 Data Samples
Due to the nature of the fake news problem, an imbalanced volume of reliable content versus
questionable content is to be expected. In the ﬁrst data set, with keyword-based tweet collection
from September to December 2020, the proportion of fake tweets was approximately 5% of the
whole data set. This is common to many real-world data sets and constitutes a problem to
many machine learning algorithms when attempting to learn a concept from an underrepresented
class [48]. An eﬀective solution to overcome this issue is applying re-sampling techniques to
change the data distribution [ 10]. These techniques include two common approaches: removing
examples from the majority class until the desired class balance is achieved (undersampling), or
conversely generating new examples for the minority class (oversampling), which can be done
by simply replicating existing examples from the minority class or by synthesizing non-existing
examples for the minority class based on underlying distributions [ 44]. The most straightforward
types of these approaches are random undersampling and random oversampling, where new
examples of the respective class are randomly removed or replicated. Another popular option for
oversampling is SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique), where a new example
of the minority class is synthesized by interpolation with one of its nearest neighbors [15].
Each of these techniques presents its own beneﬁts and challenges. While performing random
undersamplingcanpotentiallyremoveimportantexamplesfromthedataset—thereforedecreasing
classiﬁcation performance—random oversampling can lead to model overﬁtting, which in turn
will result in decreased performance [ 10,35]. We compared three re-sampling methods: random
undersampling, random oversampling, and SMOTE. Out of those three approaches, random
undersampling showed the most promising results in our initial experiments, therefore we chose

Chapter 4
Classiﬁcation Model
Based on the data described in the last chapter, in this research we strove to use only information
that could be obtained from each speciﬁc tweet, such as the text content, and tweet and user
metadata, in order to automatically classify a tweet. In other words, we only need a tweet and
its direct data to classify it, instead of relying on the tweet author’s other posts, on the posts of
its network of neighbors, or on the content from replies. This streamlines the process of deriving
features for use in classiﬁcation and helps with scalability.
This chapter details our feature engineering process and the reasoning behind our decisions.
4.1 Features
Once the data were gathered, processed, and labeled, we went through the process of deriving
features to be used in our classiﬁcation model. Since our research question RQ3is to investigate
the contribution of named entities and emotion recognition to the identiﬁcation of fake news, the
features were split into two groups: a baseline set of features, and an “extended” set, containing
all features present on the baseline set plus features based on named entities and emotions.
4.1.1 Baseline Features
The baseline features can be further divided into three main groups: metadata from the author
proﬁle, metadata from the tweet itself, and linguistic attributes derived from the tweet content.
These features are summarized in table 4.1.

and fake news consumption, with several attributes from a user’s proﬁle that have the potential

this research we implemented some features directly derived from a tweet author’s proﬁle, as
detailed in table 4.1. The values for each feature of this group, such as the number of posts by

Tweet metadata potentially also has the ability to help distinguish tweets associated with
unreliable content. As we have discussed, with the goal of eliciting a strong emotional response, a
tweet with fake news may employ a picture or video to grab the reader’s attention [ 14]. Therefore
we used a Boolean feature to indicate the presence or not of media (image or video) in the tweet.
Additionally, since tweet replication plays a big part in fake news dissemination [ 88], we also
used as features the number of times the tweet was retweeted (if any), and also a ﬂag indicating
whether the tweet itself is a retweet. Finally, in the tweet metadata group, we also used the
number of times a tweet as marked as favorite [84].
The third group contains features derived from the tweet content. With this group the
aim was to leverage the actual textual content of the tweet, and derive features representing
linguistic attributes typical of fake news text that could contribute to classifying a tweet. These
are described in detail in the following paragraphs.
4.1. Features 37
As was the case with some features in the tweet metadata group, with the text content we
aimed to leverage the fact that fake news attempt to generate a strong emotional response in
the reader. With the goal of quantifying some of the means by which that could be achieved, a
number of features were created. Feature proportion_all_caps represents the proportion of words
in the tweet body that are written in all capital letters, which are a prominent attribute for many
fake news article titles [ 38,89]. These are meant to draw the reader’s attention and convey the
text in an exaggerated and sensationalist tone. In this research we took an additional step and
computed that proportion excluding usernames, hashtags, and named entities recognized by the
NER task. This last measure was intended to exclude from the computation words and acronyms
(e.g. US, GOP, DNC) that are written in capital letters but have no underlying sensationalist
intention, leaving only words that would not necessarily have to be written completely in capital
letters.
Another stylistic feature in the text that represents inﬂated emotions is the use of exclamation
points, particularly when they are employed in excess [ 99]. Therefore we included as a feature the
number of exclamation points contained in the tweet. In that vein, we also considered the number
of adverbs and adjectives present in the tweet text [ 75,83]. Adverbs are description words that
are auxiliary to verbs, and are capable of adding urgency or other emotions to the verbs they
describe, contributing to the aforementioned sensationalism in the text [ 72,78]. Adjectives are
modiﬁer words for nouns, and can similarly increase the level of expressiveness in a text [ 59]. As
done for the proportion_all_caps feature, when computing the number of adverbs and adjectives,
we also excluded username mentions and hashtags. The number of adverbs and adjectives was
also computed as a proportion. This gives more weight to these classes of words when they are
more prominent in the text, in an attempt to capture the underlying stylistic structure and
quantify said expressiveness of the text potentially better than a simple count would [101].

increase the likelihood of an article or post being shared. Conversely, the same work concluded

aim of quantifying and measuring these attributes, the polarity (discussed in section 3.2.1) of a

4.1.2 Text Representation
Since the main portion of our data set is text-based, namely the content of the tweets themselves,
being able to leverage the content information when classifying tweets could potentially lead to
better overall results. However, as discussed in section 2.1.2, we cannot directly use raw text
data with many classiﬁcation algorithms. It is necessary ﬁrst to apply transformations to textual
data in order to obtain a numerical representation suitable for use as input to those algorithms.
Before applying any of the techniques mentioned in section 2.1.2 to obtain a numerical
representation of text, several pre-processing steps were performed. First, all text was converted
to lower case, and all links were removed. Then, we also removed any usernames mentioned in
the tweet. This step is particularly important in this scenario due to our data labeling process
(described in section 3.2.3). Since that process is based on the information publisher’s level
of factual reporting, in case that publisher is mentioned as a username, the presence of that
speciﬁc token could be highly correlated to the target label, and result in a mistakenly optimistic
classiﬁcation performance. Additionally, all hashtags were converted to words by removing the
“#” character. Then, lemmatization was applied using the spaCy library to derive the lemma for
each word. Finally, in order to maintain only words capable of conveying meaningful information,
we removed all stop words based on spaCy’s integrated list of English stop words.
In order to leverage the tweet content as features for use in classiﬁcation purposes, in this
work we compared diﬀerent versions of all of these approaches to represent the tweet text as
feature vectors, summarized in table 4.2. Using the bag of words with unigrams as tokens, we
computed three diﬀerent feature vectors for comparison: using token counts, using a Boolean
value to indicate whether the token is present in document, and weighing each token using
TF-IDF. In addition to these representations, we also constructed a bag of unigrams and a bag
of bigrams. The two resulting matrices were combined to create a feature vector of unigram and
bigram counts for each document. Finally, the last experiment with the bag of words approach
consisted of employing character n-grams, instead of n-grams composed of words. In a bag of
unigrams, any misspellings or variations are considered completely diﬀerent tokens. By using
charactern-grams, we can attempt to circumvent that limitation, so that the feature vectors
generated for misspelled words are more similar to the vectors for the correct words than if we
were using a bag of words. Since the quality and register of text in Twitter is very diverse, and
word misspellings and variations are common, we decided to experiment with this approach
for representing tweets. The character 2-grams were composed only of characters from a single
word—no character 2-grams were generated with characters from two diﬀerent words—padded
with space when necessary.
In addition to the bag of words approach, we also employed two diﬀerent applications of word
embeddings. We used pre-trained 300-dimension word embeddings from the en_core_web_lg
spaCy model, which contains 685,000 unique GloVe [ 66] vectors trained on the Common Crawl5
corpus, a large data set containing petabytes of web data collected since 2008. In order to

4.1.3 Named Entity Recognition

Horne and Adali have observed that titles for fake news articles tend to use more proper
nouns than regular articles [ 38]. The identiﬁcation of these proper nouns is one of the goals of
named entity recognition. In addition, given the short nature of text in tweets—with its 140 or,
more recently, 280-character limitation—it bears resemblance to the structure of article titles [ 79].
Therefore, we attempted to leverage those insights by computing the number of mentions to

4.1.4 Emotion Recognition
In addition to named entity recognition, we investigated the application of emotion recognition
to fake news identiﬁcation. Our goal was twofold: ﬁrst, to investigate if any emotions were more
prevalent on tweets associated with fake news than with reliable content, and also to investigate
if there were any sequences of emotions typical of one of those classes.
To compute the emotions, we used the NRCLex6Python library. The library makes use
of the National Research Council Canada (NRC) word-emotion association lexicon [ 58], which
contains associations of words with eight emotions ( anger,anticipation ,disgust,fear,joy,sadness,
surprise, andtrust) and two sentiments ( negative andpositive). This lexicon was manually
annotated by crowdsourcing, and each word can be associated with multiple emotions. On top
of the 10,000 words in the NRC lexicon, the NRCLex library uses NLTK WordNet synonyms to
expand the volume to a total of 27,000 words.
Before computing the emotions, several pre-processing steps were performed in each tweet,
similarly to what was described for text representation in section 4.1.2. First, since NRCLex
content is in lower case letters, the text in all tweets was converted to lower case. Then, any links
were removed, and hashtags were converted to words by removing the leading “#” character.
Since the many uses of hashtags include expressing emotions [ 13], removing the “#” character
was necessary to allow the resulting word to be analyzed and categorized by NRCLex. The
next step was lemmatizing the text, extracting the lemma for each word. Since NRCLex uses
a dictionary-based approach to matching words to emotions, this step was important in order
to obtain as many matches as possible. A ﬁnal step of pre-processing, needed in this speciﬁc
case study, was removing the word “Trump” from the tweets. Due to the context of our case
study and data collection process, that word, referring to former US president Donald Trump, is
very common in the data set, appearing in 62% of tweets in O1. That proper noun is neutral
and indicates no emotion, however it is mistakenly recognized as the verb “to trump” by the
NRCLex library, resulting in a misleading prevalence of the “surprise” aﬀect associated with that
word in the emotion lexicon.
The computed emotions were used as the basis for a number of features, which are discussed
in the following sections.

4.1.4.2 Emotion n-grams
The inﬂuence of the sequence of prevalent emotions in a tweet was also investigated in a number
of experiments. For each sentence, the most frequent emotion was computed, resulting in a
sequence of prevailing emotions in a tweet. Then, sequences analogous to n-grams were extracted,
where each prevalent emotion represents one item in the sequence. Due to the short length
of text in tweets, these sequences were limited to bigrams and trigrams of emotions. These
4.1. Features 47
sequences represent the ﬂow of emotions through a piece of text, more precisely between one
sentence and the next in the case of bigrams. In case there were any ties, where more than one
emotion was found to be prevalent in a sentence, these were combined in a “composite” emotion.
For example, in case a sentence contained the emotions fearandsadnesswith equal frequency,
these were combined into fear_sadness . These composite emotions were limited to a maximum
of three single emotions. When more than three emotions were the most frequent in a sentence,
we considered it was not possible to systematically determine the actual prevalent emotion in
that sentence and the sentence was ignored.

With the goal of identifying which n-grams, if any, are typical of fake or non-fake tweets, the

typical if they were at least 25% more frequent in one class versus the other.
Due to the short length in tweets, trigrams were usually infrequent and for that reason

Next, in an attempt to identify more typical bigrams, we reduced the 8 basic emotions used
in the NRCLex lexicon into a diﬀerent set of 6 basic emotions, proposed by Ekman [ 20]. For this
experiment, surprise was converted into fear, anddisgustwas converted into anger. In case a
word already represented both emotions, we ignored the former and kept only the latter emotion
(i.e.fearoranger), so as not to increase the emotion weight when computing their frequency.
As with the previous experiment, no signiﬁcant improvement in the results were obtained, so we
decided to keep all 8 original emotions.
We also explored converting emojis into natural language, in an attempt to increase the
number of words capable of expressing emotions in a tweet. However, this experiment did
not result in a substantial change in the number of typical bigrams identiﬁed or in the ﬁnal
classiﬁcation metric.
Finally, we investigated expanding the initial emotion n-grams by incorporating a neutral
emotion. While in the initial version, we ignored the sentences where no dominant emotion was
identiﬁed, in this experiment we considered their dominant emotion to be neutral. As a result,
the top recognized emotion was neutral, being approximately three times as frequent as the next

frequency about two times higher in fake versus non-fake tweets. In this experiment, there was
a decrease in the classiﬁcation metric, so the inclusion of the neutralemotion was not taken
further.

of the emotion bigrams (described in table 4.6), using as features the number of typical fake
and non-fake bigrams contained in each tweet. This version maintains the complete emotion
recognition provided by the NRCLex library, and provided the best results in our classiﬁcation

4.2 Methodology
Five diﬀerent algorithms were selected for evaluation, which included Naive Bayes, Decision
Trees, Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and AdaBoost. For Support Vector Machines,
we used the radial basis function kernel, and for AdaBoost we used one-level decision trees as
the weak learner. For all algorithms, we made use of the implementations in the scikit-learn [ 65]
machine learning framework in Python. We tested all models on two diﬀerent feature sets:
baseline and extended, as discussed on section 4.1.
All training was performed using the S1sample, which is composed of 6,000 tweets. With
values learned from that training set, features were standardized by removing the mean and
scaling to unit variance.
The next step was running 5-fold cross validation on the training set for hyperparameter
tuning, using the same folds for all models tested so their results could be directly compared.
Our strategy for hyperparameter tuning was to use randomized search, a process which involves
iterating a given number of times over diﬀerent hyperparameter values in order to identify which
values yield the best results. In each iteration with this approach, for each hyperparameter to be
56 Chapter 4. Classiﬁcation Model
tuned, a distribution or list of values is supplied. Those values are randomly combined and each
combination is used to train the cross validation models using data from each of the 5 training
folds. These models are then used to make predictions for each validation fold, and the resulting
F1-scores were computed and averaged. This process was repeated 100 times for each tested
algorithm using the baseline and extended feature sets. The models with the best classiﬁcation
results on the validation set had their hyperparameter values used to train a ﬁnal model for each
algorithm on the whole training set. Table 4.9 shows the list of values tested and eventually
selected in the randomized hyperparameter search for each algorithm.

Chapter 5
Results
In this chapter we present the results of our experiments, compare them to each other and discuss
their implications in relation to the research questions posed in chapter 1.
5.1 Complete Feature Set
First, we provide the results obtained from using all proposed features, which include features
based on the user proﬁle, tweet metadata and content, named entity recognition, emotion
recognition, and text vectorization, discussed in chapter 4. The main metrics used to evaluate
the models’ performances were F1-score, precision, recall, and accuracy. The metrics obtained
from running the tuned models against test set T1are presented in table 5.1.
The metrics were uniformly high, with a weighted F1-score of 0.92 from all models, except
for the 0.90 F1-score from Naive Bayes. The models were particularly eﬀective in identifying
non-fake tweets, with an F1-score of 0.95 from the top performing models. The performance on
detecting fake news was lower, with a recall of 0.68 and a best precision of 0.51. The main reason
for the low precision in this sample can be attributed to the class imbalance. Although the false
positive rate was relatively low, at 6%, the class imbalance close to 5%–95% means the models
are likely to generate almost as many false positives as true positives. Nevertheless, we regard
the weighted F1-score of 0.92 satisfactory enough to answer positively to RQ1, and consider it
is possible to automatically distinguish tweets associated with reliable versus unreliable content
based on a set of features.
There were virtually no changes to the resulting metrics between the baseline and extended
feature sets, though, which prevents us from answering RQ3through this experiment. This stems
from the eﬀectiveness of the bag of words-derived features, which overshadowed the remaining
features. The txt_vector_pred feature (described in section 4.1.2) had so much discriminating
power that it was the sole feature considered by decision trees and AdaBoost (using the decision
tree as the weak learner), as well as carrying 70% of the importance in the random forest with
the extended feature set.

Additionally, the results shown in table 5.2 enable us to answer RQ2. Since there was an
approximately six-month time gap between the data collections for T1andA1, the results we
obtained support the ﬁnding that the models are applicable to data sets collected with a time
period between them.
In order to conﬁrm our expectation of higher performance when classifying retweets of content
that was present in the training sample, we also evaluated the models on test set A2. Indeed,
we obtained perfect results for all models but Naive Bayes. However, instead of indicating a
strong performance, this is a sign of overﬁtting to the training data, since the most important
features are directly derived from the text content and are, therefore, identical to feature values
in samples from training set S1. For that reason we cannot consider the output from these
models to be representative of their performance on new data, which supports our decision to
remove all retweets from the training set.
Regarding application on test set A3, results were as expected, given its creation as a sort
of intermediate set between T1andA1. Accordingly, we obtained intermediate values for the
metrics, in line with the results from the two mentioned sets.
The results presented so far were achieved by using the txt_vector_pred feature as a Boolean
value, obtained from converting the real output of the SVM text classiﬁcation model into a
Boolean value denoting the predicted class. This was done with a threshold computed through
cross validation on the training data with the goal of maximizing informedness. Complementing

5.3 Re-sampling Methods
All the results and discussion presented throughout this dissertation consider the use of random
undersampling to balance the class distribution in our data set. However, as discussed in
section 3.3, we also experimented with random oversampling and SMOTE and compared those
approaches with the results obtained with random undersampling. The experiments with
oversampling methods were conducted with the same feature sets and algorithms discussed in
section 5.2.
Theoutcomewasassuggestedbyourinitialexperiments, whererandomundersamplingshowed
consistently better results. With both random oversampling and SMOTE, the models favored
the negative (majority) class. With random oversampling, that eﬀect was more pronounced, and
diﬀerent models classiﬁed virtually all tweets as non-fake. Therefore, the recall was very low,
with a conversely high number of false negatives. The experiments with SMOTE were more
balanced in that regard, even though a tendency toward negative classiﬁcation could still be
observed. The results showed a higher number of true negatives and a lower number of false
62 Chapter 5. Results
positives. However, more false negatives were generally observed as well.
With regard to the AUC on these experiments, almost all models had a lower value with
either oversampling method in comparison with undersampling. The notable exceptions were the
random forest and SVM models with SMOTE, which were able to maintain the same general
AUC values as with random undersampling. However, as discussed, these were obtained with a
slant towards the classiﬁcation of the negative class, resulting in a lower recall of fake tweets.

Theconﬂictingresultsdiscussedinsection5.2werenotenoughtoenableustoanswersatisfactorily
toRQ3. Therefore, in order to further compare the baseline and extended sets, we also
assessed the relative contribution of each individual feature by considering the mean decrease in
impurity (MDI) to estimate their importance in three of the tested algorithms: decision tree,
random forest, and AdaBoost. The comparison of feature importance is shown in ﬁgure 5.2. The
feature with the most consistently large contribution was the proportion of words in all capital
letters, by itself responsible for close to 30% of the MDI in the decision tree-based models. Other
important features, for both baseline and extended sets, are those based on the user’s proﬁle,
including the number of friends, followers, and posts, time of account creation and number of
posts marked as favorite, which collectively help demonstrate the signiﬁcance of data from a
user’s proﬁle for fake news classiﬁcation in a social media context. With regard to content-based
and linguistic attributes, the number of username mentions in the text of a tweet was also
generally important for all three models, and, to a lesser degree, the proportion of adjectives and
adverbs, as well as the sentiment polarity.
When considering the extended set of features, we observed the baseline features described
above were still the major contributors in MDI, specially in the random forest model, whose
baseline model had the same top 10 features ranked for importance as the model with extended
features. However, with extended features they accounted of 59.6% of the MDI, instead of
93.2%. A major part of the remaining contribution was provided by features based on emotion
recognition, most notably emotion frequencies. Collectively, their highest contribution among
the three models was a 28% MDI with Random Forest. Among named entity-based features,
entropy had the single highest contribution in the three models.
Therefore, while the top baseline features still ranked higher on the extended models, the
contribution of the extended features was evident when assessing their importance, which supports
a conclusion that emotion and entity-based features can be helpful in fake news classiﬁcation as
an answer to RQ3. It is also interesting to note that roughly the same features, both on the
baseline and extended sets, ranked similarly on diﬀerent algorithms, attesting to the validity of
their general importance.

Chapter 6
Conclusions
Since the popularization of the term “fake news” by former US president Donald Trump in 2016,
the problem of their proliferation has been nothing but ampliﬁed, going so far as to potentially
aﬀect election outcomes, inﬂuence economic decisions, negatively impact public health and the
public debate, mine trust in news organizations, and ultimately skew people’s perceptions about
the world. This is a serious collective problem which requires a multidisciplinary approach to its
mitigation, from reeducating readers about news consumption to technological solutions that
help curb the reach of misinformation. As the widespread use of social media has contributed
to the dissemination of fake news in ever-increasing volumes, any tool that helps identify these
items, hopefully automatically, is an important asset in the arsenal against fake news.
This chapter presents a general summary of the work that was performed to help tackle
that problem, along with a recapitulation of the research questions, and some conclusions that
were taken as a result. Finally, we also discuss some limitations and challenges, and provide
opportunities of future work.
6.1 General Summary
The work conducted in this research involved several stages. First, we deﬁned the scope of
our case study—the 2020 US presidential election, more speciﬁcally through posts on social
media platform Twitter. Then the data collection was planned and carried out, with a ﬁrst
phase between September and December 2020, and a second phase in May 2021. The process of
preparing the data ensued, encompassing cleaning and pre-processing tasks in order to get the
data ready for further processing. These were followed by a data selection step, where we chose
a subset of data, based on criteria including length and sentiment analysis concordance, with the
goal of ensuring it was consistent and capable of providing useful features for classiﬁcation.
In order to obtain a ground truth against which to perform classiﬁcation, we adopted
a systematic data labeling process with a publisher-based approach. This process involved
leveraging the level of factual reporting of a news website, as deﬁned by human experts, to label
65
66 Chapter 6. Conclusions
tweets that contained links to those websites. This process enabled us to overcome the scale
problem of obtaining a sizable labeled data set essential to verifying the validity of our results.
With the pre-processed and labeled data ready, the next step was performing feature
engineering. After a review of other studies in this ﬁeld, we derived a set of relevant features,
focused on linguistic attributes, text content, and social media metadata. These were considered
our baseline features. Aiming to answer one of our research questions and investigate the potential
contribution of features derived from named entities and emotion recognition, an additional set of
features was devised, which we called the extended set. These included a group of features based
on named entity recognition in which diﬀerent entity types were grouped into categories such as
who,where, andwhen, with the goal of identifying relevant entities that could characterize a fact,
as well as a feature computing the variability of entities mentioned in a tweet. Emotion-based
features included the frequency of eight basic emotions and two sentiments, and the number
of times emotions were conveyed in the tweet, based on emotion-carrying words, with the aim
of capturing a tweet’s emotional intensity. Additionally, we explored features derived from the
sentence-based sequencing of emotions in the ﬂow of text, using emotionn-gramsto identify
n-grams typical of fake or non-fake tweets.
Additionally, for select features, we ran several experiments in order to compare diﬀerent
versions of the constructed features and assess which showed more potential discriminating power
for our classiﬁcation task. These were then selected to compose the ﬁnal set of selected features.
With those selected features, we compared ﬁve diﬀerent machine learning algorithms to seek
the best performance for each feature set, and attempt to answer the three research questions
posed in chapter 1. Those questions are restated below, along with the answers obtained in the
course of this project.
•RQ1: Is it possible to automatically identify posts associated with fake news
based on a set of features? With the complete set of proposed features, we were able
to achieve a 0.92 weighted F1-score on a test set. Therefore, we answer positively to this
question, and conclude it is possible to leverage a set of features to automatically identify
tweets associated with fake news.
•RQ2: How does a time gap between the model creation and its use impact the
identiﬁcation of fake news? To answer this question, we made use of an account-based
data set collected approximately six months after the initial data collection. We observed
even improved results over the performance on the previous test set, with a weighted
F1-score of 0.97, and enhanced detection of fake news, with a F1-score of 0.81 on that class
of tweets. Therefore, we conclude it is possible to employ a model to classify data with a
time gap between the model’s creation and its application.
•RQ3: Is it possible to improve classiﬁcation performance using features based
on emotions and named entities? After comparing the models’ performances on the
baseline and extended features sets, the results were conﬂicting. While lower-performing
6.2. Contributions 67
models displayed a decrease in performance with the addition of features based on emotions
and named entities, the best-performing models—random forest and AdaBoost—actually
had their performance increased with the use of those features. Therefore, we can conclude
those features potentially have discriminating power and are indeed helpful for fake news
classiﬁcation, although we believe further work should be conducted for a more conclusive
answer.
6.2 Contributions
In the course of answering these research questions, this study oﬀers a number of contributions,
which are listed below.
•We have created a data set of tweets focusing on the 2020 US presidential election,
comprising data from over three months, centered on the election day. It was systematically
annotated containing tweets with links to news content, using an approach based on the
publishers’ level of factual reporting. The result is an annotated data set of fake news and
legitimate content from Twitter, composed of approximately 144k tweets associated with
reliable content and 7k associated with unreliable content.
•We demonstrate the applicability of a set of features based on diﬀerent characteristics of
a tweet—text content, linguistic attributes, user proﬁle, post metadata—for fake news
identiﬁcation in Twitter with satisfactory results in a comparison of diﬀerent machine
learning models. Additionally, we point out this approach is based only on data that can
be obtained from an individual tweet—as opposed to approaches based on a user’s history
or on a post’s propagation ﬂow—which means a tweet is potentially ready for classiﬁcation
as soon as it is posted, enabling early detection and helping to prevent the harm caused by
fake news dissemination.
•We show the relevance of features derived from named entities and emotion recognition in
the automatic identiﬁcation of fake news. We demonstrate in particular the applicability of
using emotion frequencies and the entity type entropy as features. In addition, we employ
sequences of prevalent emotions per sentence, analogous to n-grams, in order to identify
sequences of emotions typical of fake and non-fake tweets, for use in classiﬁcation.
•We have submitted a paper to the WEBIST’21 conference (already approved), which
demonstrates some of the results obtained in this work [7].
6.3 Limitations
Regarding the general classiﬁcation of tweets associated with fake news content, we can name a
number of limitations and challenges faced in this work.
68 Chapter 6. Conclusions
In connection with feature engineering, one limitation we dealt with is that it was not possible
to use links in tweets, i.e., the news source, as basis for any features. The reputation of a
source has been considered by human evaluators as the most important factor in assessing tweet
credibility [ 40]. In fact it is such a strong indicator that it formed the basis for our automatic
labeling process. On the other hand, the features derived from tweets labeled based on links
generalized well to tweets without regard to the presence of links, and also with other contents not
related to the US election. Additionally, some commonly used features for fake news classiﬁcation
based on text content, including the overall number of words or sentences, the number of words
per sentence, or other length-related features, are more suited for longer pieces of text, and could
not be easily explored for fake news classiﬁcation in shorter text content such as tweets.
Concerning the classiﬁcation task, the class imbalance presented a signiﬁcant challenge to
be faced. As discussed in section 5.1, even though the models generally displayed a relatively
low false positive rate, the high proportion of reliable to unreliable tweets translated into a high
number of false positives, i.e., a lower precision. Additionally, the need to collect and label our
own data led to limitations in the size of the created data set, which contained approximately
3,600 original tweets associated with fake news. Due to that resulting data set size, no neural
network or deep learning-based approaches were experimented with, since those techniques
commonly require more data in order to achieve acceptable performance [27].
6.4 Future Work
There are several promising possibilities for extending this work. The favorable classiﬁcation
results obtained by our model using the proposed set of features in the speciﬁc case study
investigated in this work raise the question of how well those results can be generalized to other
domains outside of politics. An encouraging initial result was obtained in this work, with the
good classiﬁcation performance on a test set with low vocabulary similarity to the one the model
was trained on. Nevertheless, a deeper investigation into the applicability of the classiﬁcation,
specially cross-domain, is an interesting direction for further research. This additional test set was
also collected with a time gap relative to the ﬁrst data set collection. Due to the time constraints
inherent to this research, that time gap consisted of approximately six months. While we obtained
good results using that data, an interesting option to examine is to make a comparison with
other test sets collected at diﬀerent intervals.
Regarding our proposed features, there is much room to expand with emotion and name
entity-based features. One option to be explored is narrowing down the emotions recognized for
each word. Since the NRC lexicon usually identiﬁes several emotions per word, when computing
emotion frequencies in a sentence, these emotions often overlap, potentially diluting some of the
information. Being able to precisely identify a single prevalent emotion in a word would likely
lead to a clearer representation of the overall prevalent emotions in a sentence. One possible
approach to tackle this problem is leveraging the context each word appears in. For example, if
a word that conveys the emotions of fearandsadnessappears between two segments with the
6.4. Future Work 69
prevailing emotion fear, that word could be deemed to express the fearas well, helping to ﬁlter
out extraneous emotions and provide a more precise identiﬁcation. One additional possibility for
enhancing the emotion recognition precision is leveraging the context speciﬁc to the investigated
data. As mentioned in section 4.1.4.2, the most frequent emotion in our 2020 data set— trust—is
present in words that are actually associated with the election process or to oﬃcial authorities,
i.e., they lack relative discriminating power in that context. Therefore, being able to take the data
context into consideration when identifying emotions in the text could lead to richer features.
In addition to emotion-based features, those based on named entities also contain room for
further investigation. In particular, we would like to deepen the relationship between recognized
entities, and look into ﬁnding semantic connections between diﬀerent entities in order to extract
a more precise representation of a tweet content and how it relates potentially false information
as a fact.
In all, we demonstrate in this work the potential for the automatic identiﬁcation of fake
news. We describe steps taken since the initial data collection and processing, using the 2020
US presidential election as the main context, with an automated labeling approach. We present
and compare the results of applying diﬀerent machine learning models to that data, and obtain
satisfactory performance from many models—notably based on random forest and AdaBoost—on
diﬀerent test sets created with diﬀerent approaches, showing the model is capable of generalizing
to other contexts. Additionally, we investigate and show the contribution of employing features
derived from named entities and emotion recognition in enhancing the automatic identiﬁcation
of fake news.
We believe the machine learning-based model proposed in this work to automatically identify
posts associated with fake news on Twitter has several possible uses. Since our model works
directly with data that can be obtained from individual posts, and is not reliant on propagation-
based features, it can be employed in an early warning system. As discussed in section 2.2.2, this
type of approach is vital in an attempt to contain as much damage as possible before harm is
irreversibly caused. Other possible uses range from alerting end-users about potentially unreliable
content, to assisting organizations, online content providers, and fact-checkers in automatically
ﬁltering questionable content for further screening, contributing to the mitigation of a serious
problem that aﬀects us all.

title: Kazakhstan's Proactive Measures in Addressing the Aral Sea Crisis as a Platform for Enhanced International Representation and Media Engagement

SDU Journal of Media Studies 2025/1 (1)
