seven edited volumes between 1984 and 1992,
comprising over 100 essays from French scholars.
Only three were translated into English, in the
1990s. But before these English translations, Nora’s
work and theories were brought to the attention of
English-speaking readers with the publication of an
essay by him summarizing his ideas in the journal
Representations (Nora, 1989).
For Nora, true milieux de m ´emoire are organic, and
typically associated with local, premodern, archaic—
and certainly primitive—s ocieties (Legg, 2005:
481, 494). In this regard, Nora’s propositions bear
a similarity to Ferdinand To ¨nnies’ concepts of
Gemeinschaft (an organic and archetypally rural com-
munity) and Gesellschaft (an associational and arche-
typally industrial society) (Harris, 2001). Nora is
nostalgic for what he sees as real collective memory,
formilieux de m ´emoire , he argues, are now rarely in
evidence.
The opposite is true of lieux de m ´emoire ,s a y s
Nora. Lieux de m ´emoire are receptacles of memory,
vehicles of commemoration or memorialization. They
can obviously be places (reflecting the direct transla-
tion from the French), but are also events, concepts,
performances, or publications. These serve as mne-
monic devices (artifacts or activities that aid human
memory). Infused with symbolic meaning, lieux de
m´emoire are sites where collective memory is crystal-
lized as representational components of communal
identity that monumentalize the past (Frier, 2019:
40; Legg, 2005: 496). What all lieux de m ´emoire have
in common is an ability to provoke an emotional
response (Legg, 2005: 482). They are far removed,
therefore, from being harbors of true memory. They
are pictured, in effect, as cenotaphs—“literally empty
graves” (Legg, 2005: 495).
L i e u xd em ´emoire are realms of memory that
“commemorate and sanctif y” the past (Schwartz,
2016: 12). As such, they are not far removed from the
concept of an invented tradition. According to Hobs-
bawm (1983: 1), an invented tradition is a set of prac-
tices “normally governed by overtly and tacitly
accepted rules and of a ritual or symbolic nature,
which seek to inculcate certain values and norms of
behaviour by repetition, which automatically implies
continuity with the past.” Many traditions that appear
to be old are in fact recent in origin and invented.
Further, they are not synonymous with customs,
which can evolve, unlike traditions, which aim at
invariance (Hobsbawm, 1983: 2).
According to Nora, lieux de m ´emoire —“invented
traditions,” as some might term them—have now
eclipsed milieux de m ´emoire . As authentic collectivememory eroded, the need to “archive and recollect
consciously”—that is, the urge to create lieux de
m´emoire —correspondingly grew (Legg, 2005: 489).
The tendency, Nora argued, has been for niche, local,
pre-existing, spontaneous memories to undergo
homogenization. What we c all collective memory,
explained Nora, is now, in fact,
the gigantic and breathtaking storehouse of a material
stock of what it would be impossible for us to remember,
an unlimited repertoire of what might need to be recal-
led...an autonomous institution of museums, libraries,
despositories, centres of documentation, and data banks.
(Nora, 1989: 13)
In other words, the practice of historical research and
writing, seen by some as a constructed and contrived
“science,” has become far more important than real
collective memory.
Nora’s theories of memory have not been assessed
without criticism. In virtually whatever setting one
chooses, manifold different memories—multiple
milieux de m ´emoire —have surely survived from the
distant past into the present (Legg, 2005: 494). For
example, memory can reside and survive in everyday
gestures, habits, rituals, clothing, postures, bodily
practices, and skills. In short, the body has the poten-
tial to retain “real” memories (Legg, 2005: 494, 498).
Like genes, culture is transmitted from one generation
to the next. Continuing the theme of organic “memory
from below,” in the case of lieux de m ´emoire it can be
observed that although the influence and impact of
authority is undeniable, not all acts and cultures of
commemoration by any means originate from author-
ity (Low and Oliver, 2012: 3). While it is true that
increasingly lieux de memoire are manufactured by
authority, from the state to corporations to various
groups of elites, it is also the case that many—perhaps
the majority—remain “bottom-up” in origin. Setti-
mini (2021) has reported that studies on how people
understand and define heritage have demonstrated
that “non-expert” communities have the capacity,
irrespective of the desir es of those manufacturing
heritage “from above,” to develop specific ways in
which to draw on the past to create the senses of place
and tradition. In short, ordinary people do not neces-
sarily buy into professional, political, and commercial
heritage discourses. Thus, in the 1990s, the British
historian Raphael Samuel (1994: 11) could be found
criticizing Nora for concentrating on official national
memory and thereby ignoring popular memory
attached to alternative, periphery, minority, and local
“identities of resistance.” This makes logical sense
when one considers that homogenizing lieux de698 IFLA Journal 50(4)
memoire would not be needed if free-acting had
mostly been silenced. Clearly, not all memory can
be homogenized on authority’s terms. Consider-
ation must be given to the power of counter-
memories, which challenge the core lieux de
memoire in circulation. Certainly, Nora’s nostal-
gia for milieux de m ´emoire —his perception that
they have evaporated—gives a very negative
impression of the existence of a post- or late-
modern heterogeneous, pluralist society (Legg,
2005: 493–494, 497, 498).
However, just as the creation of a definite division
between history and collective memory is difficult to
defend, within the latter the stark separation of mili-
eux de m ´emoire from lieux de m ´emoire can be chal-
lenged. For example, commemorative lieux de
m´emoire and free-formed milieux de m ´emoire might
be seen to have found joint expression in the burgeon-
ing heritage culture and industry (Hewison, 1987). In
his book Theatres of Memory , Samuel (1994)
explored the emergence of everyday retro-thinking
and retro-creativity, such as the retrofitting and design
of buildings signaling the importance of period living
and working, retro-chic fashion, “living history”
installations like outdoor museums, heritage walks
and tours, and local museums bursting at the seams
with interesting “old things” but organized with no
thematic plan in mind. Lowenthal (1996: ix) observed
that we have become possessed by the past: “All at
once, heritage is everywhere,” he wrote, “the whole
world is busy lauding—or lamenting—some past, be
it fact or fiction.
According to critics of heritage—the “heritage
baiters,” as Samuel (1994: 259) called them—history
has become popular not in terms of widening the
scope and appeal of the subject to groups previously
hidden or excluded from it, but in a less noble way, in
that under the spell of heritage, history becomes sani-
tized and simplified for commercial or “political” rea-
sons. The heritage mentality—some might say
“sentimentality”—has been generated by the accel-
eration of history, the increased speed and complexity
of life, encouraging people to look to the past for more
stable, less anxious times. Holders of power have
been able to tap into this mentality in order to
“market” heritage versions of history that are condu-
cive to authority or vested interests, with the main-
stream manifestations of heritage often being
“nationalist, top-down, c ommercial and tourism-
focused,” constituting a hegemonic discourse
(Robertson, 2016: 1). Heritage has moved from the
private sphere (most obviously expressed in the popu-
larization of genealogy) to the public realm, where the
meaning of heritage conforms to a definition thatcenters on material artifacts, landscapes, mythologies,
memories, and traditions, which are fashioned into
cultural, political, and economic resources for the
present (Howard and Graham, 2008: 3). As such, it
is argued that heritage undermines the true past,
debasing it for greedy and grasping ends (Lowenthal,
1996: x).
However, there is no doubting the fact that a great
deal of heritage activity has been of the bottom-up
kind—what Harvey (2008: 20) refers to as “small
heritages”—arising autonomously in the form of
self-actualizing local history and heritage groups that
exploit not only “the archive,” but also memory
(e.g. Balfron Heritage Group, 2023; Barford Heritage
Group, 2014; Ravensdale, 1982 ). Ordinary citizens
conducting heritage activities autonomously brings
them into contact with ancestors, serves as a commu-
nal glue, clarifies identity, and roots them in custom;
it engenders a shared legacy in terms of family and
community, race and nation (Lowenthal, 1996: x, 2).
In this respect, milieux de m ´emoire and lieux de
m´emoire are fused together.
The intersection of memory theory
and the history and collective memory
of national library and information
associations
Although Nora’s focus was on French national
history, his thinking, subject to qualification, can be
applied to virtually any community, imagined or real,
including that of the library and information profes-
sions and the national institutions that represent them
and advocate on their behalf.
Defying any proffered divide between history and
collective memory, the archives of a number of
library and information associations, as well as the
authentic collective memory swirling around them,
have been tapped to produce valuable lieux de
m´emoire in the form of national-association histories
(e.g. Deyoung, 2020; Munford, 1976; Thomison,
1978). Being “commemorative and congratulatory,”
as well as largely descriptive and non-theoretical,
such histories conform to the lieux de m ´emoire for-

infused with milieux de m ´emoire in that they originate
from a cultural gene pool of inherited awareness of
past professional activity, as evidenced by the over-
whelming presence of library and information profes-
sionals in the production of library and information
history (Carroll and Griffith, 2023).
L i e u xd em ´emoire have certainly become more
prominent in the library and information world.
“Lieux de m´ emoire,” wrote Nora (1989: 12),699 Black: Memory and amnesia in the archival practices of national library and information associations
“originate with the sense that there is no spontaneous
memory, that we must deliberately create archives,
maintain anniversaries, organize celebrations, pro-
nounce eulogies and notarize bills because such activ-
ities no longer occur natura lly.” Typically labeled
as “storehouses of knowledge,” library and infor-
mation professionals are better positioned philoso-
phically than most other expert occupations to
promote record-keeping. Indeed, the archives of
library and information institutions (certainly
library institutions) are relatively abundant, espe-
cially in relation to the time since the normative
formation of the profession—characterized by the
appearance of traits like pr ofessional associations,
journals, examinations, and registration—in the
second half of the 19th century. As will be dis-
cussed, however, the performance of national asso-
ciations in the area of record-keeping seemingly
does not match the culture of archiving evident in
institutions like public, university, national, and
even social libraries.
National associations are inveterate maintainers of
anniversaries and pronouncers of eulogies. A good
historical example of this is the various commemora-
tions of the life and service of Edward Edwards, Brit-
ain’s leading professional librarian of the Victorian
age and chief witness to the 1849 parliamentary com-
mittee that paved the way for the inaugural Public
Libraries Act of 1850 (Munford, 1963). In 1885,
Edwards died in poverty and isolation in Niton on the
Isle of Wight. In 1902, Edwards’ first biographer, the
library promoter and publisher Thomas Greenwood,
paid his debts and, in the cemetery of Niton Church,
erected a monument over his grave, the unveiling of
which was attended by librarians and representatives
of the Library Association (LA) (Greenwood, 1902).
In 1912, the Manchester Libraries Committee orga-
nized a dinner in Manchester Town Hall to celebrate
the centenary of Edwards’ birth, Edwards having been
the first librarian of Manchester Public Library, itself
the first free municipal library to open its doors in
Britain in 1852 (Munford, 1976: 86). In 1950, to cele-
brate the centenary of the Public Libraries Act, which
Edwards had done so much to bring about, a group
from the LA attended a service of commemoration at
Niton Church and afterwards laid a wreath on
Edwards’ grave, which the LA undertook to maintain
thereafter (Munford, 1976: 265). This commemora-
tive trend was reinvigorated in early 2023 when the
public library in Niton was renamed the Edward
Edwards Community Library (Whitmore, 2023).
Such actions indisputably come under the panoply
oflieux de m ´emoire , as does, ironically, Edwards’
own work on the (then) current state and history oflibraries internationally, as spelt out in great detail in
his exhaustive and aptly named book Memoirs of
Libraries (1859), in which, in authentic lieux de
m´emoire fashion, he excavated and publicized “the
archive.”
Moving into the present as well as onto a global
level, an anniversary lieu de m ´emoire is also exercis-
ing the minds of professionals linked to IFLA, which
celebrates its centenary in 2027. IFLA’s Library His-
tory Special Interest Group is seeking to compile a
commemorative collection of essays celebrating
IFLA’s achievements over the decades, and critically
examine certain themes that have emerged during its
history. A major tool for accomplishing this task will
be documents housed in IFLA’s own archive (in itself
alieu de m ´emoire ), held in the Koninklijke Bib-
liotheek (Royal Library of the Netherlands) in The
Hague (Lor, 2022).
Further lieux de m ´emoire connected to the
centenary commemorations are planned in the form
of oral-history testimonies elicited from IFLA offi-
cers, past and present (IFLA Library History Special
Interest Group, 2021). This oral-history project is in
the tradition of certain pr ojects run at a national
level. In the UK, for example, a set of 23 oral-
history interviews with leading librarians, many
closely involved with the LA, conducted in the
1970s was released in a “Librarians Speaking”
audio-cassette series, the lead interviewer being the
British public librarian David Gerard (1974–1976).
In 2001, the UK’s Library History Group (now the
Library and Information H istory Group, which oper-
ates under the auspices of the Chartered Institute of
Library and Information Pro fessionals (CILIP)) ini-

were conducted with a number of librarians about
their career history, after which transcripts of the
interviews were placed on the Group’s website
(Library and Information History Group, 2023).
Similar to the capture of audio career histories are

The archival practices of the world’s
national library and information
associations
The actual and potential richness of memory practices
in the library and information professions, whether
recorded in the “archive” or free-flowing through pro-
fessional networks, means that national library and
information associations would be foolish to ignore
the possible benefits that accompany either authentic
historical accounts or heritage marketing projects.
However, it would seem that few of IFLA’s constitu-
ent organizations have the requisite holdings and tools
to exploit these possibilities. This assessment is based
on the results of a study completed in 2008 by IFLA’s
Library History Section, the results of which were
published on the IFLA website in 2008 (Black,
2008). It is highly unlikely, it should be added, that
the situation noted in 2008 would have changed
a great deal today.
The first stage of the study involved an analysis of
the websites of the world’s national library and infor-
mation associations in order to detect the presence of
archives (with archives being defined as records that
have a value over the long term and are collected and
preserved for historical re search and institutional
memory). Surprisingly, the subject of an association’s
archives had a presence on only two websites—those
of the Australian Library and Information Association
and the American Library Association.
The second stage of the study was formed by the
distribution of a questionnaire to all national library
associations, defined for the purpose of the study as
the institution in a country with prime responsibility
for the professional accreditation and representation
of library and information professionals (and, in addi-
tion, to the Special Libraries Association, USA). The
archives of IFLA itself did not form part of the inves-
tigation. The questionnaire received 10 responses,
with these being from the Icelandic Library and
Information Science Association; Association of
Library and Information Professionals of the Czech
Republic; Special Libraries Association (USA);
CILIP (UK); Malta Library and Information Associ-
ation; Indonesian Library Association; Polish Librar-
ians’ Association; Swiss Libraries and Librarians’
Organization; American Library Association; and
Australian Library and Information Association. The
disappointing lower-than-expected engagement with
the study was possibly due to the questionnaire having
been provided in English only. However, consider-
ation must also be given to the possibility that the
good management of internally generated archives
is far from being a priority for many associations.All of the associations reported that they held
archives relating to their past, dating from the early
history of their organization. The holdings included
the papers of various internal bodies; reports, news-
letters, and correspondence; annual reports; news
releases; financial records; and personal papers as
well as membership lists and professional disserta-
tions. Some associations considered public-domain
organs such as association magazines, journals, and
yearbooks to form part of their archive (which is per-
haps a debatable categorization). Some associations
held archives relating to the history of other
organizations.
The responsibility for archiving the records of
special interest groups, branches, chapters, and divi-
sions attached to the associations was not seen to be
that of the associations, although the written archival
policies of some associations advised on how such
records could be deposited in local public—for exam-
ple, state or university—archives. Six of the associa-
tions retained their archives in-house. The other four
associations out-housed most of their archives (with
current records and semi-current records being kept,
naturally, in-house). The associations that out-housed
material were the Icelandic Library and Information
Science Association (deposited with the National and
University Library of Iceland, Reykjavik); CILIP
(deposited with University College London (UCL));
American Library Association (deposited with the
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign); and
Australian Library and Information Association
(deposited with the National Library of Australia and
state archival repositories). Seven associations
reported the existence of finding aids and lists for
their archival collections. At least two associations
denied access to the public and for another association
the conditions of access were unclear from the reply
given. Four associations stated categorically that they
had a written archives policy.
Case study: CILIP
One of the associations mentioned in the report
with a good record of archival management was
CILIP. CILIP was inaugurated in 2002 through the
amalgamation of the LA, established in 1877, and
the Institute of Information Scientists, established
in 1958 (Munford, 1976; Ward and White, 2021).
Upon the formation of CILIP, the archives of the
LA were deposited with UCL—specifically, with
its Special Collections Department, which is home
to a large collection of archives, manuscripts, and
rare books. This initial de posit of LA documents in
2002 was supplemented in the following year by701 Black: Memory and amnesia in the archival practices of national library and information associations
the deposit of the archives of the Institute of Infor-
mation Scientists.
UCL’s Special Collections Department is one of the
UK’s foremost university collections of manuscripts,
archives, rare books, and other printed materials. Some
collections (or parts of them) have been digitized,
including the papers of George Orwell and Jeremy Ben-
tham. The Department also holds UCL’s institutional
archive (including the records of the UK’s first library
school, established in 1919), as well as printed items
connected with UCL’s history. Following the initial
large deposits of the LA and Institute of Information
Scientists records with UCL in 2002 and 2003, respec-
tively, access to the collection was for a number of
years available at a satellite records repository approx-
imately a mile north of the UCL campus. Since then,
further out-housing has taken place and, in recent years,
the CILIP collection has been accommodated at the
UK’s National Archives in Kew, south-west London,
although readers are required to order documents
through UCL and consult them there. This arrangement
offers a high level of physical security for the collection
but, unlike a great many other documents housed in the
National Archives, access to it is obviously not instant.
Access is also compromised by the absence of a
detailed descriptive catalogue of the collection, of the
type found at the National Archives. The CILIP
Archive, as set out on the UCL Special Collections
website, is descriptively extremely sparse. It contains
13 broad categories of document and makes no men-
tion of the records of the Institute of Information
Scientists. The categories are as follows:
/C15Tedder bequest and other materials
/C15LA publications and conference papers
/C15Career Development Group papers
/C15LA Council minutes, Committee papers and
other Board papers
/C15LA Charter, by-laws, library license
/C15Discipline and subject study field of
librarianship
/C15Newspaper cuttings and library scrap books
/C15LA policy documents
/C15Awards
/C1519th and 20th century pamphlet collection
/C1519th and 20th century pamphlet collection,
relating to librarianship, literacy and social
reform
/C15Public libraries in the UK and overseas
/C15Miscellaneous papers (University College Lon-
don, 2023)
A much more detailed description of the CILIP
Archive is on the National Archives (2023) website,covering documents created between 1894 and 1999.
Unlike the UCL listing, this listing does refer to the
papers of the Institute of Information Scientists. The
CILIP Archive is relatively large, occupying 102.7
linear meters of shelving a t the National Archives
(five boxes of documents housed in this shelving con-
tain the records of the Institute of Information Scien-
tists). Online, the collection is barely catalogued.
However, a more detailed paper listing for the CILIP
Archive—referring to the records of the LA and the
Institute of Information Scientists—is available to
readers in the Special Collections Reading Room or,
as in my case recently, on special request at a distance
as a scanned document.
It is important to point out that the CILIP Archive
contains few records for the period after its formation
in 2002. Since then, it appears that the Special Collec-
tions Department at UCL has received only five archi-
val deposits from CILIP, comprising the papers of: the
IIS, in 2003 (as noted above); the Multimedia Infor-
mation and Technology Group, in 2004; the Career
Development Group and the Library Assistants Asso-
ciation, in 2008; and the A ssociation of Assistant
Librarians. It is worth noting here that CILIP, like the
LA before it, does not officially take responsibility for
the records of its special interest groups. Thus, the
absorption into the CILIP Archive of the records of the
Multimedia Information and Technology Group and
the Career Development Group would appear to be
accidental. A footnote to these seemingly unofficial
deposits is that in around 2005 CILIP’s Library and
Information History Group arranged for its records to
be organized and catalogued by volunteer students at
one of the UK’s schools of archive studies, as a pilot
study for transferring the records of other special inter-
est groups to the CILIP collection. Unfortunately, the
papers were lost in transit.
As is required by statute, CILIP maintains financial
records for a certain period, and these, together with
other records of governance covering recent years, are
available on the Chartered Institute of Library and
Information Professionals, 2024 website (located
under “Governance” at the foot of the page) Chartered
Institute of Library and Inf ormation Professionals,
2024. These records include annual trustees’ reports,
annual financial statements, and board minutes. It
would appear that paper versions (and probably elec-
tronic versions) of these core records of governance
relating to the period prior to the statutory period of
curation are secured in-house, along with other
papers, awaiting future deposit at UCL and subse-
quent transfer to the National Archives. It is not clear,
however, how these might be accessed before that
transfer occurs.702 IFLA Journal 50(4)
As for the future, much depends on CILIP’s current
program of organizational restructuring and reloca-
tion. As of late 2023, the individual with a remit for
the area of records and archives management had left
CILIP and the organization was awaiting the appoint-
ment of a new post-holder. There are also plans to
appoint a consultant archiv ist, whose job it would
be to prepare a fresh deposit of records for UCL, as
well as update CILIP’s Records and Information
Management Policy. Having spent decades at its pre-
mises in Ridgmount Street, Bloomsbury, in 2023
CILIP relocated to a space in the British Library. As
part of the relocation project, CILIP has moved the
paper records it currently holds to a secure off-site
storage facility (not the National Archives), where it
is being triaged in advance of a fresh deposit with
UCL, hopefully in the first half of 2024. Encoura-
gingly, the Chief Executive Officer of CILIP has
stated that the organization has been very careful not
to lose material that effectively bridges the gap
between the original deposit at UCL and the material
that had been held at Ridgmount Street and is now
held in independent storage. The Chief Executive
Officer was keen to point out that 2023 marked the
125th anniversary of CILIP receiving its Royal
Charter, and as part of the planned celebrations, the
opportunity arose to draw extensively on CILIP’s
organizational history as contained in its archive.
CILIP is also investigating, together with a commer-
cial partner, the prospect of digitizing parts of its
collection (Nick Poole, Chief Executive Officer,
CILIP, emails to author, 9 January 2023, 27 February
2023, 14 December 2023). However, it is disappoint-
ing to see that none of these matters appear in
CILIP’s “Five-Year Strategy and Action Plan”
(Chartered Institute of Library and Information
Professionals, 2023).
The Special Collections Department at UCL has
stated that it is ready to receive a fresh deposit of
records from CILIP as and when it becomes available,
and would work with CILIP to determine the most
appropriate form for the documents to be depos-
ited—the choice being, essentially, between physical
and electronic versions. Although the COVID-19 pan-
demic interrupted the Department’s retrospective cat-
aloguing program, a detailed cataloguing of the entire
CILIP Archive is still very much something that is in
the Department’s plans. It is lucky to have a number
of volunteers, but they only work on “catalogue
enhancement” projects. Full cataloguing has to be
done by either paid staff or students on placement
from UCL’s Archives and Records Management
course (to meet the course requirements, work on a
collection must involve organization as well aslisting). The Department does not expect financial
assistance from a deposit ing institution to manage
a collection in its care, but it sometimes works with
donors to secure funding to improve access to collec-
tions through cataloguing or digitization (Rebecca
Sims, Head of Special Collections, UCL, email to
author, 24 February 2023).
Clearly, it would not be expected that over the past
two decades CILIP should have made highly frequent
deposits of records with its archival partner. However,
it would not be too critical an assessment to observe
that a period of 16 years since the last (minor) deposit
and of over 20 years since the initial major deposit
constitutes an unfortunate oversight in the organiza-
tion’s discharging of its archiving responsibilities. For-
tunately, the plans announced for the future
management of the CILIP Archive offer a good exam-
ple of an institution that is determined to “remember.”
Yet it also demonstrates that the potential for corporate
amnesia in terms of an organization’s history is never
far away. Consequently, as a way of promoting
improvements, a large-scale study—better resourced
than that conducted in 2005–2006—is required in order
to assess the archival collections and policies of the
world’s library and information associations, and to
establish, in short, the balance that exists between
memory and amnesia in such organizations, and, by
inference, in the professions they represent.
Conclusion
Given all the talk in recent decades about the
“learning organization” (Marquardt, 2011)—about
how organizations that learn are successful organiza-
tions—it is bewildering that so many organizations,
and not simply the type discussed in this article, do
not seem to appreciate the importance of archive
retention as a component of organizational learning,
except, perhaps, as a tool for heritage marketing and
nostalgic reflection. The fear is, indeed, that the
archival practices of many of the world’s library and
information associations sit at that end of the archival-
retention spectrum where neglect and even mindless
disposal, as opposed to good curation, are deeply
embedded in the corporate culture. The neglect and
disposal of archives would surely qualify as a form of
“cultural vandalism,” but, on reflection, that might
not be a strong enough term to employ in this context.
Perhaps the term “cultural lobotomization” is more
appropriate. Lobotomies, after all, can result in an
impairment of memory and, at worst, its amputation.
Let us hope that the world’s national library and infor-
mation associations have not been involved in703 Black: Memory and amnesia in the archival practices of national library and information associations
conducting too many cultural lobotomies with regard
to their archival responsibilities.

Abstract
This article provides an overview of the recorded history of information associations, focusing especially on the
Association for Information Science and Technology . Discussions with the archivists of three other
professional associations about their beginnings, services, and funding provide the framework. While there
are firm legal guidelines for keeping association records, there are no firm guidelines that specifically describe
how to archive association records for historical purposes. Association records—including correspondence,
votes, and addresses that are not held in formal publications—can reveal how and when decisions were made.
Making these records available in archives is invaluable to historians. The authors’ views and opinions are based
on what they have learned during the last several years of the active engagement of the Association for
Information Science and Technology’s History Committee (HC) and curator, and the hope is that this
article will be useful for other associations as they curate their own archives.

Introduction
Professional associations and learned societies have
existed since antiquity. Italy organized gatherings of
craftsmen or scuole (Pullan, 1981) and the Germans
had the Hanse , the association of trade guilds, from the
middle of the 12th century to the middle of the 17th
century. These guilds represented and defended com-
mon economic interests, especially regarding trade.
During the 1600s, the Enlightenment period saw the
growth of associations dedicated to the sciences. In
Great Britain, for instance, the Royal Society of Lon-
don ( c.1660) and the Philosophical Society of Edin-
burgh ( c.1738) flourished, and, across the Atlantic,
Benjamin Franklin established the Junto Club in
1727. A number of these societies produced proceed-
ings and journals, some of which are still extant (Gib-
son, 1982; Perkin, 1989). Expanding the scope of this
article beyond the western tradition (specifically, Eur-
ope and North America) would reveal rich variations
about the nature of professional alliances, but it is lim-
ited to its historical geographical roots.Over the last few centuries, attempts have been
made in almost every occupation to form professional
associations, with the concomitant establishment of
professional journals (Darity, 2008). Abbot (1988:
3) writes that professions began to grow in the
1900s with the “merging of apothecaries with sur-
geons and physicians, the rise of the lower branch
of the legal profession ...and the growth of university
professionals schools.” Wylie (1994) describes the
characteristics of a profession as including a well-
defined knowledge base; a standardized graduate
degree; a system of testing and certification by the
state; and oversight by a state body to enforce sanc-
tions. Haralambos and Holborn (2002) expand on the
sociological definition of professions to include a
code of ethics and professional norms; dedication to

serving the public interest and being socially respon-
sible; a characterizable knowledge base; a specialized
and standardized education system that includes
postgraduate studies; a technical and research basis;
provision of unique services to the community; devel-
oped professional membership associations; and
autonomy and decision-making among members.
Although it is not explicitly stated, part of the social
responsibility of a profession includes care for its own
history, including making available the archival doc-
uments about its origin, development, and activities to
members of the profession and the community.
Within library and information science, among the
earliest professional associations were the American
Library Association (ALA), founded in 1876, and
England’s Library Association, founded the following
year. Abbot (1988: 217) describes the growth of librar-
ianship as a profession that “arrived in several waves.
The public libraries of the latter nineteenth century
were followed by the academic and special libraries
around the turn of the century.” Librarianship grew
as a result of Melvil Dewey’s push to adopt technical
and scientific management in the late 1800s and early
1900s. At the same time in Europe, the documentation
and bibliography movements, founded by Paul Otlet
and Henri LaFontaine, were gaining traction.
Modern professional and scientific associations
rest on the foundations of t he generally accepted
belief that joint work is a condition sine qua non not
only for the progress of the association but also for
the development of the profession, the scientific
discipline, and science in general.
Managing associations and their history
Associations are usually non-profit, member-driven
organizations that produce many records in the course
of their work, and there are laws governing their
record-keeping. Many have annual conferences, and
organizing these is a time-consuming task. Associa-
tion management companies were created to take on
organizational tasks and provide stability between
transitions in leadership. Association management
companies have their own professional identity and
gatekeeping mechanisms. According to the AMC
Institute, association management companies offer
services such as
membership, marketing and policy developments to legal
and risk management ...staffing, office space, equipment,
contracts, technologies and member services ...strategic
planning ...public affairs and lobbying; education and
professional development; statistical research; meetings
management; and marketing and communications ser-
vices. (AMC Institute, 2023: para. 7–9)The American Society of Association Executives, as
of fall 2023, is developing a certificate in association
management with six courses focused on roles and
tasks, including association management, leadership,
operations management, ethics, and working with
volunteers and boards (American Society of Associ-
ation Executives, 2023). Record-keeping is within the
professional expertise of association management
companies, but historical services fall distinctly out-
side of their list of services.
We are unaware of a description of best practices
that specifically address preserving association his-
tory, and the archivists of associations who we talked
to also said that they were unaware of any such guide-
lines. This leads to a fundamental question: Why does
an association’s history matter? Seeking external vali-
dation, we sought the wisdom of the neural network
ChatGPT, which quickly produced 10 bullet points
that confirmed our thinking:
/C15The preservation of legacy and tradition;
/C15A source of inspiration;
/C15Learning from past mistakes;
/C15Documentation of progress;
/C15Demonstration of credibility;
/C15Member engagement and connection;

This issue of the IFLA Journal traces some of the
histories of the work of associations within the infor-
mation profession, and several of the threads are pres-
ent in this and our own work. We also recognize that
preserving history is a chore, so enshrining its worth
and then making it part of the day-to-day business of
work is essential.
The International Council on Archives (2012) has
produced a “Manual for association management” for
archivist associations. It could very well be applicable
and useful for other types of associations as well; we
hoped that it might offer more pointed advice on
retaining association history due to the historical bent
of the Council’s members. It does outline the pur-
poses of professional associations: education, public
awareness, advocacy, and communication, for
instance. It explains that much of the work of an asso-
ciation is done at annual meetings, which must be
managed; it includes “advice on setting up a records
management program and developing an association
retention schedule” (International Council on
Archives, 2012: 3). The authors write that “[r]ecords
documenting non-committee meetings supporting the707 Bossaller and Aparac-Jelu ˇsic´: Reflections on preserving association records
organization of a conference” (164) should be
retained for two years aft er the conference, then
should be destroyed, but the “final version of
Association conference policies” (165) should be
permanently retained. Training materials should be
permanently retained but records of a course should
be destroyed after two years. Photographs should be
retained indefinitely. Records marked for permanent
retainment should be sent for archival processing
after they are no longer nee ded in-house. This indi-
cates that the association’s management team should
have a firm grasp of what should be retained, and
then regularly schedule items to be transferred from
the office to the archives. Many associations of var-
ious sizes have archives, which enable historians to
piece together stories of the work and members of
the association. The following section provides an
overview of interviews with the archivists of three
associations.
American Library Association
The ALA was established in 1876 in Philadelphia.
After some time, its archives were gathered together
and housed in a warehouse in Chicago. In 1973, they
were transferred to the University of Illinois in antic-
ipation of the association’s 100th anniversary so that
more historical work could be completed by its mem-
bers. At that point, the association entered into a
three-year agreement with the university and hired a
half-time archivist to begin processing the materials.
Today, the ALA Archives house nearly 4000 cubic
feet of materials and over a terabyte of digital materials
that are accessible through over 1500 finding aids. The
ALA headquarters regularly transfers files to the
Archives. However, there is little provision for its
roundtable or satellite organizations. For instance,
REFORMA: The National Association to Promote
Library and Information Services to Latinos and the
Spanish Speaking was established in 1971 as an affili-
ate of the ALA, but its archives are housed at California
State University, Los Angeles. Round table records are
often passed between their chairs rather than being
housed centrally by staff, which illustrates one of the
pitfalls that a dispersed, member-driven organization
might experience regarding its history. Cara Bertram,
an ALA archivist, reported that the association cur-
rently has one full-time and one part-time archivist.
There is a large backlog of files that need to be pro-
cessed, especially for the ALA’s divisions.
In addition to its physical archives, the ALA has an
Institution Repository (ALAIR), which contains over
19,000 items and an image database with over 5300
images. The ALA Web Archive, which captures theentirety of the website annually, is run by the Internet
Archive. The archivists also maintain a dark archive
of born-digital materials that are unsuitable for imme-
diate dissemination. The archives serve ALA staff,
researchers, and members of the public who are inter-
ested in the ALA or librarianship in general.
In 2023, the ALA had 49,705 members and a staff
of 212 (American Library Association, n.d.). Note
that Cara Bertram, the ALA archivist, has also con-
tributed to this issue, so please refer to her article for
more details on the ALA’s archives.
Society of American Archivists
The Society of American Archivists (SAA) was
established in 1936 and its first annual meeting was
held in Washington, DC in 1937 (Doylen, n.d.).
Archival material was originally “preserved by the
officers and chairmen of the committees,” was to be
“turned over by them to the secretary when their terms
expire[d],” and then would be “turned over to a
depository selected for it for permanent preservation”
(SAA Constitution, 1936: Section 21; quoted in Doy-
len, n.d.). Many past presidents and committee chairs,
however, failed to “turn over their files and those who
did were ‘most dilatory in applying [to their own
records] the principles of preservation and arrange-
ment which they propound[ed]’ as professional
archivists” (SAA Constitution, 1936: Section 21;
quoted in Doylen, n.d.). The SAA’s Council first
chose the Colorado State Archives as the official
depository in 1963, then moved the records to the Uni-
versity of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 1978, which it
believed would encourage officers to transfer their
inactive files. This circuitous route to a permanent
home is meant to illustrate the problem that even archi-
vists have with their own professional organization.
Today, Derek Webb serves as one of the SAA’s
archivists. He and one other archivist are employed
by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, and they
receive no financial support from the SAA. Webb
reported that when they receive materials from the
SAA or from individuals, the materials enter their
regular backlogging queue. Students are sometimes
hired for discrete projects, including oral history tran-
scriptions. The SAA also maintains a website that
includes some historical materials, such as a brief
history of the association; a timeline with short
embedded articles; a collection of oral histories that
was created for the association’s 75th anniversary;
and transcripts of all of the presidential addresses.
In 2023, the SAA had over 5000 individual and
institutional members, 11 employees (Society of708 IFLA Journal 50(4)
American Archivists, 2023), and a revenue of
$2,758,657 (Society of American Archivists, 2022).
A study in contrast: the archives of the American
Medical Association
The American Medical Association (AMA) is a very
large and influential profe ssional association with
1300 employees, 271,660 members, and a revenue
of nearly $500 million in 2022. We chose to speak
with two AMA archivists, Jorie Braunold and Kelsey
Walsh, because the association is outside of the infor-
mation fields, we thought that the AMA might offer a
different perspective. The AMA’s archivists, Jorie
Braunold and Kelsey Walsh, agreed to an interview.
The provided us with an overview of the AMA
archives’ history, purposes, and processes.
The AMA first discussed preserving its history in the
late 1800s but did not establish an archive as a division
of its extensive library until 1961. The digital availability
of materials led to the closure of the library in 2000. The
archivists said that the ear ly years followed a general
trend in the development of the archival profession, with
archivists issuing regular ca lls for materials throughout
the 1960s and 1970s to develop the AMA’s historical
collection. In 1994, the arch ives were established as
a distinct division and paired with records manage-
ment, which resulted in pre- and post-1994 collec-
tions. Today, the archives are housed under the
corporate services of the association.
Braunold described the framework for records man-
agement and the transfer of materials to the archives as
being based on the AMA’s statement of scope: it col-
lects all documents related to the official business of the
AMA and employees of the association, but does not
collect outside materials. Its processes, likewise, are
internally focused. The AMA began receiving digital
materials in 2005, and those are filed in the previously
established organizational structure. Today, SharePoint
is used for the transfer of materials to the digital repo-
sitory. Until 2017, the AMA employed three archivists,
but today one is shared with another division. Given the
size of its staff and their role within the organization,
there is not the capacity to make its materials openly
available to the public. While there is not much back-
logged material, the processing is suboptimal, and there
are only a few finding aids an d high-level collection
descriptions. The archivists also opined that, to their
knowledge, most associations do not invest heavily in
their historical archives.
Looking for information: IFLA, a case study
How do researchers use association records? We
email-interviewed Steve Witt, editor-in-chief of theIFLA Journal , who contributed reflections that
illustrate some of the problems he has experienced
when writing about information associations. While
this represents only one person’s experience, it is
instructive in producing some recommendations for
association archives from the researcher’s standpoint.
Witt explained that his research intersects with
IFLA’s early years and the networks of activity that
informed its founding. When he began his research,
he was not aware that IFLA’s archives were open for
researchers, and he relied heavily on archival collec-
tions of the ALA and the Rockefeller and Carnegie
foundations. He continually ran into problems in
accessing records of library associations (outside of
the ALA). He found that some archives, including
those of the UK’s Library Association and IFLA, did
have adequate finding aids. In addition, he pointed out
that the archival practices of some organizations omit
important correspondence from volunteers in the
organization, so those records are spread across vari-
ous institutional archives around the world. Doing
research on an international organization like IFLA
thus becomes both expensive and time-consuming.
Technology, organization, and the increased avail-
ability of finding aids, however, could make this work
easier. Witt pointed out that it is essential to have
finding aids that describe organizations and the con-
tents of their collections. This is especially true if one
seeks to document the history of an organization
beyond listing events, leadership changes, and top-
level activities. Furthermore, he explained that while
many historians love to do nothing more than read
files in archives and gain the deep understanding that
comes from looking at records within their original
context, digitization has many advantages. It greatly
increases access to files, especially if the researcher
already knows what they are looking for. The digiti-
zation of the League of Nations Archives, for exam-
ple, represents a high-quality project that both
increases access and enables browsing of the archives
digitally.
Witt pointed out that associations often have a
forward-looking focus regarding their activities.
However, it is important that they also understand that
their histories are important for understanding their
long-term impact. Maintai ning and developing the
historical record also enables an association’s mem-
bers to understand organizational changes, and to dis-
cern the social and cultural dynamics that shaped its
evolution. For example, Witt remarked that it might
be difficult to research how organizations like the
Association for Information Science and Technology
(ASIS&T) were impacted by Cold War research and
development activities that preferenced information709 Bossaller and Aparac-Jelu ˇsic´: Reflections on preserving association records
technologies with value to the military–industrial
complex. Were there any internal debates on the
subject? Did the organization engage in other
aspects of Cold War activities? In contrast, the
archival model developed by the ALA has allowed
researchers to interrogate its history while also giving
the ALA the ability to promote its values, history,
and accomplishments. Problems researchers encoun-
ter when working on projects like that described by
Witt demonstrate how lapses in the collective archi-
val record impede historical research.
Organization of Association Archives
The ALA, SAA, and AMA archives are three
different models that are the product of the organiza-
tions’ size and financial health, purpose of the
archives, and value that the associations place on their
archival materials and history. The ALA, for instance,
invests in one archivist and a student (although others
might be involved in discrete projects). It has an
office that is accessible to the public and serves any-
one interested in the history of the association. It has a
robust digital collection and an institutional reposi-
tory, and a regular process for transferring materials
from headquarters, and accepts donations from
members. The AMA, on the other hand, is a very large
association but its archives serve the organization as
an arm of records management—they are internally
focused. The SAA is a small association with archives
similar to those of ASIS&T; the collection is housed
within a university’s archives with no dedicated
employee and no receipt of financial support from the
organization. Witt’s description of his travails using
archives demonstrates how archival arrangement and
availability promote or impede historical work.
Association for Information Science
and Technology: challenges and pitfalls
A brief history of ASIS&T
Information science is a broad field. ASIS&T is now
an international organization that is dominated by
academics. Its roots, however, are found in the
American Documentation Institute, which was
founded by Watson Davis, who selected scientific,
industry, and governmental organizations to make
up its membership until the 1950s. Davis’ vision,
which he described in his 1962 address to the
institute, was to miniaturize (microfilm) and index all
scientific publications. He was not the first to envision
open scientific knowledge, however. He was building
on the work of Otlet and La Fontaine, who established
the International Federation for Information andDocumentation in Brussels in 1895. The American
Documentation Institute became a member of the
International Institute for Bibliography after World
War II and, as the technologies of documentation
progressed, the institute grew and changed.
The American Documentation Institute was
renamed the American Society for Information Sci-
ence (ASIS) in 1968, and its membership included a
swath of professionals who were invested in informa-
tion storage and retrieval, including “librarians,
authors, publishers, mathematicians, equipment tech-
nologists, communication theorists, linguists, and
users of messages” (Schultz, 1976: 50). ASIS retained
a relationship with the Special Libraries Association
and the American Chemical Society, and its member-
ship grew, but a merger between the Special Libraries
Association and ASIS failed in the 1970s. As ASIS
approached its 50th anniversary in 1988, its member-
ship was shrinking and it was financially stressed,
even in the face of an explosion of new information
technologies and advances in telecommunications
and document retrieval (Garfield, 2000).
In 1999, Michael Buckland, then ASIS’s immediate
past president, described two traditions that had
evolved within the information professions and were
also causing a rift in education for the information pro-
fessions: the “document” tradition of archives and
librarianship versus the “computational” tradition of
information retrieval. History can reveal this rift to be
a false dichotomy, however, by looking to the early
years of the International Federation for Information
and Documentation. In 2000, members voted to rename
and rebrand ASIS, adding “&T” for “and Technology.”
Internationalization, too, crept in very gradually. ASIS
added a Northern European Chapter in 1974 and a
European Chapter in 1993. The Asia-Pacific Chapter
was established in 2018, the Africa Chapter in 2020,
and the Middle East Chapter in 2021. Internationaliza-
tion brings prestige and financial stability, and
increases opportunities to expand scholarly and profes-
sional connections, but it is also reflective of changes in
scholarly communication, business, and education, and
pressure from governments to expand international
scholarship as a means of increasing prestige.
Why history matters
ASIS&T has evolved from an invitation-only group of
experts in the USA focused on bibliography and docu-
mentation to an international association dominated by
researchers affiliated with universities. The rich legacy
and tradition found in the American Documentation
Institute and International Federation for Information
and Documentation can provide new members with a710 IFLA Journal 50(4)
sense of pride and inspiration; it is not merely academic
navel-gazing. The organization’s history demonstrates

An overview of ASIS&T’s archive and historical
programs
ASIS established a relationship with the University
of Michigan for the deposit of its materials in 1988
(University of Michigan Library, 2023). Today, the
University of Michigan archive holds 185 linear feet
of materials in 188 boxes, and includes print as well as
photographic, audio, and video materials. It includes
materials from all the association’s annual meetings,
publications, membershi pr o s t e r sa n da w a r d s ,a n d
holds many administrative files. The archive contains
documentation from the Chapters and Special Interest
Groups, and many scattered documents related to 239
affiliated organizations and subjects. The collection
was processed and a finding aid was created in
2004–2005. There are no digitized materials; it con-
tains no born-digital files; and there are no plans to
transfer born-digital materials.
There have been several successful projects that
demonstrate how members of the Special Interest
Group on the History and Foundation of Information
Science, the History Committee, the curator, and indi-
viduals have worked to capture ASIS&T’s history.
Perhaps one of the most ambitious projects was begun
in 1996 by Robert Williams, who started to document
the foundations of the profession and ASIS&T in the
“Pioneers of Information Science” project. The proj-
ect includes brief biographies and a list of archival
holdings for US and Canadian scientists and contri-
butors in the field. The project has recently been
transferred to a wiki, which it is hoped will lead to
broader international representation of leaders in the
field, as well as documentation of the historical devel-
opment of some of its major concepts, both of which
will be useful resources and inspiration for members
and non-members alike.Another important collection is that of oral history
interviews with distinguished scholars and practi-
tioners in the field, which were completed by
ASIS&T members. Seventy-four known interviews
are currently scattered across various websites, uni-
versity collections and repositories, the Science His-
tory Institute, and YouTube. ASIS&T holds some that
are not currently available. During the last few years,
an attempt has been made to gather and register the
oral history interviews in a database, and current plans
point toward uploading them to ASIS&T’s YouTube
channel and linking to them from a wiki.
Other recent efforts have included opening access
to nearly all past American Documentation Institute,
ASIS, and ASIS&T publications, including the
Annual Review of Information Science and Technol-
ogy(although some, such as ASIS&T’s journal, are
not open); compiling a bibliography of ASIS&T pub-
lications, which is available on its website; and com-
pleting several retrospective projects and celebrations
at annual meetings.
In 2013, ASIS&T’s 75th Anniversary Task Force
assessed that “resources were widely scattered across
repositories, poorly organized, needed significant pre-
servation work, and perhaps most importantly, were
difficult to identify and access through standard
research and documentation practices” (LaBarre
et. al., 2013: 1).
The task force made significant progress with the
oral history project and sought to improve access to
the archives at the University of Michigan and digi-
tized photographs. It also sought to “encourage the
deposit of records/archives of ASIST leaders”
(LaBarre et. al., 2013: 1).
The 80th anniversary project was completed by
Kathryn LaBarre in 2018. That same year, ASIS&T
created a curator position, which was charged with
monitoring “the discovery, preservation, and accessi-
bility of resources relating to the history of ASIS&T”
(Association for Information Science and Technology,
2023), and recommending policies and best practices
for knowledge management. The mandate for the His-
tory Committee (HC) was to “advance the identifica-
tion, collection, digitization, preservation, and
accessibility of materials and resources relating to the
historical development of the theory and practice of
information science and technology, as well as docu-
menting the Association’s activities and achievements”
(Association for Information Science and Technology,
2023). The committee also held the Bob Williams His-
tory Fund, which promotes work on the history of the
field, and a separate ASIS&T Heritage Fund, which
supports incidental expenses related to preserving the711 Bossaller and Aparac-Jelu ˇsic´: Reflections on preserving association records
association’s heritage resources. The oral history col-
lection has been funded by various sources.
Despite progress, in 2023, the ASIS&T leadership
decided to sunset the HC and discontinue the curator
position. The work of the committee has fallen to the
History and Foundation of Information Science Special
Interest Group, although the latter does not receive
active support from the association’s management team.
The Special Interest Groups are self-driven and thus less
integrated in supporting the mission of the association.
Conclusion
Historical work explains how we have arrived at where
we are today, but it depends on people who will
actively preserve and organize the multitude of papers
and documents that are produced during work pro-
cesses. In a scholarly or professional association, these
mundane documents might include items such as the
membership rosters of various committees, financial
reports, the results of votes, and internal and external
communications. These documents provide evidence
that will one day be useful to tell stories and dispel
myths. The records of annual meetings and monumen-
tal decisions are always saved, but the documents that
demonstrate how those decisions evolved might be bur-
ied in the quotidian material marked for disposal.
If the paper documentation of these mundane
decisions is easily lost, today’s born-digital records
are even more so. What will happen to our hard drives
upon retirement? Digital archiving is an item of dis-
cussion within ASIS&T’s community, yet many of,
yet many of our personal records will never make it to
an archive where they will be available for future
historians. On retirement or death, a university’s
information technology team wipes hard drives; other
records are corrupted or lost. ASIS&T’s management,
likewise, will face similar problems if its records are
not transferred to a trusted repository. Remote work
brings a dire need for documentation and preservation
for our future historical assets.
In early 2024, ASIS&T will permanently close its
physical office. Since the COVID-19 pandemic in
2020, staff have worked remotely, and the office lease
will expire. The executive director issued a call for
proposals for an archival education program to pro-
cess the remaining physical records before they are
transferred to the University of Michigan. This offers
a valuable experiential educational opportunity, but
no program has yet answered the call, which might
be because many library and information science
programs are also online.
The physical holdings are only one piece of the
puzzle, however. For historical purposes, digital filesalso need to be properly captured, processed, and
integrated into a filing structure in a common envi-
ronment. With the dissolution of the HC and the cura-
tor position, the responsibilities of historical
preservation have been relegated to the History and
Foundation of Information Science Special Interest
Group, whose influence is significantly weaker.
Based on the interviews with the archivists from other
associations, we believe that the best step forward
would be to provide financial support to the Univer-
sity of Michigan archives. While hiring a full-time
archivist might not be feasible at this moment in time,
this is a crucial step in increasing access to historical
materials and continuing to develop policies regard-
ing the transfer of materials. This includes accepting
members’ files, digitizing materials of interest, and
creating an institutional repository.
Black (2008) notes that archives are a crucial
component for associatio n management. Historical
records can be used for marketing a profession and
association, and researchers can use records from
associations’ anniversaries and important past profes-
sional events and landmarks to enhance professional
identity. Almost 20 years after Black’s warnings, why
are we still reflecting on how our professional asso-
ciations treat their historical assets? There is still a
need to standardize storage and preservation; system-
atically organize materials; increase accessibility; and
ensure the formulation and implementation of an
archives policy to assure that collections are available
for future use (Black, 2008: 4). To this we add the
need to proactively scrape website and born-digital
materials and then reconcile those with print archives,
in a single repository when possible. This is a com-
plicated environment that requires the investment of
time, thought, and money.

Abstract
The centenary of IFLA is approaching. IFLA’s Library History Special Interest Group has embarked on various
projects to prepare for the event, including the compilation of an edited volume of scholarly chapters on IFLA’s
history. This article originated as a background paper for members of the Library History Special Interest Group
and others who may be contemplating conducting research on IFLA with a view to the centenary in 2027. An
overview is given of published sources for the historiography of IFLA. These include publications about IFLA
published by IFLA and its structures, and by other parties. IFLA’s own publications include guidelines and
standards; policy statements; reports on the work of its professional units and strategic advisory committees;
the IFLA Publications Series; and report series such as the IFLA World Reports and Trend Reports. Much of this
material is published on IFLA’s websites, both current and arc hived. It provides valuable evidence of IFLA’s activities.
In this article, the emphasis is on material about IFLA published by IFLA itself and by other parties. The literature
about IFLA includes historical accounts published as articles, books, book chapters and theses. Many contain useful
bibliographies. With a view to identifying topics and them es for the historiography of IFLA, the subject matter of
some 294 items about IFLA published from 2000 to 2022 inclusive is analysed. Brief attention is paid to possible
themes emerging from the literature that may be useful in developing research on IFLA.

IFLA, historiography, published sources, bibliography, research themes
Introduction
On 30 September 1927, during a conference of the (Brit-
ish) Library Association in Edinburgh, a decision was
made to establish what was in itially called the Interna-
tional Library and Bibliograp hical Committee. Although
IFLA regards 1927 as the year of its foundation, it was
not until 1929 when the constitution proposed by the
Committee and the name International Federation of
Library Associations were a dopted (Wilhite, 2012). In
1976, IFLA changed its name to the International Fed-
eration of Library Associations and Institutions, but
retained the acronym IFLA (pronounced ‘if-lah’), which

This article is intended as a background for scholars
who may be contemplating research on IFLA with a

an analysis of topics and themes in the published liter-
ature during the period 2000–2022; and suggests some
themes that may be worth exploring.Categories of published sources
Various categories of published materials can be
distinguished and are discussed below. The primary
distinction to be made is between publications pro-
duced or published byIFLA and those about IFLA.
This article deals with publications about IFLA
(some of which will have been produced or pub-
lished by IFLA).
