ferences evolved over the years, and Wilhite’s year-
by-year account enables the researcher to follow these
changes, as well as the dates on which major commit-
tees, professional units and initiatives were started.
Wilhite’s (2012) main sources were the proceed-
ings of IFLA ‘sessions’ as published in the Actes du
Comit ´e international des bibliothe `ques, later known
as the Actes du Conseil g ´en´eral/Proceedings of the
General Counci l (1927–1968), and their successor
series. Listing the publications in the series chronolo-
gically with their dates of coverage in his Appendix 2,
Wilhite titles them ‘Core IFLA research sources’. In
the early years, the proceedings were mainly in
French and, as a result, they are generally referred
to as the Actes .T h e Actes were detailed and quite
substantial reports, with accounts of the papers pre-
sented, discussions, committee meetings and IFLA
activities. Technically, whilst mainly printed for dis-
tribution to the IFLA membership and stakeholders,
these are published sources, as they were also offered
for sale to a more general audience. The titles used for
these proceedings reflected the naming of the meet-
ings, being referred to first as ‘sessions’ (1927–1952).
The major part of Wilhite’s (2012) book (Part 2)
offers a ‘Chronology of sessions’ for the period 1927
to 2012. ‘Sessions’ refers to the meetings of what was
initially called the International Library and Bibliogra-
phical Committee – annual meetings of representatives
of the Federation’s member associations (the words
‘and Bibliographical’ were dropped in 1928). Larger
international meetings were to take place every five
years. The first was the First International Congress
of Libraries and Bibliography, held in Italy in 1929,
at which time IFLA’s constitution and name – Interna-
tional Federation of Library Associations – were
adopted. These meetings were difficult to organise. The
second international congress was held in Madrid in
1935. The third, planned for Germany, was abandoned
when the Second World War broke out. After the war,
the scope of the ‘sessions’ gradually expanded to much
larger annual conferences. The term ‘conference’ only
emerged in 1980. What old-timers knew as the ‘IFLA
conference’ became the IFLA World Library and Infor-
mation Congress in 2003.
These developments were reflected in successive
name changes, which are listed by Wilhite (2012:
347). Wilhite devotes several pages to each session,
covering the venue (or venues – on several occasionsthey were held in more than one city) and dates of the
meeting; its theme; the number of participants; the
number of open sessions; the workshops and other
events; the president and secretary general; and reports,
announcements and major decisions. There is also
information about IFLA generally, such as the compo-
sition of IFLA’s governance bodies and administrative
personnel; the number, types and activities of profes-
sional units; membership numbers; and significant
IFLA publications in the relevant year. There are useful
appendices, a bibliography and a detailed name index.
The Actes were succeeded by the IFLA Annual
(1969–1995). In the early years the proceedings were
mainly in French and as a result they are generally
referred to as the Actes. The full series, from 1928 to
1968, is now freely available in the Hathi Trust Digital
Library. Wilhite (2012) also lists a number of other
sources, including the IFLA Repertoire (1931–1968);
theUNESCO Bulletin for Libraries (1947–1978); the
‘IFLA communications’ section, which appeared in the
journal Libri (1953–1974); IFLA News (1962–1974);
theIFLA Directory (1971–2003);1IFLA Journal
(1975–), which replaced IFLA News ;a n dt h e UNESCO
Journal of Information Science, Librarianship, and
Archives Administration (1979–1983), which was the
successor of the UNESCO Bulletin for Libraries .O v e r
time, as IFLA grew and became more complex, the
degree of detail in these sources tended to diminish.
The IFLA annual reports can be accessed by search-
ing on IFLA’s website, although the search function is
not very intuitive.2This link confusingly also brings up
the annual reports of IFLA sections, in no particular
order. This brings us to the next, overlapping, category.
IFLA publications arising from its professional
activities
Over its almost 100 years, IFLA has published a vast
amount of information in addition to the resources
referred to above. These include standards and guide-
lines, manifestos and statements of principles, technical
reports, reports on research projects, reports on confer-
ences and workshops, and major report series such as
the IFLA World Reports and the more recent Trend
Reports.3In recent years, these have increasingly been
published online. To gain an impression of the variety
of materials, one should examine the ‘Type’ options in
the search box on the IFLA’s ‘Resources’ web page.4
These publications are not necessarily about IFLA
itself, but reflect what it does and the significance of
its activities. One should also mention the publications
relating to IFLA’s annual World Library and Informa-
tion Congress, including prospectuses, promotional
newsletters and the congress programme.5715 Lor: Published sources and themes for the historiography of IFLA
IFLA has several publications series. The best
known are the IFLA Journal , IFLA Publications Series,
IFLA Series on Bibliographic Control and IFLA Pro-
fessional Reports. The IFLA Journal has been pub-
lished quarterly since 1975 and a brief history marked
its 40th anniversary (Mansfield, 2014). It is by no
means confined to material about IFLA or arising from
IFLA congresses, but includes news items about IFLA.
It is published in print and online and is available online
on the Sage Journals website (from 1975) and open
access via the IFLA site (from 1993).6
The IFLA Publications Series is a monograph series
(ISSN 0344-6891) or ‘greenbacks’ published by De
Gruyter.7Two or three issues appear every year, with
many of them emanating from workshops and confer-
ences about professional matters. At the time of writing,
the most recent one was Number 183.
A significant proportion of the publications about
IFLA’s activities are produced by IFLA’s professional
units (sections, special interest groups, advisory commit-
tees and divisions). They issue publications about their
activities, such as annual reports, reports on project out-
comes, professional and technical reports and guidelines
for best practice, and newsletters. This also applies to the
former ‘Core Activities’, some of which are now advi-
sory committees.8Each of the professional units has a
page on IFLA’s website. Their publications are listed
there, mostly with clickable links where one can down-
load them. A good example is the web page of the
Cataloguing Section, which over decades has been very
active in various projects and especially in developing
and publishing international standards and guidelines for
cataloguing.9On its site, there is an extensive list of its
publications. The Cataloguing Section also has
a ‘Section Archive’, which lists older publications
and unpublished materials such as annual reports, strate-
gic plans and meeting reports.10The Section’s Metadata
Newsletter can be accessed via its web page as well.11
Special mention should be made of the many man-
ifestos, declarations, statements, position statements,
guidelines and standards of various kinds. They make
important contributions to the dissemination of pro-
fessional best practice and to advocacy for the place
of libraries in the international arena. Although it is
not their primary purpose, these documents constitute
evidence of IFLA’s activities. Often, they are pre-
faced by an introduction describing the processes
through which they were produced.
IFLA’s institutional repository, the IFLA Library,
should not be overlooked. It was launched in 2013 and
is growing steadily, as congress papers and other
resources are added to it continuously. It can be
searched and browsed, and access to the materials is
instantaneous.12IFLA publications about itself
In common with other organisations of its nature, IFLA
has produced many publications introducing and pro-
moting itself, and describ ing its activities. Among
other publications, the annual reports, referred to
above, serve this purpose. On the IFLA website there
is a page about IFLA’s history, giving references and
clickable links to PDF files. This site also includes
publications other than those of IFLA itself.13Individ-
ual professional units have also published brochures
aimed at recruiting members. Many of these have been
ephemeral, but more recently they have been published
on the website and can be found by searching, for
example, for ‘brochures’ using the search function
mentioned above. Indeed, today, the IFLA website is
the single most important source of information about
IFLA, and a search there is indispensable in any his-
torical research. This leads us to the next category.
Bibliographic sources
A serious search should include the use of biblio-
graphic databases such as LISA: Library and Infor-
mation Science Abstracts, now part of the ProQuest
stable. LISA has been seen as offering better interna-
tional coverage. EBSCO’s Library, Information Sci-
ence and Technology Abstracts is a free open-access
database for library and information science. A search
on the term ‘IFLA’ immediately pulls up almost 8000
references in at least seven languages, many of them
about the Library Reference Model, a high-level con-
ceptual model for bibliographic control data that is
currently receiving much attention. A huge number
of items can be found very rapidly, but in no particular
order, using Google Scholar. The lack of order pro-
motes serendipity. One finds useful items, both older
and very recent, for which one is not specifically
looking, with the advantage that an electronic copy
can often be accessed at the same time.
Several published histories of IFLA include useful
bibliographies. The history of IFLA from 1927 to
1940 was the subject of a Master’s dissertation sub-
mitted to Loughborough University of Technology by
Johanna L de Vries (1976). Her bibliography includes
short contemporary articles from British library jour-
nals (mainly the Library Association Record ) and the
Dutch library journal Bibliotheekleven ,a n ds o m e
items in French and German. Some of the older works
cited by De Vries provide contemporary accounts of
meetings of the International Library Committee
(e.g. Theissen, 1928) and of the World Congress of
Libraries and Bibliography (e.g. Leendertz, 1936).
Many of these were intended as reports by conference
delegates to the library associations they had716 IFLA Journal 50(4)
represented. It would be interesting to compare them
with the ‘official’ accounts of these events. Two ‘term
papers’ ( Hausarbeiten ) submitted to the Bibliothekar-
Lehrinstitut des Landes Nordrhein-Westfalen, the
library school of the West German federal state of
Nordrhein-Westfalen, also deal with the history of
IFLA (Haselbach, 1967; Heinzle, 1977).
An important source for the history of IFLA’s first
50 years is the celebratory volume IFLA’s First Fifty
Years: Achievements and Challenges in International
Librarianship (Koops and Wieder, 1977), published
as IFLA Publication No. 10 and reprinted in 2011 as
an e-book by De Gruyter. It includes a substantial
chronological overview of IFLA’s development
(Wieder, 1977), with a long list of references. Wieder
makes heavy use of IFLA’s Actes and its various suc-
cessors, but also cites journal articles in various lan-
guages about IFLA’s development; these were
predominantly published after the Second World
War. A selection of extracts from this chapter, with
photographs of all the IFLA presidents, was published
25 years later, but did not update the 1977 chapter
(Wieder and Campbell, 2002). There is a substantial
well-referenced chapter on the ‘prehistory’ of IFLA,
providing a useful chronology of 11 international
library and bibliographic conferences that preceded
the foundation of IFLA (Rudomino, 1977), and a
detailed account of American (and Canadian) involve-
ment in the birth and early years of IFLA. This includes
an enlightening report on the moral crisis that resulted
from the German invitation to hold the 3rd Interna-
tional Congress in Germany in 1940 (Mohrhardt,
1977). The remaining chapters in this volume are
shorter. Some offer the personal reminisces of key fig-
ures such as Arthur Breycha-Vauthier, Sir Frank Fran-
cis and Herman Liebaers, all of which provide some
insight into the ‘gentlemen’s club’ that ran IFLA in its
earlier years. Others discuss IFLA’s relationship with
the socialist countries of Eastern Europe (Vladimirov,
1977) and developing countries (e.g. Jordan, 1977),
and reflect on IFLA’s future. In the introduction to
Koops and Wieder’s (1977) volume, the editors refer
to a special issue of IFLA Journal entitled ‘IFLA and
contemporary library problems’, also to be compiled
for the 50th anniversary. It was to consist of articles
taking the then newly introduced divisional structure of
IFLA as its point of departure.
A bibliography on IFLA was compiled for the Fed-
eration’s General Council (i.e. conference) in Washing-
ton in 1974, edited by Edward P Cambio at the Library
of Congress. It contains a general introduction to IFLA,
which is followed by a multilingual bibliography of
general items about IFLA, with an emphasis on the
International Conference on Cataloguing Principles(Paris) and other meetings. The section ‘About IFLA’
has a chronological list of sessions (conferences) with
publications emanating from them. It includes publica-
tions relating to the International Office for Universal
Bibliographic Control and I nternational Office for
International Lending, an d works about individual
sections (Cambio, 1974). In 1977, an updated second
edition of The International Federation of Library
Associations and Institutions: A Selected List of Refer-
ences was published by Verlag Dokumentation as IFLA
Publication No. 11 (Cambio, 1977). This formed part of
the 50th-anniversary celebrations. At 52 pages, it is a
greatly expanded version of its 17-page predecessor,
with comprehensive coverage of the international
offices for Universal Bibliographic Control and Univer-
sal Availability of Publications, the International
Association of Metropolitan City Libraries, IFLA’s
21 sections and two working groups.
In an article written in the context of IFLA’s 60th
anniversary, Klaus Plo ¨tz (1987), while acknowled-

International Library Review published an annual
survey under the title ‘The year’s work in interna-
tional librarianship’ (e.g. Aman, 1972). Festschriften,
autobiographical works and general studies on inter-
national library and information work contain mate-
rial ranging from reminiscences to scholarly articles
relevant to IFLA’s history (e.g. Carroll, 1986; Knuth,
1994; Liebaers, 1980; Wormann, 1968). As men-
tioned earlier, a bibliography of publications on
IFLA’s history can be found on IFLA’s website.
Materials are grouped in some broad categories. It is
especially useful in providing references to the more
substantial publications that have appeared when
IFLA sections celebrated special anniversaries (e.g.
McCallum, 2003; Rovelstad, 1977; Van Swigchem,
1977). Substantial bibliographies can also be found in
relevant books and articles. For example, the book by
Alex Byrne (2007) on IFLA and freedom of informa-
tion has an impressive bibliography, which is, of
course, not limited to works about IFLA.
Various encyclopaedia entries have appeared about
IFLA – for example, those in the various editions of
theEncyclopedia of Library and Information Sciences
(Shimmon et al., 2010; Wijnstroom, 1974). IFLA is
the main subject of Rayward’s (1994) entry on inter-
national library associations in the Encyclopedia of
Library History , and IFLA also features in similar
articles in other encyclopaedias (Rayward, 1980,
1986, 1993). It is worth looking at the entries in suc-
cessive editions since they have different authors and
different emphases. For the earlier history, the Hand-
buch der Bibliothekswissenschaft , a ‘handbook’ in the
German encyclopaedic tradition, should be men-
tioned. A second edition of this work appeared after
the Second World War with two articles on interna-
tional librarianship. The second of these (Breycha-
Vauthier, 1961) is especially informative.
Peripheral sources
There is a great deal of material in which IFLA fea-
tures only peripherally. What the researcher finds rel-
evant depends on the topic of interest and how much
material can be found on it. In some cases, a casual
mention of IFLA may provide evidence of IFLA’s
involvement in an event or process, or of the presence
of IFLA in a given country. Any Google search for
IFLA or IFLA personalities turns up an almost unma-
nageable number of additional peripheral material.
Topics or themes in the published
literature
This section offers an analysis of the more recent
literature published about IFLA. It is based on ananalysis of literature collected by Lor while working
on a book about international and comparative librar-
ianship (Lor, 2019). During the approximately 14
years of this project, starting in 2005 and continuing
after the publication of the book, databases and Goo-
gle have been scanned, the contents pages of the most
likely library and information science journals have
been regularly checked, and references in bibliogra-
phies have been followed up. The references are
added to a Zotero database, which currently contains
over 9300 references. Just over 2000 of these were
cited in the book. Since it was initially intended to
include a chapter on IFLA, everything about IFLA
that was found was added to the database. Later, as
the focus of the book shifted and the chapter on IFLA
became a paragraph, items were added more selec-
tively. This changed when IFLA’s centenary was
approaching and the history of IFLA became the
focus of this author’s research. Currently, more com-
prehensive coverage of IFLA is aimed for, and efforts
have been made to fill any lacunae, inter alia by using
the ‘snowball method’. This work is ongoing. For the
earlier years, many items have proved difficult to
access and require further work. For this reason, this
analysis is limited to the period 2000–2022 inclusive.
Even in this later period, coverage is not complete –
new items keep turning up serendipitously and the
coverage of non-English-language material is
inadequate.
When the analysis was carried out, a search using the
term ‘IFLA’ in the author’s Zotero database yielded
1337 hits. However, many of these are not relevant.
They occur simply because these items were published
in the IFLA Journal and other IFLA publications. This
analysis is limited to works about IFLA. Works pub-
lished by IFLA are included only if they are about
IFLA. The Actes du Comit ´e international des bibliothe `-
ques and related series as listed by Wilhite (2012: 347)
in his Appendix 2 have not been included.
Boolean searching is possible in Zotero using a
wide range of fields, but it is somewhat cumbersome
when used for multiple items. Therefore, all the hits
were examined for relevance, leaving 543 items.
Restricting the search to the period 2000–2022 left
294 items. For the purposes of this analysis, it is pro-
posed that this corpus is adequate.

Analysis of topics
The items that are added to the database are allocated
alpha-numeric codes, which were developed in the
early stages of the research for the book – for example:
Q: IFLA
Q1: Origins and development
Q2: Goals and values
Q3: Membership and structure

The classification was extended as the database
grew, but although it was useful in identifying mate-
rial about IFLA, the a-priori classes proved inap-
propriate for the topical analysis. In a preliminary
study reported elsewhere (Lor, 2022), a set of 16 topic
tags was used. The tags were developed inductively –
that is, on the basis of ‘li terary warrant’ and not
deductively using predetermined categories. For the
present study, this set of tags was refined and
extended to 25. All the items were then allocated tags
in a fresh round. This was done for the full data set of
543 items, starting in 1927.
Three levels of topic tags were used. The same set
of topics was used for all three levels, the difference
being in the degree to which the tagged materials dealt
with the topics. Primary tags were allocated to items
that dealt exclusively or mainly with IFLA. Only one
primary tag was allocated per item. No more than one
secondary tag was allocated to items that did not deal
mainly or exclusively with IFLA but in which useful
information about IFLA was presented. Each item
was given either a primary or a secondary tag. In
addition, one or two supplementary tags could be
allocated to cover additional topics in items to whichprimary or secondary tags had been allocated. The

readily; others are more difficult to delimit:

It is interesting to compare these themes with fra-
meworks for the study of organisations – for example,
those of Schein (2011) and Holmes (2019). In the
study referred to earlier (Lor, 2022), a comment by
Schein served as a point of departure for a framework.
He wrote that all organisations ‘have to deal with two
fundamental sets of issues – external adaptation and
internal integration’ (S chein, 2011: 314). On this
basis, we might distinguish two broad areas: (a)
IFLA’s external environment and how it responds to
it and (b) how IFLA conceptualises and organises
itself. An alternative schema can be derived from the
theory of ‘organisational logics’ in ‘hybrid organisa-
tions’, as discussed by Holmes (2019). Professional
associations can be regarded as ‘hybrid organisations’
because they must meet the needs of diverse stake-
holders. This implies diverse ‘institutional logics that
set out the orientation of teams and acceptable beha-
viour patterns’ (Holmes, 2019: 77). The logics can be
summarised as follows:
1. The membership logic is concerned with
responding to the needs of the association’s
members, speaking on their behalf, executing
their will, and dealing with them as a diverse
collective.
2. The professional logic is concerned with stra-
tegies to preserve the association’s control
over a professional field, and the improvement
of the occupational prestige and status of its
members. This includes the ‘learned society
function’ of creating and curating professional
knowledge and establishing standards.
3. The public logic is concerned with the benefit,
information, engagement and protection of the
public, including the clients served by the
association’s members.
4. The organisational logic is concerned with the
running of the organisation, dealing with risk
and managing risk, and managing the demands
of employees and volunteers (adapted from
Holmes, 2019: 78).
This provides an explanatory framework for the list
of themes developed above. Different organisations
will give different weight to the four logics. IFLA is
an international non-governmental organisation that
needs to reconcile the requirements of a very diverse,
geographically distributed membership; seeks to pro-
mote excellent professional practice in the interests of
library users and potential users worldwide; and needs
to survive as a viable organisation. Its international
role adds a level of complexity to the four logics
proposed by Holmes.Conceptual frameworks
By far the majority of the items examined for this
article were straightforward, bland and uncritical nar-
rative accounts. The historical contributions were
mainly descriptions of events and developments in a
roughly chronological order, or narratives rich in
anecdote. In the literat ure published during 2000–
2022, only 15 items were of interest in terms of meth-
odology . The authors of these contributions had
applied various forms of literature, content, rhetorical
and bibliometric analysis; explicit comparative meth-
ods; and formal programme impact assessments.
There were also 12 items of a critical and evaluative
nature, including some dealing with the recent man-
agement problems at IFLA headquarters, critical and
evaluative assessments of IFLA standards and guide-
lines, critical views of IFLA conferences, and cri-
tiques of IFLA’s stance on human rights and social
justice. In only two cases were explicit ideological
stances (Marxist and post-colonial) evident. The
published literature on IF LA is largely devoid of
methodological rigour. Explicit research paradigms
are hardly ever mentioned. Neither is there any
evidence of the use of conceptual frameworks from
other social science disciplines.
Historical research should not be undertaken in a
theoretical void. A suitable theoretical framework adds
value, especially in the case of more ambitious
contributions. A great deal has been written on the
theory of organisations, international organisations,
non-governmental organisations and international
non-governmental organisations in the context of inter-
national relations, development theory, the relationship
between civil society and other political-economic
actors, globalisation, neo-liberal capitalism, gender
studies, and so on. At the very least, we should not
forget the wider context of library and information his-
tory as, for example, in the work of Black (e.g. Black,
1998; Black and Mak, 2019) and Rayward (e.g. 1996,
2014). This varied literature is sure to suggest useful
theoretical frameworks for the historiography of IFLA.
Conclusion
There is no lack of material awaiting IFLA’s histor-
ians. The approaching IFLA centenary presents an
opportune time for historians to delve into IFLA’s
history, on which a scholarly monograph is being
planned. A call for chapter proposals, which at the
time of writing is being developed, will show that
many interesting and challenging themes have already
been identified. It is hoped that this article will help
generate interest and prompt IFLA members to par-
ticipate in the centennial projects of IFLA’s Library721 Lor: Published sources and themes for the historiography of IFLA
History Special Interest Group, and contribute to the
historiography of IFLA.

Preserving the history of the
American Library Association
Cara Bertram
American Library Association Archives, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, USA
Abstract
The American Library Association Archives at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is the official
repository of the American Library Association, the world’s oldest and largest library association. Established
in 1973, the American Library Association Archives holds over a terabyte of digital content and nearly 4000
cubic feet of official records, personal papers, and publications created by or relating to the association, its
members, and the history of librarianship. On the strength of its collection and affiliation with the University
Archives, the American Library Association Archives serves as a major research center on the history of the
association and American librarianship. This article reflects on the history of the American Library Association
Archives, the investment made by the American Library Association to preserve its heritage, and the growth of
the program. It also discusses the current state of the collection and what has made the program successful.
Keywords
Archives, library history, library associations, American Library Association
Introduction
From 4–6 October 1876, 103 librarians gathered at the
Historical Society of Pennsylvania during the USA’s
Centennial Exposition for a Convention of Librarians.
This was the first convention of professional librar-
ians in the USA since 1853, primarily organized by a
then relatively unknown librarian, Melvil Dewey,
and supported and attended by leaders of the field—
Justin Winsor, William F Poole, Reuben Guild, Henry
A Holmes, and Lloyd P Smith. The conference was
viewed as a success and, by the final session, a reso-
lution was passed to establish the American Library
Association (ALA; Thomison, 1978: 5–10). While a
previous attempt at forming an enduring library asso-
ciation in 1853 failed, this time it was successful and
was the start of what has become the oldest and largest
library association in the world.
Preserving ALA’s nearly 150-year history is the job
of the ALA Archives at the University of Illinois at
Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). In 1973, ALA and
the University of Illinois ent ered a three-year agreement
for the University Archives to manage ALA’s records.
Through the establishment of the ALA Archives, ALA
made a commitment to preserve its history and invested
in its heritage. Fifty years later, the partnership between
ALA and the university remains strong.The state of primary sources on library history
appears to be questionable, with the ALA Archives
standing as an example of a robust archival program
focused on librarianship. The collection is as com-
plex as ALA’s membership make-up, touching a
wide range of libraries and librarians from across
the USA, and thereby making it an invaluable
resource for library historians. The ALA Archives’
founding is typical of that of many, culminating
from the pressures of an anniversary celebration and
lack of space to store the collection properly. How-
ever, it is worth examining the history of the estab-
lishment of the ALA Archiv es. Its origins reflect
many of the concerns library historians have about
the stewardship of library primary sources. Never-
theless, its founding and ALA’s continued support
of the archival program has created a unique collec-
tion and situation that can be emulated by peer
organizations.

Literature review
It is difficult to get a good understanding of the
current landscape of the preservation of primary
sources on library association history on an interna-
tional scale or even within the USA. There is not
much in the way of a formal survey or study on avail-
able finding aids, collections, or archival practices
amongst library associations and institutions. How-
ever, several articles, primarily focused on US library
history, paint a less than optimistic picture of the state
of primary sources.
Many library historians despair over the lack of
care taken by librarians in the preservation of their
own history. In the foreword to A History of the Amer-
ican Library Association, 1876–1972 , Edward G Hol-
ley (1978: ix–x) complained that librarians did not
care for their history, and that the author of the book,
Dennis Thomison, had to rely heavily on published
sources in his research be cause there were no avail-
able primary sources available at the time. In the
same vein, Marion Casey, in her essay in the
National Catalog of Sources for the History of
Librarianship ,n o t e s :
Librarians, who ferret out and treasure records from the
past, have actually been quite remiss about saving their
own personal papers and the archives of their own insti-
tutions. Searchers must dig quite deep in some circum-
stances to find anything at all. (Casey, 1982: 6)
In another article, the library historian Wayne
Wiegand (1990: 106–107) praises the bibliographic
control of American library history, however, he
laments that, “[i]n general, the library profession in
the United States has not done a good job of retaining
important records for historical scrutiny.” The archi-
vist Richard Cox (1998: 58) also accuses American
librarians for having “little respect for the records and
artifacts of their own past,” and states that “librarians
have demonstrated a lack of awareness of the reasons
why records need to be maintained.” While these are
not systematic studies of library-history primary
sources, the authors draw on their own experiences
as practiced historians and information professionals.
Their frustrations are notable in their observations of
how librarians have preserved their own history.
John Mark Tucker’s (2000) overview of source
materials on library history is not as bleak. Tucker
(2000: 200–203) praises the advancement of technol-
ogy for locating documents on library history, the rise
in the oral histories of librarians, and the microfilming
of institutional records from the Library of Congress
and Harvard University Library, along with the com-
pilation of directories and online databases of primarysources. These approaches have opened access to pri-
mary sources and documented library history in pro-
mising ways. He also praises the work done by Holley
in his scholarship and transcription utilizing the 1876
ALA scrapbook in Raking the Historic Coals: The
ALA Scrapbook of 1876 (1967). However, he does
bring up concerns that no other librarian has taken
up similar projects or research, and there is a lack of
interest from the community about its history. He
laments about the “ahistorical mindset of our
service-intensive profession,” citing an incident when
a library disposed of photographs of its own events
and publicity prior to 1980 due to them taking up
space (Tucker, 2000: 204–205). As Tucker acknowl-
edges that advancements have been made in discover-
ing and providing access to primary source items, he
also acknowledges what he finds to be a troubling
mindset amongst librarians with regard to their own
history, echoing previous library historians.
A more recent article by Dominique Daniel (2021)
examines digital resources on library history. Daniel
details her experience as a library-history researcher
during the COVID-19 global pandemic, utilizing
remote reference services and digital collections. She
utilized well-known resources such as OCLC’s Archi-
veGrid and the Digital Public Library of America,
along with browsing the Internet. She remarks that
“there are many primary sources on the history of
libraries online, but not as many as one would hope
and it can be challenging to find them” (Daniel, 2021:
231). Daniel (2021: 233–234) observes that source
materials are fragmented, it is difficult to find digital
collections that are focused on library history, and
there is a lack of research guides on the topic.
Most of the literature is anecdotal, drawing on the
experiences of library historians, but there have been
a couple of attempts at a more systematic approach to
analyzing library primary sources. Cox (1991) exam-
ined the citations used in scholarly articles in the
Journal of Library History from 1985–1987, finding
that the manuscripts of library leaders were more
heavily used than library institutional records. He
found similar trends in library-history dissertations
in the same period. His analysis of the National Cat-
alog of Sources for the History of Librarianship
(1982) notes that public libraries represent the second
most numerous sources, trailing far behind personal
papers, but that they only represent a small fraction of
actual institutions within the USA (Cox, 1991: 581).
He concludes that “librar y archives are generally
underdeveloped and a rarity on the national scene,”
and that, compared to other kinds of libraries, there is
a higher chance for academic libraries to have725 Bertram: Preserving the history of the American Library Association
archival records due to there being a university
archivist on staff (Cox, 1991: 584).
In 2005, Alistair Black (2008) sent out a survey to
all national library associations that were a part of
IFLA, along with the Special Libraries Association
in the USA, to collect information on their archives.
The survey received 10 responses, with six associa-
tions indicating that they kept their archives in house
and four that they deposited their archives with out-
side institutions. Of the respondents, seven indicated
that there were finding aids for their collections,
although one was only in draft form, and another did
not make their collections publicly available (Black,
2008: 3). While Black’s report does not give the spe-
cific number of surveys distributed, and he notes that
the survey was only in English, he expresses disap-
pointment that the number of responses was lower
than he expected. He argues that “this reflects the low
priority given by associations to their archives and, it
follows, to their heritage” (Black, 2008: 4).
It is difficult to get a grasp on the current state of
preservation of the history of librarianship and library
associations. Much of the literature and many of the
studies on the state of primary source materials go
back 20 to 30 years. The landscape of library associ-
ation history may not be as bleak as the literature
suggests, at least not within the USA. Discovery tools
like ArchiveGrid can cast a wide net and locate the
archives of library associations, although Archive-
Grid primarily focuses on institutions within the
USA and repositories must opt in to have their finding
aids indexed.
Regardless, the anecdotes of library historians are
not optimistic and, even if these observations are not
accurate with regard to the number of primary sources
available for research, the perception that librarians
do not care for their history is damaging. This percep-
tion can become a barrier to access, discouraging
researchers from seeking out materials or leading
them to approach their research with less optimism
for what is out there. It may also be an indication that,
whatever association and institutional archives are
being maintained, they are not highly visible online
or through published guides.
An exception to the woes of library historians is the
ALA Archives. In many of the cited articles, the ALA
Archives is an exception to the rule, with a large
library-focused collection, strong presence, and
education-driven mission.
Establishing the ALA Archives
While the ALA Archives was established at the
University of Illinois in 1973, the origins of the ALAheadquarters as a repository can be traced back to
1910 with the acceptance of the papers of Seth Hast-
ings Grant (Winger and Miksa, 1971: 3–4). However,
serious discussion regarding the management and pre-
servation of ALA’s records started in the 1940s. A
final report issued by the Committee on American
Library Association Archival and Library Materials
(1949: 1) established that “ALA as a part of its
responsibility to its membership should house the
archives of the Association and of its Divisions,
Boards, Round tables, and ALA Committees.” The
report named the headquarters library as the deposi-
tory for the records, with responsibility for the selec-
tion and arrangement of archival materials belonging
to the individual ALA units. Analysis of the recom-
mendations was positive and, at least intellectually,
ALA was heading in the right direction for preserving
its history. Despite this strong foundation of guide-
lines, one consultant observed that “no positive action
has ever been taken to implement them” (Munden,
1968: 1).
In 1953, two problems were identified regarding
the management of ALA’s historical records. The first
was the housing of the archives and the second was
the organization of the records. In discussions, it was
noted that the instructions for organizing the records
in the 1949 report were unclear to staff, and that there
was a need for a trained archivist to work with the
ALA divisions. The issue of space was also discussed,
with several different locations within the headquar-
ters suggested for housing the archives (Geer, 1953:
2–3). Whatever action was taken following the meet-
ing is not recorded, but a few years later, in 1956, the
headquarters librarian Helen Geer wrote to the exec-
utive director David Clift in despair about the state of
the archives: “they are stored in a room which is very
damp during the summer months and very hot in the
winter months. I know that the paper will deteriorate
under these conditions.”1
Ten years after Geer’s lament, her successor, Ruth
White, wrote to the ALA associate executive director
Alphonse Trezza about the continued disorderliness
of the historical materials. White recommended that
an archivist and a secretary be hired to collect and
organize the archives. She also commented on how
the archives were dispersed in different parts of the
building and in a nearby warehouse.2While Trezza’s
response to White’s letter was not saved, in the fol-
lowing year, ALA started looking for a professional
archivist to undertake a survey of the archives.
In 1968, Kenneth Munden, an archivist at the
National Archives, produced a report on the archives
and recommendations on how to proceed. Amongst
his recommendations was the need for the ALA726 IFLA Journal 50(4)
Archives to become a separate department within the
organization or, if it was tied in with the library, to be
renamed “Library and Archives,” so that the archives
would not become an afterthought (Munden, 1968: 8).
However, progress in establishing the ALA Archives
was slow, even with ALA’s centennial anniversary
quickly approaching in 1976. The report of the Spe-
cial Committee on American Library Association
Centennial Anniversary (1969: 1) to the Executive
Board expressed disappointment that no archivist
had been hired, and concern that there could be no
publication celebrating ALA’s history for its centen-
nial. Space at headquarters and financial limitations
continued to hinder efforts for the realization of
organized association archives.
A second report on the archives was produced in
late 1969 by Philip Mooney, a curator from the
George Arents Research Library at Syracuse Univer-
sity. It did not break new ground following Munden’s
earlier report, with one exception—Mooney said that
Syracuse could acquire ALA’s archives. It was an
attractive proposal, as ALA had concluded that
managing its own archives would not be feasible
(Warncke, 1970: 1). But the potential arrangement
with Syracuse did not satisfy ALA’s needs. The loca-
tion was deemed too far from its headquarters in
Chicago. Other concerns included transferring own-
ership of the records to Syracuse and if adequate
access to the records could be provided (Warncke,
1970: 1–2).
ALA hoped instead to find a repository closer by.
The suggestions included the Newberry Library in
Chicago; the University of Illinois, which had cam-
puses in Chicago and Urbana-Champaign; and the
Library of Congress, which was in the vicinity of
ALA’s Washington office (Warncke, 1970: 1). The
library historian Edward Holley wrote about the mer-
its of the Urbana-Champaign campus of the Univer-
sity of Illinois:
The idea of transferring the archives to the University of
Illinois strikes me as a good one, but I think the Urbana
campus would be preferrable to Chicago, the main rea-
son being that Urbana has so many other materials that
would be important to a researcher working on the
archives ...I refer to annual reports of libraries, library
periodicals, and even such materials as the University
Archives. A number of Illinois staff members have been
heavily involved with ALA and most of their papers are
well organized.3
In 1971, Robert Talmadge, a member of the ALA
Executive Board and a librarian at UIUC, connected
with University of Illinois archivist Maynard Brich-
ford regarding the possible acquisition of the ALAarchives.4Later that year, Brichford carried out
another survey of the archives and proposed transfer-
ring the archives to UIUC. Like Holley, Brichford
emphasized the strong archival program he had estab-
lished; library and archival holdings in the areas of
librarianship and library history; the university’s pro-
minent library school; and the participation of its staff
and faculty in ALA.5ALA and Brichford entered dis-
cussions over access policies and shaping an agree-
ment that satisfied both parties. ALA and the
University of Illinois ent ered a three-year contract
to house the records at the Urbana-Champaign cam-
pus. On 31 October 1973, ALA announced the trans-
fer of its archives from its Chicago headquarters to
Urbana-Champaign.
The establishment of organized archives was a long
process, and the lack of progress was summed up well
in the minutes of the 1970 spring meeting of the ALA
Executive Board:
Funds were denied previously for staff to arrange the
archives. There was little disposition then to consider
the arrangement of the archives as an essential need,
possibly because there might be funds—and there would
be time—in another year. (American Library Associa-
tion Executive Board, 1970: 86)
The lack of prioritization of the archives echoes the
worries that many library historians have expressed—
that library associations and institutions do not care
for their history. There was an awareness of the need
to preserve ALA’s history, but the issue stagnated
until the internal and external pressures of its centen-
nial finally pushed ALA into action. Still, it took years
to find an archival repository that satisfied its needs.
Following Brichford’s initial proposal in 1971, it
would be another two years before ALA began trans-
ferring its records to UIUC.
However, the slow approach to selecting a final
repository was not necessarily a bad thing. An orga-
nization needs to know that its records will be well
taken care of; that the hosting repository can fulfill its
needs; and that the conditions satisfy both parties,
whether it be having the archives on deposit or
through a donation. Willam Maher (1994: 9) notes
that while the lead time to the final agreement
between UIUC and ALA seemed like a long time,
in hindsight, it produced a sound contract with clear
relationships and responsibilities.
Programmatic growth
Since the original deposit agreement in 1973, ALA
has continued to renew the contract for the last
50 years. While the contract has changed during that727 Bertram: Preserving the history of the American Library Association
time frame, the core elements of the original
agreement are still in effe ct today and, from this
foundation, the archival program has seen significant
growth.
Rather than donating the archives to UIUC as a
gift, ALA has retained ownership of its materials. In
most deed-of-gift agreements, ownership of copyright
is transferred to the receiving institution. However, a
deposit agreement allows ALA to retain its intellec-
tual property while the repository maintains and pro-
vides access to the collection. Ownership has meant
that ALA has stayed strongly involved with its
archives. ALA units utiliz e the collection and the
expertise of archives staff as a resource; there is
collaboration between the ALA Archives and head-
quarters for events, celebrations, and the acquisition
of archival materials; and the ALA Library headquar-
ters staff and archives st aff maintain consistent
communication.
ALA provides annual financial support for the
archives, the majority of which goes to personnel.
At the time of the initial agreement, ALA could not
afford to hire a full-time archivist. However, the Grad-
uate School of Library Science (now the iSchool) pro-
vided an ample source of graduate students seeking
hands-on experience in archives under the supervision
of the university archivist or assistant university archi-
vist. In 2004, ALA provided funding for a half-time
academic professional to serve as the archivist with
graduate assistant support. In 2020, funding increased
to maintain a full-time professional archivist with grad-
uate assistant support. With a professional position,
there is now continuity and strong collection knowl-
edge, which is often lacking when relying primarily
on graduate assistants as they are typically enrolled
for only two years. Additional costs are related to
supplemental digital programs, supplies, and travel
for personnel.
While ALA was prepared to pay for storage at the
university, complications with the campus legal coun-
sel prevented payment for the space. This meant that
the University Archives had to accommodate the
ALA records in its then current allocation of storage,
thus making the argument for the research value of the
ALA Archives at UIUC, and its compliment to exist-
ing collections, even more essential (Maher, 1994: 9).
Despite the lack of funding for the physical space, the
University Archives has worked to improve the stor-
age, access, and preservation of the collection, as is
done with their other materials. Initial storage of the
archives was in the basement of a campus building
with reference services operating out of the University
Archives. Then, in 2007, the collection and services
were moved into office spaces and climate-controlledstacks at the Archives Research Center, which is an
additional service point and storage location for the
University Archives. The heating, ventilation, and air
conditioning, fire suppression system, and insulation of
the stacks were updated in 2016. Currently, the ALA
Archives is slated to move into the renovated Archives
and Special Collections building at the center of cam-
pus. This project is estimated to be completed in 2026.
The deposit agreement also had another, possibly
unintended, effect—of creating a distinct program
separate from the University Archives collection.
While still under the supervision of the University
Archives, the program has forged its own identity.
The extent of ALA’s records was large enough that
Brichford developed a classification system separate
from that of the University Archives. The original
paper finding aids and microfilmed guides are now
in an individual searchable database, branded specif-
ically for the ALA Archives. The archives also main-
tains its own website and social media presence,
displays exhibits, hosts events and tours, and has a
dedicated professional archivist and its own patron
base. The growth of the program has provided better
preservation of the materials, subject expertise from
staff, and higher visibility, and thus access, to the
collection.
Collection and digital resources
In accordance with the collection’s policy, the ALA
Archives collects, preserves, and provides access to
inactive records of enduring value from ALA units
(defined as offices, divisions, round tables, commit-
tees, etc.); members’ papers as they relate to ALA
activities and librarianship; and manuscripts and
records on the history of libraries and librarians
(American Library Association Archives, 2022). The
collection spans from a scrapbook on ALA’s short-
lived predecessor, the 1853 Librarians Convention, to
digital-born documents produced by ALA members
today. The core of the collection was transferred from
ALA headquarters, primarily consisting of files from
ALA’s offices, divisions, and governance. These files
document the history of ALA’s administrative func-
tions and policies, events and conferences, advocacy,
literacy and library campaigns, awards and scholar-
ship programs, and public service. There is also a
growing collection of papers from ALA presidents,
staff, leadership, and members, collected through pri-
vate donations.
Alongside the physical materials, the ALA
Archives maintains a robust and multifaceted digital
archives program, most of which is open access or
available on request. This includes:728 IFLA Journal 50(4)
/C15The University of Illinois Digital Library,
which displays digitized physical records and
born-digital collections.
/C15The ALA Institutional Repository, an online
repository that preserves and provides access
to the intellectual work of ALA, including pub-
lications, minutes and agendas, oral histories,
reports, White Papers, speeches, and presenta-
tions. As of 2023, it held over 19,300 open-
access items.
/C15An image database of over 5400 digitized items
scanned from the physical archival collection
and comprising primarily photographs, along
with postcards, posters, and illustrations.
/C15The ALA Web Archive, a collection in Archive-It
of the annual captures of ALA’s websites going
back to 2013.
/C15The University of Illinois Library’s Medusa
digital preservation repository, an offline stor-
age system for the preservation of digital mate-
rials which provides storage space for digitized
and born-digital items that are unsuitable for
immediate open access.
The ALA Archives also holds materials on related
library associations and organizations, either created
and collected by ALA or deposited at the archives by
said associations. This includes records on IFLA, the
Art Libraries Society of North America, Association
for Library and Information Science Education, and
National Associations of Librarians of Color. These
complimentary records strengthen the core collec-
tion by expanding into specialized areas of librar-
ianship and emphasizing the work of organizations
for under-represented librarians. Moreover, these
records demonstrate the interconnectedness of ALA
on the national and international stage, document-
ing past and ongoing relationships. Many library
organizations can also trace their origins to ALA
or its members.
The IFLA records within the collection are a good
example of ALA’s interconnectedness. Within the
papers of the ALA International Relations Office, a
researcher can trace the beginnings of IFLA in files on
international library cooperation from the mid to late
1920s. There are meeting minutes and reports that
cover the preparation and discussions within ALA for
the 1927 conference in Edinburgh, Scotland, where
IFLA was founded, and ALA’s early participation.
The ALA International Relations Office and Interna-
tional Relations Committee’s files document ALA’s
continued participation, containing materials on con-
ferences as early as 1929, and maintain a collection of
IFLA publications. But more can be found throughoutthe ALA Archives. Participation in IFLA by ALA
presidents, executive directors, and members is well
documented within its papers, including past IFLA
president Robert Wedgeworth. Photographs of IFLA
conferences and events can be found in the files of
the magazine, American Libraries , from 1977 to
2004. There are also over six cubic feet of files
from IFLA’s Cataloguing Section. These records
show the strong participation of ALA and its mem-
bers in IFLA, and strengthen the archives’ histori-
cal holdings on international librarianship.
A weakness of the collection is the early years of
ALA, particularly from 1876 through 1910. Before
ALA had long-term headquarters, it was said that the
association was in Dewey’s desk drawer or wherever
the ALA secretary hung up their hat. The reality is
that the association originally operated out of
Dewey’s offices in Boston, then a few short-term
locations until it moved to Chicago in 1909
(Massman, 1969: 475). Without a consistent location
to accumulate and store records, they likely ended up
with individuals or were lost (Winger and Miksa,
1971: 3–4). Even when ALA had permanent head-
quarters, disorganizati on and environmental condi-
tions meant that some early records were lost or
thrown away. While archiv al sources from this time
are sparse, the published conference proceedings,
programs, reports, and photographs held by the ALA
Archives help to bridge this gap.
Another gap in the collection is documentation of
ALA round tables. These units are driven by member-
ship and reflect the values, concerns, and activism of
the profession. However, the materials produced by
the round tables often remain with ALA members and
are not transferred as regularly as records accumu-
lated at headquarters. Because of this, the archival
record on round tables sometimes does not reflect the
depth of their history.
Despite the gaps in the archival record, the ALA
Archives continues to be a destination for researchers
who are interested in library history. The collection
touches a wide range of topics in American librarian-
ship and has expanded in the last 50 years. At the time
of the publication of the first Guide to the American
Library Association Archives in 1979, the ALA
Archives consisted of 678 cubic feet of processed
archival materials and intellectual control over 437
record series (Brichford, 1979: 3). In 2023, the col-
lection had expanded to over 1500 searchable find-
ing aids, most with box- and folder-level inventories,
and 3900 cubic feet of physical materials, as well as
over a terabyte of digital content. The quality of the
stewardship of the collection and its growth, includ-
ing processing new materials and writing finding729 Bertram: Preserving the history of the American Library Association
aids, can only be maintained through the continued
support of ALA.
Considerations
The care of the archives of an active library associa-
tion is an ongoing investment, not a one-off project.
While the thought of archives often congers up
images of dusty old files and boxes from the past,
archives are also about the future. Active organiza-
tions will continue to produce documentation,
whether it be physical or digital records, and those
must be taken into consideration through records
management and retention schedules.
ALA’s archives started out as many archives do—
disorganized and put off to deal with another year.
When ALA finally prioritized its historical records,
it created a sustainable archival program in partner-
ship with UIUC. What has made the ALA Archives a
successful venture is a combination of factors.
First is the partnership between ALA and UIUC.
Strong cooperation, communication, and education-
driven missions have created a fruitful collaboration
that has endured for over 50 years. Beyond negotiat-
ing a satisfactory deposit agreement, the university
library and University Archives also had collections
that built on the thematic strengths of the ALA’s
records, which has made the ALA Archives an attrac-
tive place for library historians and scholars. This also
helped the University Archives in building a justifi-
cation for taking in ALA’s archives. Finding an insti-
tution that works well with a library association or
organization in communica tion style, mission, and
collection strengths can create a partnership that ben-
efits both parties.
Second is the financial investment of ALA in the
continued support of the archives. As an active library
association, its records have continued to grow, and
they must be continuously managed, making ALA’s
support essential to the ALA Archives’ success as a
program. Even with the proliferation of digital
records that do not take up physical space, these too
must be organized, preserved, and made available as
appropriate. The preservation of digital records is
also not immune to costs, as their storage can be
expensive. While most organizations cannot fund
an archival program at the level of ALA, even small
financial contributions can help to secure the time
and labor of an archivist or graduate student for ini-
tial arrangement and description. This also acknowl-
edges the effort and resources that go into caring for
a collection.
Third is the visibility of, and access to, the collec-
tion. The ALA Archives maintains its own website,distinguishing itself as a distinct archival program
with a database of finding aids, research guides, blog
posts, and other information about the archives. While
links to the archives are buried in the ALA and uni-
versity library sites, it is relatively easy to find the
website. It also maintains responsive reference ser-
vices and provides both on-site and remote services.
At minimum, an organization should have a web page
that provides information about its archives, where it
is located, how it can be accessed, and links to any
finding aids or inventories.
And finally, fourth is the continued depositing of
physical records and focus on digital records.
Archives staff work closely with ALA units to pro-
vide guidance on the retention of materials. This has
resulted in the growth of the collection and continued
documentation of ALA’s history. ALA has also
worked on preserving its digital records, developing
a digital repository with the archives, investing in a
web archive, and working with the archives on other
strategies for digital collections. As stated above,
organizations need to look to the future as they con-
tinue to produce records, both physical and digital,
and work in cooperation with archivists on preserva-
tion strategies.
Conclusion
Library associations, organizations, and institutions
must be leaders in the preservation of their own his-
tories, not just for use in celebrations and publicity,
but also as a tool of transparency. Librarians and
archivists advocate for open and free access to infor-
mation for the public and, with this ideal, they must
practice it within their own organizations. For the
growth, development, and morale of library organiza-
tions, they must be active in preserving their histories
and make them available for celebration, analysis,
and criticism.

The attempt to create a post-World
War II international information
order
W Boyd Rayward
School of Information Sciences, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, USA
Abstract
This article focuses on the UNESCO-sponsored 1971 Intergovernmental Conference for the Establishment of
a World Science Information System (UNISIST) and the 1974 Intergovernmental Conference on the Planning
of National Documentation, Library and Archive Infrastructures (NATIS) and the events, often themselves
international and intergovernmental conferences, leading to them in association with IFLA (especially its
Universal Bibliographic Control program), the International Federation for Documentation and
International Council of Scientific Unions, and its Abstracting Board. It notes the disappearance of these
programs and their approach to a coherent, cooperative global information system. It argues that this was a
result of geopolitical developments, organizational changes within UNESCO and its related organizations, and
the rapid evolution of huge competitive commercial enterprises. These have been responsible for both
developing and exploiting the transformative digita l technologies that are now associated with owning
increasingly complex information systems and services, and selling access to them in what has become a
global, borderless marketplace for information as a commodity.
Keywords
UNISIST, NATIS, IFLA, FID, information commodification
Introduction
As World War II drew to a close, there was an increas-
ing awareness, in contradistinction to the period at the
end of World War I, of the need not only to mobilize
information as a key component of post-war planning to
support the new world order that was emerging from the
chaotic conditions of the war, but also to manage an
enormous range of international tensions and conflicts
that were emerging at the time. This article focuses on
two separate but related trends of development that cul-
minated in two major conferences: the Intergovernmen-
tal Conference for the Establishment of a World Science
Information System (UNISIST) in Paris in 1971 and the
Intergovernmental Conference on the Planning of
National Documentation, Library and Archive Infra-
structures (NATIS) in Paris in 1974. The events, often
themselves international conferences, that led to these
summative meetings were centered on the newly cre-
ated UNESCO working during a period of several
decades with three major international associations con-
cerned with information: IFLA, the InternationalFederation for Documentation (FID) and the Interna-
tional Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU). It was as
if something like a world information order, based on
the coordinated work of international associations, was
at last to be achieved (Otlet 1907, 1909). But even as
these important international meetings took place and
had some impact, they were overtaken by a constantly
accelerating impetus for change in the information orga-
nizations, systems, and services of which, for a time,
they were a part. For a timeline of the conferences and
organisations mentioned in this text (see Figure 1).

documentation activities

both sides in times of war have depended in part on

to gather, process, evaluate, and deploy—as well as
restrict access to—information. These systems are
needed, for example, for the research related to weap-
ons development and manufacture, and the technical
and social infrastructure necessary to support this
research (inventions, materials, processes, machines,
factories, workforces); for gauging enemy capabilities
and movements; for assessing and attempting to influ-
ence the social conditions of the belligerent nations
and the countries they occupy; and for managing pub-
lic opinion and the physical, social, and cultural wel-
fare of the civilian populations involved. Information
that is operationally critical is usually referred to as
“intelligence.” At a more general level are issues of
dissemination of information, including “intelligence,”
to allies within the constraints of perceptions of
national security and the interests of political alliances.
One of the important aftermaths of war has been what
to do with this information and the systems and ser-
vices that emerged to manage it.
As World War II drew to a close, there was an
increasing awareness, in contradistinction to the
period at the end of World War I, of the need to
mobilize information as a key component of post-
war planning in order to shape the new sociopolitical
conditions that were emerging from the chaotic con-
ditions of the war. How was the enormous range of
international tensions and conflicts that characterized
the apparent return of peace to be managed—the des-
cent of the Iron Curtain that divided Europe into a
communist East and a democratic West and repre-
sented the beginning of the Cold War, the outbreak
of widespread anti-colonial independence revolu-
tions, the Korean War, the nuclear arms race, and so
on. Against this background, the “information” dis-
cussions and the activities they entailed were ani-

currency, that what was needed was the creation of

For the Allies during World War II, the information
“problem” was of two kinds. The first, an “internal”
matter, was related to the research and other informa-
tion that they themselves generated and needed
to manage; the second, an “external” matter, was
the need to capture as much Axis research and
intelligence-related information as possible. In the
first case, close cooperative research and develop-
ment arrangements were quickly developed between
the Allies. These involved setting up liaison offices in
London and Washington, for example; arranging the
frequent visits of scientists, engineers, and high-level
military and civilian personnel between the two coun-
tries, despite the dangers this inevitably involved; andthe creation of regular, detailed reporting services
about the information that was being generated and
collected. The extent of the exchanges of information
was remarkable. Farkas-Conn (1990: 103) quotes
some of the figures: through September 1945, nearly
60,000 separate reports, letters, and samples were sent
to the USA from the UK and Canada, while the flow in
the other direction was over 82,000 such documents.
With regard to the second “external” matter, the
war erected almost impenetrable barriers to the nor-
mal pre-war flow of information between the general
publishing and scientific and scholarly research com-
munities of Japan, the European Axis countries, and
the Allies. As a result, the Allies put in place programs
to try to capture as much of this enemy information
as possible (Moholy, 1946; Muddiman, 2005; Peiss,
2007, 2020; Richards, 1981, 1989, 1994). One
aspect of this was the ever-fascinating examples of
intelligence-gathering by individual spies and espio-
nage networks, and the dramas of code-breaking,
about which so much has been written and shown
on cinema and television screens. But to this must
be added the need to acquire the more formal research
and other materials that were the Axis equivalent of
what the Allies were themselves producing to further
their war efforts. Peiss (2020) meticulously relates the
extraordinary story of the programs, personalities, and
bewilderingly complicated organizational arrange-
ments that resulted from these initiatives. Important
in this respect were the various branches of the US
Office of Strategic Services, such as its Interdepart-
mental Committee for the Acquisition of Foreign
Publications (IDC). It had posted agents, librarians,
and others to most of the major neutral cities, such as
Lisbon, Stockholm, and Cairo. They sought out news-
papers, periodicals, and whatever other documents
they could find that could provide information that
would be useful for the war effort.
In the eight-month period from November 1942 to June
1943, the IDC microfilmed nearly 28,000 published
items and collected over 23,000 original publications;
in the same period it distributed nearly three-quarters of
a million items to a variety of war agencies.
This material was often microfilmed “on the spot and
sent to Washington for processing and distribution”
(Peiss, 2007: 378).
As the war was coming to its close, a sense of
urgency arose in the need to capture enemy informa-
tion that might still be found in Germany and else-
where (e.g. see Farkas-Conn, 1990; Peiss, 2020;
Richards, 1981, 1989, 1994). To give an immediate
impression of the sense of how powerful the impetus733 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
for this had become, it is enough to cite the relevant
titles of the chapters in the books by Farkas-Conn and
Peiss on this period: “The war years, then information
turmoil” (Farkas-Conn, 1990: 99–122); “The wild
scramble for documents” and “Acquisitions on a
grand scale” (Peiss, 2020: 68–121). It was understood
that German scientists had been instructed to destroy
the records of their work. A Combined Intelligences
Subcommittee was given the task of combing Ger-
many in search of these documents—a task that was

another 50 tons, and 600,000 documents had
been screened at Wrights A irfield by 1947 (Valjes,

And the situation with respect to libraries and
books was just as difficult. As World War II gathered
pace before Pearl Harbor, the US library community
witnessed the potential drying up of important
European library resources with alarm. “A micropho-
tographic expeditionary force” was even proposed to
copy materials still available in Europe. While this did
not eventuate, Peiss (2020: 30) notes that the fear of
losing important Allied manuscripts and books to
bombing during the course of the war led to coopera-
tive copying with various British organizations: “by
January 1941, six camera operators were rapidly
copying books and manuscripts in a bomb-proof loca-
tion, and by 1944 they had shot five million frames of
microfilm.”
In 1945, following the acquisition role the Library
of Congress had played in the wartime IDC, it estab-
lished a Post War Mission to Europe not only to find
material related to the German Army and the Nazi
Party, but also to buy up stocks of more current mate-
rials that had been held by German book dealers
against the anticipated post-war needs of American
libraries to fill the gaps that the war inevitably created
in their collections (Downs, 1949: 157-165; Peiss,
2020: 93–121). In addition to these materials, the
Library of Congress made available for distribution
in the USA large quantities of duplicate foreign pub-
lications received from various US military bodies,
which brought in Italian, French, Swiss, Dutch,
Belgian, German, and Austrian titles (Downs, 1949:159). Reuben Peiss, who had played a heroic role in
the acquisition of foreign materials during the war
(Peiss, 2020), writing in 1947, suggested that the
Library of Congress Mission had been responsible for
collecting and sending to the USA more than a million
volumes (Peiss, 1947: 116); two million items is the
estimate reported by Kathy Peiss (2020: 118).
As World War II seemed to be drawing to a close,
plans were being established for what to do with all of
this information after the war. In 1944, President
Roosevelt raised with Vannevar Bush the issue
of how
[t]he information, the tec hniques, and the research
experience developed by t he Office of Scientific
Research and Development and by the thousands of
scientists in the universities and in private industry,
should be used in the days of peace ahead for the
improvement of the national health, the creation of new
enterprises bringing new jobs, and the betterment of the
national standard of living. (Bush, 1945: 3)
In his landmark report to the president, Science—the
endless frontier , Bush (1945), who was head of the
US Office of Scientific Research and Development,
which was slated for closure at the end of the war,
argued that the captured German research material
would be of use to American industry, and that the
vast amounts of research materials created by his own
office and all the other branches of government,
national security issues having been satisfied, should
be rapidly declassified after the war:
Most of the information needed by industry and in
education can be released without disclosing its
embodiments in actual military material and devices.
Basically there is no reason to believe that scientists of
other countries will not in time rediscover everything we
now know which is held in secrecy. A broad dissemina-
tion of scientific information upon which further
advances can readily be made furnishes a sounder foun-
dation for our national security than a policy of restric-
tion. (Bush, 1945: 28–29)
While the ultimate impact of Bush’s report has since
been questioned (e.g. Geiger, 1997), the result of the
policy adumbrated by President Roosevelt was an
influx of large quantities of documents from the
Office of Strategic Services (OSS) and other agencies
that had been accumulating such materials, having
recognized that they were ready for declassification
(Farkas-Conn, 1990: 108; Valjes, 2004: 90). Dealing
with all of these materials was to create serious pro-
cessing problems for the agencies involved. Process-
ing had to be done rapidly so that the information734 IFLA Journal 50(4)
could be used before it became out of date. This gave
a powerful impetus to experiments with innovative
approaches to information handling in that much of
this material was no longer in the conventional form
of printed books or journals. It was what was to
become known as “grey literature”—idiosyncrati-
cally, sometimes imperfectly produced typescripts in
limited numbers of copies of memoranda and research
reports not intended for general publication, a form of
literature that, since then, has become an increasingly
important aspect of the information landscape (see
Egan, 1954; GL 2022 Program and Conference
Bureau, 2022; Scho ¨pfel and Farace, 2009; Valjes,
2004).
“Information” had now become an ongoing
problem. In the USA, for example, research and
development agencies after the war were continu-
ously generating huge amounts of information that,
in the context of national security and the needs of
civilian peacetime availability, had to be processed,
evaluated for security reasons, and publiclydisseminated. The agencies involved often have com-
plicated administrative histories, such as the Atomic
Energy Commission (founded in 1946) and the giant
Department of Defense (emerging through the period
1947–1949), the National Science Foundation (1950)
and, after Sputnik in 1957, the National Aeronautics
and Space Administration(1958), among others.
What was true in the USA was equally true in the
UK, France, and the USSR. World War II had turned
on an information spigot that no one could now afford
to turn off. The interesting situation had arisen that
information, in its various manifestations, was rela-
tively suddenly itself an important object of research,
development, and innovation, especially in mechan-
ization if its potential value for research and develop-
ment more generally were to be realized. All sorts of
non-conventional systems began very quickly to be
invented and experimented with in the struggle to
bring this inundation of documents under control
and ready for distribution. It is in this situation that

Royal Society Empire Science
Conference, 1946
While the Allied countries were dealing with the
accumulation of documents amassed during and at the
end of World War II, and grappling with the geopo-
litical, economic, and colonial contests that followed
it, the issue of information’s role in science and soci-
ety in the post-war era was being discussed at another
level—in another dimension, as it were—as adum-
brated by President Roosevelt and Vannevar Bush.
It is possible to argue that there were two levels to
the information “problem” in the immediate post-war
period. One level involved a finite, relatively short-
term task of disposal, of the incorporation of physical
masses of existing documents into national systems
and structures such as libraries or research and docu-
mentation centers, and the organizational and admin-
istrative developments that flowed on nationally from
this. At another level was the creation of international
systems and structures that were necessary for the
management of scientific and other literature in the
vistas of the years ahead. How might international
steps be taken to mobilize information in the interests
of world peace and to increase the welfare and pros-
perity of all countries throughout the world?
In determining how this was to be thought through
and to assess what was needed, an important player
was the Royal Society of London. One of the main
progenitors of a completely new international organi-
zation for the management of science after World
War I in the form of the International Research Coun-
cil (later ICSU and now the International Council for
Science) was the Royal Society of London (Green-
away 1996). It called a huge imperial science confer-
ence, which met for not quite a month between June
and July 1946. As the president of the Royal Society
observed in his opening address before the King and
Queen:
During the war, the Society has been a focal point for
discussion of matters of mutual interest by scientific
representatives of the Dominions, many of whom acted
as liaison officers in London. It became evident that
many problems needed closer consideration and these
included the fuller use of Science for the benefit of
mankind, the improvement of scientific communica-
tions and other questions relating to the organization
of science within the Empire, and finally the machinery
of international co-operation. Arising from these meet-
ings it was resolved that it would be a wise procedure tocall together, soon after the war, representatives of a
wide range of the sciences from the various parts of the
Empire, in order to facilitate an exchange of views on
scientific matters of mutual concern. (Royal Society,
1948b: 15)
Among the wide-ranging general and sometimes quite
specific (such as the village pond in the rural economy
of India) subjects that the conference would take up
was that of the dissemination of scientific informa-
tion. In his survey paper, Robert S Hutton, Professor
of Metallurgy and a founding member of the UK
Association of Library and Information Bureaux
(later the Association for Information Management
or Aslib), stressed the need for a comprehensive cov-
erage of the increasing volume of literature in the pure
and applied sciences. In one paragraph, he referred to
the “[v]ast scale of scientific literature” and, in the
next, to the “gigantic scale of the literature” and the
problem this posed for its distribution throughout
the Empire. He also raised the problem of classifica-
tion, especially the use of the Universal Decimal Clas-
sification (UDC), “for it is indispensable that the
indexes and abstracts should be subdivided so that
anyone wishing to secure a bibliography of some sub-
ject matter ...can do so in the most efficient manner
