possible” (Royal Society, 1948b: 687). This led him
to suggest the importance of either a general agency to
collect centrally all the literature that was needed
for subsequent processing or the creation of a
“cooperative scheme by which suitable abstracting
bodies will work together along carefully prepared
lines so as to cover the whole field of scientific liter-
ature, to classify and interchange it by some logical
system” (Royal Society, 1948b: 693).
The upshot of all this was that, instead of
recommending another very broadly based meeting
on all aspects of the scientific research being carried
out or needed in the various countries of the British
Empire, the conference recommended that the Royal
Society convene a conference that would be wholly
focused on
the libraries, societies, and institutions responsible for
the publishing, abstracting and information services, in
order to examine the possibility of the improvement in
existing methods of collection, indexing and distribution
of scientific literature, and for the extension of existing
abstract services. (Royal Society, 1948a: 13)
The recommendation retained an Empire focus on
invitations being sent to “the Dominions, India and
the Colonies,” but it was suggested that, in addition,
observers might be invited from the USA (Royal
Society, 1948a: 14).736 IFLA Journal 50(4)
UNESCO
One of the organizations falling under the umbrella of
the new United Nations Organization that came into
being officially in 1946 was UNESCO. In its consti-
tution, UNESCO’s preamble declares: “That since
wars begin in the minds of men, it is in the minds
of men that the defence of peace must be con-
structed.” Among its objectives, it seeks “the full and
equal opportunities for education for all”; pursues
“objective truth” and the “free exchange of ideas and
knowledge”; and aims “to increase the means of com-
munication between peoples.” The ultimate goal is
“international peace and the common welfare of man-
kind” (UNESCO, 1945). At the very outset, in the part
of its constitution concerned with purposes and func-
tions, was enshrined its fundamental commitment to
maintaining, increasing, and diffusing knowledge by,
among other things, the creation of conventions to
protect the world’s intellectual heritage of books,
works of art, and monuments. It foreshadows the
development of cooperation among nations in all
forms of intellectual activity by the international
exchange of personnel and of information in all of its
many formats.
In a sense, its fundamental tenets were put to an
initial practical test—a test that had been so proble-
matic in 1919. Despite all sorts of international Allied
political and administrative complexities at the end of
the war, there was to be little in the way of a punitive
approach intellectually to the defeated nations. Unlike
the situation at the end of World War I, for example,
there was no attempt to create a new organization for
the international management of science and scien-
tific communication that would exclude the enemy
nations (Cock, 1983; Greenaway, 1996). This is per-
haps not surprising in that the first director of
UNESCO, Julian Huxley, and the first director of
UNESCO’s Science Section, Joseph Needham (one
of those responsible for science being included in the
remit of the new organization, with early discussion
having focused on education and culture), were inter-
nationally prominent scientists.
UNESCO, ICSU, and abstracting
After World War I, it took from 1919 to 1937 for a
formal relationship to be established between the Lea-
gue of Nations International Institute for Intellectual
Cooperation (the forerunner of UNESCO) and ICSU
(Nature , 1937; Renoliet, 1999). After World War II,
however, such a relationship was created almost
instantly when a formal agreement between UNESCO
and ICSU was drawn up in 1946. It had echoes of the
1937 agreement between ICSU and the InternationalInstitute for Intellectual Cooperation in that UNESCO
agreed to recognize the scientific unions as the basis
for the international organization of science as repre-
sented and coordinated by ICSU, while ICSU recog-
nized UNESCO as the “principal agent of United
Nations Organisation in the field of international sci-
entific relations” (Greenaway, 1996: 75). All of this
was possible because Ar ticle X1 of the UNESCO
constitution provided for UNESCO to “make suitable
arrangements for consultation and cooperation with
non-governmental intern ational organizations ...
and ...invite them to underta ke specific tasks”
(UNESCO, 1945, Constitution ). ICSU was an early
beneficiary of this provision. UNESCO offered rooms
for an ICSU liaison officer in its headquarters in Paris
and a substantial annual grant-in-aid (Stratton, 1950).
One of the first tasks that ISCU and UNESCO took
up was to collaborate in organizing an international
conference in 1949 on abstracting in science. The
existence of abstract and indexing journals of various
kinds has had a long history (Manzer, 1977). During
the interwar period, a number of these journals in the
anglophone world—such as Chemical Abstracts ,Bio-
logical Abstracts ,Physics Abstracts , and the range of
Abstracts issued by the Commonwealth Agricultural
Bureaux—continued to develop, though sometimes
with great difficulty financially and in receiving
access to the material they needed to cover. To some
extent, all of them had become international in
their disciplinary reach, but perhaps erratic in their
coverage. They were based in and issued by national
scientific organizations. Within their ranks were
duplication and overlap, subject lacunae, language
barriers, and idiosyncratic production and publishing
systems. Moreover, they constituted only half, as it
were, of pre-World War I services. Many German
bibliographic services had ceased publication in the
post-World War I period as a result of the punitive
approach taken at the time to German science
(Schroeder-Gudehus, 197 3: 99; see also Richards,
1994: 74–75). Donker Duyvis (1948a), Secretary
General of FID in reporting on the difficulties that
FID was facing in attempting to create a comprehen-
sive directory of extant abstracting services for dis-
cussion at the 1949 conference on abstracting,
remarked that “the circumstances of the war have
entirely overthrown the situation in the field of
abstracting.”1
Against this post-war background of lack of
coordination internationally and general disarray in
the field of science abstracting, UNESCO’s attention
had been drawn in 1946 to a proposal by the British
Medical Association to create an abstracting service
that would substantially overlap the proposals for an737 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
ambitious international abstracting service, Excerpta
Medica, then being planned in Amsterdam ( The
Lancet , 1947). Today, this has morphed into Embase,
a complex, commercial, bi bliographically based
information service.2But, in 1946, all of the problems
related to abstracts that were to be identified in the
Royal Society’s conference of 1948 were apparent in
these competing projects. Both would be strongly
duplicative of each other’s coverage, and both would
compete with and overlap the coverage and activities
of other established abstract journals. UNESCO was
able “after long negotiations,” commented Edward
Carter, Head of the Library Section of Unesco in the
report he presented to the IFLA meeting in 1948, to
set up an “interim co-ordinating committee for
medical and biological abstracting” that brought
together the important players in this area, including
eventually the World Health Organization (which
was then being organized, its formal existence being
ratified in 1948), in a forum where issues such as
duplication, gaps, exchange of abstracts, and standardi-
zation of methods could be discussed. The apparent
success of this venture led to the decision by UNESCO
in collaboration with ICSU to call an international
meeting to discuss similar problems of abstracting
across the entire domain of the sciences (Carter,
1948: 55–56).
Royal Society Scientific Information
Conference, 1948
The Royal Society Scientific Information Conference
was convened in London in June and July 1948 to
follow up on the recommendations of the Empire Sci-
ence Conference. This had, as mentioned above, sug-
gested that official invitations be restricted to the
countries of the Empire and to the USA. In fact, invi-
tations were extended not only to the USA but also to
the newly established UNESCO. Other arrangements
were made that, in effect, would allow anyone who
was interested to attend as an observer (Royal Soci-
ety, 1948a: 13–14). The conference was an extraordi-
narily comprehensive and forward-looking, although
rather intimidating, affair. In addition to the many
papers submitted, there was a small exhibition that
attempted to provide illustrative materials for most
of the subjects covered by the conference. Perhaps
the most interesting section for attendees was on
“Mechanical indexing and sorting.” This included
punched-card machines, coding systems for these
machines, microfilm readers, a Recordak system that
read UDC numbers backwards and eventually ended
in a microfilm process, and a cinestat photomatic
tabulator. Some of the machines were reproduced asplates in an appendix to the report on the conference
proceedings (Royal Society, 1948a: 225–232).
The introductory and extremely succinct “Editors’
preliminary notes” set up the background for the
conference in stating, in a brief paragraph for each,
what the information system problems facing the
world were and what was needed to solve them:
absolute loss of knowledg e in the sense of potentially
relevant papers that were ne ver retrieved; a partial
loss of knowledge resulting from delays in publica-
tion and abstracting, and inefficiencies in distribu-
tion such as a paper arriving as many as three years
late; inconvenience because of the time required to
search the literature; increasing costs; and the loss of
the scientific clerical and technical personnel neces-
sary to produce the literature. What was needed to
address these issues was cheapness, quality, rapidity,
ease of reference, and availability (Royal Society,
1948a: 237–238).
The report on the various discussions and the
papers that were submitted dealt often in great detail
with all the emerging issues related to information
needs, information uses, and institutional relation-
ships of the time. The section “Evidence taken,” for
example, for the discussion about mechanization,
touched on a number of inventions that were becom-
ing noteworthy. The use of different kinds of punched
cards and coding systems for the cards, such as Calvin
Mooers’ system (its name, Zatacoding, was not men-
tioned), were described. There was a cursory refer-
ence to one of the first computers: “The UNIVAC
machine (Eckert and Mauchly, Philadelphia) stores
information electronically and on magnetic tapes”—
there is no sense in this remark of the future of com-
puting for the transformation of information storage
and retrieval. Ralph Shaw described his Rapid Selec-
tor, which attempted to operationalize an idea of
Vannevar Bush for microfilm selection by machine.
A separate section was devoted to chemical indexing
and the problems of chemical notation. New repro-
graphic techniques, especially microfilm, appeared in
the discussions of several of the papers and section
reports. Among the final recommendations was that a
full-scale experiment in “mechanical methods of
indexing and selection” might be considered in a sci-
entific library (Royal Society, 1948a: 161). There was
also much commentary on how the services of
libraries might be improved, especially the need for
upgrading the status of special librarians and informa-
tion officers (Royal Society, 1948a: 158–163, 202).
The UDC had had a long and rather difficult history
since its initial formula tion in 1895–1896 (see
Rayward, 1975: 85–96).3Its use both in the organiza-
tion of bibliographical entries in abstracting and738 IFLA Journal 50(4)
indexing journals and in catalogs was discussed at
various points during the conference. It was noted that
it was “the only [system] worked out in detail for the
whole of science and was now at a stage to be ready
for ‘machine coding’” (Royal Society, 1948a: 160). It
was also singled out for a slightly backhanded
comment:
The Conference has concluded that, although the
application of the Universal Decimal Classification
(UDC), particularly in the field of applied science, has
definite limitations, there are manifest possible advan-
tages to be gained through extension of its use, and it is
hoped that all who can use the UDC will do so. (Royal
Society, 1948a: 203)
But it epitomized the discussions within the confer-
ence on the problems and the needs for classification
in information organization and access that had to be
worked out in the years to come. JD Bernal, the pio-
neering crystallographer and Fellow of the Royal
Society, who played a major role in the conference,
suggested in this respect that “[a] special scientific
body to carry out a long-term investigation into the
theory and practice of classification without pre-
commitment to any particular system, should be set
up” (Royal Society, 1948a: 190; see also Muddiman,
2003). This provided the impetus for the creation of
the Classification Research Group in England, which
over many years was to elaborate a theory of faceted
classification and compile a number of new kinds of
subject classifications (see Justice, 2004; McIlwaine
and Broughton, 2000).
Among the recommendations that were perhaps to
have the most impact subsequently were those on
abstracts. Even the “Editors’ preliminary notes”
stressed the importance of the conference’s work in
analyzing the problems associated with the publica-
tion of abstracts, and the necessity that they be con-
tinuously cumulated along with related indexing
services in such a way as to facilitate retrospective
searching of the literature (Royal Society, 1948a:
235). The conference recommended that the Royal
Society create a “Standing Committee of abstracting
organisations” to examine such issues as the need for
standardization in citation practices and indexing
methods; the compilation of a comprehensive list of
abstracting journals; and the identification of lacunae
where services were needed (Royal Society, 1948a:
139). These were among the subjects to be taken up
the following year at the UNESCO/ICSU conference
on abstracting. A one-page statement—“Presentation
of abstracts”—in the report of the section on scientific
publishing was especially important. It was to becomethe basis for a standard for the preparation of abstracts
in much later discussions about abstracts in the con-
text of indexing and abstracting journals, as well as in
terms of emerging institutional information services
(Royal Society, 1948a: 200).
UNESCO, so new at the time, was rarely referred
to throughout the conference. UNESCO, however,
had a high-powered representation: Professor Joseph
Needham, head of its Science Section, prominent bio-
chemist, and China expert; Edward Carter, head of the
Libraries Section, architect, and librarian; AJ Moeller,
head of the Bibliographic Section; and JB Reid, a
program specialist in scien tific information (Royal
Society, 1948a: 30). Carter was to acknowledge the
importance of the Royal Society’s “Documentation
Conference” (1951: 258) (as he called it) in shaping
UNESCO’s own programs. The potential bibliogra-
phical or documentation role of UNESCO (the terms
were sometimes used indistinguishably), however,
was already the subject of at least one major exposi-
tion. Describing documentation activities in the UK,
AFC Pollard provided a complicated schematic plan
of international and national developments in docu-
mentation, which placed UNESCO and the Interna-
tional Organization for Standardization (ISO) at the
apex of his chart, the latter organization having come
formally into being in 1948. The chart showed them
working through FID, IFLA, and ISO Committee 46:
Documentation. He mentioned that FID’s relation-
ships with UNESCO were being finalized at this time
(Royal Society, 1948a: 370–375). Pollard had been
president of the International Institute of Bibliography
in Brussels and active in its reorganization into what
became FID, and was also one of the founders and
president of the British Society for International
Bibliography, an affiliate of the Brussels body that
had merged with Aslib in January 1948. He died not
long after the conference concluded ( Journal of
Documentation , 1948; Muddiman, 2005: 415).
FID and UNESCO
One of Huxley’s early appointments of personnel to
set up the UNESCO Secretariat, as mentioned above,
was Edward Carter as head of the Library Section.
Carter became a major force in reviving, with
UNESCO financial support, both FID and IFLA. He
worked tirelessly in trying to bring the two organiza-
tions, ultimately unsuccessfully, into harmony with
each other. This was a constant theme of his reports
to the meetings of IFLA and FID for over a decade. At
one stage in the early 1950s, it was proposed that a
permanent liaison comm ittee between them and
UNESCO be set up, though this idea lapsed. As an739 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
example of his attitude, he also suggested that when
the UNESCO International Advisory Committee on
Bibliography was created as an outcome of the 1950
Conference on the Improvement of Bibliographical
Services, the Committee might be considered “in
theory ...a sub-commission of IFLA and FID and the
other international organizations for librarianship”
(Carter, 1954: 4).
At the first full meeting of FID after War World
War II in Paris in 1946, Carter introduced an agree-
ment between UNESCO and FID that paralleled that
of UNESCO with ICSU:
[UNESCO] recognises the Federation International de
Documentation as the principal international organisa-
tion of nation documentation bodies and councils
through which their opinion can be consulted on all
relevant matters of Unesco’s program with regard to
documentation: and that conversely FID recognises
Unesco as the principal agency of the United Nations
in the field of documentation. (UNESCO and Federation
of Documentation, 1947: 46)
Further paragraphs dealt with, among other things,
mutual commitment to the development and improve-
ment of documentation services throughout the world,
mutual consultation, and reciprocal representation at
each other’s meetings. Article VIII, dealing with finan-
cial and other material support, provided for UNESCO
to offer financial support for international projects being
carried out by FID, including conferences and assistance
in the form of “office space, secretarial services, arrange-
ments for meetings documentation etc.” (UNESCO
and International Federation for Documentation, 1947:
47), although the offer of these specific services was
quickly withdrawn. Among the projects it was suggested
that FID might undertake with UNESCO su pport
were: the compilation of a directory of national doc-
umentation services; a subject list of periodicals; the
creation of what was calle d the Repertorium Tech-
nicum, a survey of technical fields where the litera-
ture was difficult to find and for which there were
inadequate lists; and, finally, the development of the
UDC, with a view to establishing its concordance
with the Dewey System ([F´ ed´eration International
de Documentation], 1948: 2).
The overall structure and activities of FID had been
determined at the point of its revival in 1946. Its sta-
tutes were revised in 1948. They emphasized that its
membership and financial base were anchored in
national committees or associations for documenta-
tion. An important addition to this base was that of
the American Documentation Institute in 1947. The
Institute had been set up in 1937, and the history of itsevolution into the American Society for Information
Science has been told in detail by Farkas-Conn
(1990). At the prompting of the Rockefeller Founda-
tion, it had been represented unofficially at the first
post-war meeting of FID in Paris in 1946 by Charles
David, director of the University of Pennsylvania
Library. In 1947, the American Documentation Insti-
tute became the official US member of FID, its rep-
resentation being managed through an international
relations committee chaired by David. He became
strongly supportive of the Institute’s membership, in
part influenced by what he considered the deep com-
mitment of UNESCO to working with and through
FID. He suggested in his “Report from Europe” of
1948 that in cooperation with UNESCO, the FID pro-
gram, developed with UNESCO support, consisted of
such matters as: the compilation of an international
directory for documentation and reprographic ser-
vices; the standardization of methods and apparatuses
of document reproduction, filing systems, and nomen-
clature; the coordination of abstracting services; and
the study of classification, especially the UDC. Like
Carter, David (1948) raised the question of the simi-
larities between the work of FID and IFLA, and the
possibilities of achieving cooperation between them.
As one of its first projects with FID, UNESCO
commissioned a major survey of existing abstracting
services. This was intended to provide basic informa-
tion to be drawn on in the deliberation at the confer-
ence on abstracting. Donker Duyvis, FID’s general
secretary, described the process involved and the dif-
ficulties that FID faced in ultimately presenting what
was accepted as an incomplete, provisional listing
(1948). He also submitted to the UNESCO Organiz-
ing Committee, in the name of the FID General Secre-
tariat, a long general report discussing what literature,
mostly pre-war, was available on the general prob-
lems presented by abstracting journals, especially the
overlap between journals that were related to the same
or similar subjects and the scatter of information
between journals that led to relevant information
b e i n gh a r dt of i n do rs i m p l ym i s s e dc o m p l e t e l y
([Duyvis], 1948b).
UNESCO/ICSU Conference on Science
Abstracting, 1949
Pierre Auger, head of UNESCO’s Natural Sciences
Section, pointed out that the need for such a confer-
ence had been recognized as early as the first General
Conference of UNESCO in 1946: “The idea would be
for every research worker to be able to read abstracts
of all articles of interest to him, almost immediately
they appear, irrespective of the country or language of740 IFLA Journal 50(4)
publication” (International Conference on Abstract-
ing, 1951: 7). Much of the conference discussion and
several of the final recommendations drew on data in
the FID survey that had been commissioned by
UNESCO. They also followed up many of the recom-
mendations of the Royal Society Scientific Informa-
tion Conference. The problems of scientific
publishing in general, and of compiling and incorpor-
ating abstracts into scientific papers and then disse-
minating the abstracts to the abstracting services,
were canvassed in great detail in the conference’s
sections. Problems such as the importance of
national coverage, difficulties of indexing and clas-
sification, costs, language, terminology, and coordi-
nation between abstracting services were explored.
There were long discussions about the use of micro-
film both in publishing and e xchanging abstracts, as
well as distributing the original articles for which
abstracts were compiled.
The potential use of machines, of which discus-
sions about the possibilities of microfilm were a part,
was clearly exciting. Developments in the UK,
France, and the USA were canvassed more enthusias-
tically and comprehensively than in the Royal Society
Scientific Information Conference. A separate note on
“New devices for documentation and their effect on
abstracting” contained selections from a letter from
JW Perry of the Massachusetts Institute of Technol-
ogy on mechanized documentation centers. John Von
Neuman at Princeton replied (technically and perhaps
unintelligibly to most) to a query from the Secretariat
of the conference about “the large electronic com-
puter he is building and the possibilities it offers for
the recording and rapid selection of information”
(International Conference on Abstracting, 1951:
163–164). The conclusion was essentially that the
machines being developed “were too rare a luxury”;
“only a very small number of abstracting services and
documentation centres can consider buying them”;
their potential was great but remained as yet unrea-
lized; a code for handling masses of information was
needed along with the standardization of equipment;
and UNESCO had a role to play in bringing people
interested in these matters together, perhaps by orga-
nizing a small conference on the subject (International
Conference on Abstracting, 1951: 105–108).
A major practical recommendation dealt with the
problem of abstracting in the literature of physics. It
was suggested
[that c]onsideration be g iven to the possibility of
publishing, under the auspices of a single internationally
controlled organization, a single international general
abstracting journal for physics, both pure and applied,and for such branches of engineering as it may be pos-
sible to include; that a committee, composed of
representatives of the interested international scientific
unions and of the organizations responsible for the exist-
ing general abstracting services in this field, including
the Institution of Electrical Engineers and the American
Physical Society, be convened for the purpose of carry-
ing out this recommendation; that this committee give
attention to the proposals that the abstracts presented in
the journal should be mixed. (International Conference
on Abstracting, 1951: 116)
A postscript was added to the conference’s final
report, outlining subsequent developments to June
1953. Notable among these was the creation of a per-
manent International Advisory Committee on Docu-
mentation in the Natural Sciences to advise the
director general regarding the relevant programs of
UNESCO and to keep such a committee in contact
with the parallel Advisory Committee on a Biblio-
graphy located in the Libraries Division of
UNESCO, which was “concerned with generalised
channels and techniques of documentation” (Interna-
tional Conference on Abstracting, 1951: 193). These
committees represented a division of interest and activ-
ity within UNESCO that was to play out over a period
of 20 years until the formation of the UNESCO Gen-
eral Information Programme/Programme G´ en´eral
d’Information.
ICSU Abstracting Board
ICSU, prompted by the Union of Pure and Applied
Physics, began a process that sought to implement the
recommendation that a single physics abstract journal
be prepared. An ICSU Commission was created to
study the matter. It met in 1949 in Paris at the same
time as UNESCO was itself following up the proposal
in a “Meeting of users of document abstracts in
Physics.” The idea of creating a single journal proved
impossible to carry out. It would have required the
amalgamation of Physic Abstracts , part of the long-
standing British Science Abstracts that dated from the
early part of the 20th century, with the physics section
of the French Bulletin Analytique , published by the
relatively newly active French Centre national de la
recherche scientifique. Moreover, the revival of the
German service, Physikalische Berichte , was under-
way and could be expected to complicate both lin-
guistic and cooperation problems. The decision was
to keep the two existing abstracting services separate
but to ensure that all leading physics journals publish
author abstracts according to the Royal Society’s
guidelines, which had been slightly emended in Eng-
lish for the English-speaking nations and in French for741 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
the European nations, irrespective of the original lan-
guage of an article (International Conference on
Abstracting, 1951: 170–171, 194). In order to speed
up the compilation, editing, and printing of the
abstract journals themselves, the editors of the jour-
nals to be abstracted were encouraged to send page
proofs or at least clippings of abstracts to the offices
of the abstracting journals or ICSU in Paris for
distribution.
The complicated negotiations that were involved in
coordinating the abstracting of the physics literature
led to the realization that “the Bureau of ICSU accepts
an International Abstracting Service as a normal per-
manent activity of the council” (Boutry 1959: 1508).
This, in turn, led to the decision in 1951 that ICSU
create a Board for the International Abstracting Ser-
vice. This became the ICSU Abstracting Board, which
was set up initially with funding from UNESCO and
ICSU. It began to operate in 1952 with just two mem-
bers— Science Abstracts and the physics section of the
Centre national de la recherche scientifique’s Bulletin
Analytique . Membership was sought the following
year by the revived Physikalische Berichte ,a n d
almost at the moment of the formal creation of the
Abstracting Board, the International Union of Pure
and Applied Chemistry had suggested that the coor-
dination of the abstracting of chemical literature
should become part of the new organization. It took
until 1954 for the Abstracting Board to intimate “that
it felt ready to extend the scope of its activities,”
(Boutrty, 1959:1513) and Chemical Abstracts and the
Bulletin Analytique related to chemistry joined the
board as members, followed soon after by the Che-
misches Zentralblatt . The foundation and early work
of the ICSU Abstracting Board has been described in
great detail by its first secretary, GA Boutry (1959).
All of the journals that included articles reporting
original research agreed to provide abstracts in the stan-
dard form set out by the Royal Society and as emended
by UNESCO in English or French. The Board received
page proofs of the issues of various journals or, in some
cases, clippings of authors’ summaries or abstracts.
These were then distributed to the relevant abstract
journals either in print form, when they had been pro-
vided in multiple copies, or as microfilm, when only
one copy had been received. The chemical literature,
because it was so much larger in quantity, complexity,
and diversity, presented particular problems, and the
Board had to devise novel procedures to handle it.
A particularly important extension of the Board’s
activities in 1954 was its outreach to the Academy of
Sciences of the Soviet Union to negotiate an exchange
of Russian and American journals. This began in 1955
with the Board microfilming the Russian material forfurther distribution. Eventually, the American Insti-
tute of Physics, in consultation with various European
counterparts, undertook to prepare a full cover-to-
cover English translation of some of the Russian
journals. In 1984, the ICSU Abstracting Board transi-
tioned into independence as the International Council
for Scientific and Technical Information.
IFLA and UNESCO
IFLA came to post-war life a year later than FID—that
is, in 1947 at a conference in Oslo where 52 delegates
from 18 countries convened to begin the process of
rebuilding the organization. The Rockefeller Founda-
tion had given financial aid for the resumption of its
work (Sevensma, 1947: 25). The president, Marcel
Godet, in a long farewell address on his much-
delayed retirement from the position, having movingly
described the losses and destruction inflicted on
libraries and librarians during World War II, stressed
the need to try to restore what had been lost by seeking
the widest possible forms of international coopera-
tion—especially, working with UNESCO and FID. The
world of today, he said, was born of the war. The past
would never return and it would be foolish to wait
“[w]ith folded arms” for the ship to sink. It was in this
context, he believed, that libraries and librarians had to
find their “modest” role as “refuges of tranquillity,
fountains of science and homes of culture” (Godet,
1947: 16) in combatting the threats to civilization.
The meeting went on to elect a new president—the
Norwegian, William Munthe—and a new executive
board, and to deal with the reports that had come in
from the various subcommittees. The committee deal-
ing with popular libraries suggested that IFLA needed
to become more deeply involved with these libraries,
and the meeting resolved that IFLA and UNESCO
should encourage the establishment and strengthening
of systems of public libraries throughout the world. Of
particular importance were reports from the Subcom-
mittee on the Unification of Cataloguing Rules, espe-
cially a report prepared by Andrew Osborn, Head of
Cataloging at Harvard University, on the work that
had been going on in the USA. Among other issues
explored were professional education, currency-
related problems in the acquisition of materials, and
the continuing work on photocopying and micropho-
tography by representatives of FID, UNESCO, and
the infant ISO. While this last did not come into being
officially until 1947, it essentially took up the work of
the pre-war organization for standards (International
Organization for Standardization, 1997: 15). Pierre
Bourgeois, whose career covered both librarianship
and documentation, and who was to follow Munthe742 IFLA Journal 50(4)
as president of IFLA, presented a long report from the
ISO Secretariat on the library-related standards that
were being discussed or had been developed by its
pre-war organization: paper formats, paper quality,
the size of catalog cards and cards used for abstracts
by publishers, microfilm, abbreviations of the titles of
periodicals, and so on.
The presence of two persons provided a special
focus for the meeting. Fritz Donker Duyvis presented
a report on the activities of the recently resuscitated
FID and stressed the need for the cooperation of IFLA
with both FID and the ISO. He also read the report
from Aslib’s Edith Ditmas on the development of
special libraries and documentation centers in the
UK. How libraries and documentation centers were
similar and different and the implications of this were
unresolved problems carried over from the pre-war
era. IFLA, for example, had been invited by the Union
franc¸aise des organismes de documentation to take
part in the 1937 World Congress of Universal Docu-
mentation, among whose sponsors were FID and the
League of Nations International Institute for Intellec-
tual Cooperation. Tietse Pieter Sevensma, then—and
still—secretary general of IFLA, had responded to the
invitation by observing that libraries were viewed so
differently by those organizing the Congress that “I
don’t quite see how our Federation could participate
in a Congress of which the programme shows so little
interest and understanding of our professional work.”
He suggested that it would be interesting to know
what was meant by documentation and where “the
work of libraries ended and the work of documenta-
tion began” (De Vries, 1976: 101–102). This sense
of a division between the two was to be perpetuated
beyond World War II and perhaps, ultimately, by
UNESCO itself as its work in the 1960s and 1970s
became divided between issues essentially related to
libraries and those related to the organization of doc-
umentation conceived of as scientific and technical
information. Jacques Tocatlian (2000: 11) refers to
this issue as late as 2000.
Edward Carter, representing UNESCO, outlined its
program for libraries and for cooperating with IFLA.
He presented what is now a standard format for a
formal agreement between UNESCO and IFLA along
the lines first worked out with ICSU and FID, in
which each organization, recognizing the other’s cen-
trality in its respective roles, agreed to cooperate. As
in the case of FID, UNESCO promised financial sup-
port for IFLA, and for some years it received an
annual subvention from UNESCO (Projet de Conven-
tion, 1947: 46–48).
Invited to hold its 1948 meeting in the USA, for
financial reasons this had to be held in London where,in association with UNESCO, IFLA also conducted
an international summer school on public libraries,
with 50 librarians from different countries in
attendance (Comit´ e international des biblioth` eques,
1948: 12). At pretty much the same time as this
UNESCO/IFLA library event was taking place, FID
was cooperating with UNESCO on planning the 1949
Conference on Science Abstracting. Once again,
cooperation with FID was an important issue, which
came up at different times throughout the 1948 IFLA
meeting.
Perhaps the outstanding document at the meeting
was a lengthy report by Carter on the work of the
Libraries Division of UNESCO. An overriding theme
was that of stimulating the setting up and work
of public libraries, in connection with which he
announced the drawing up, in conjunction with the
IFLA Public Libraries Committee, of the “IFLA–
UNESCO Public Library Manifesto,” the regular revi-
sion and publication of which has been a feature of
IFLA’s work ever since (IFLA and UNESCO, 2022).
Another important announcement was the planning,
in conjunction with the Library of Congress, of a
survey of bibliographical services throughout the
world. The 1947 UNESCO General Conference had
authorized funds for “a survey of bibliographical ser-
vices jointly with the Library of Congress of the
United States and to seek the active cooperation of
other national libraries in the development of the
survey” (Kasiske, 1967: 5). Carter stressed that IFLA
and FID were “intimately concerned as the agencies
through which any project which is evolved can be
carried out. (1948: 57)” The International Council of
Archives (created in 1948 on the basis of an existing
committee of the League of Nations) was also to be
involved. A preliminary survey by Catherine Oliver
Murra on the nature and distribution of bibliographi-
cal services supporting fundamental education
throughout the world was distributed in 1947.
UNESCO Conference on the
Improvement of Bibliographic
Services, 1950
The UNESCO Conference on the Improvement of
Bibliographic Services met in Paris from 7–10
November 1950. The final report of the UNESCO/
Library of Congress survey, Bibliographical services,
their present state and possibilities of improvement ,
provided the basis for discussion at the conference.
Carter, discussing the imminent publication of the
report at the International Conference on Science
Abstracting, hoped it might “provide the general
scheme into which all types of biographical services743 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
would fit” (International Conference on Abstracting,
1951: 25).
This far-reaching report by Verner Clapp of the
Library of Congress canvassed the current state of
bibliographical services throughout the world; the
roles of various levels of national, international, and
special bibliography in contributing to the existing
state of affairs; and how the overall situation interna-
tionally might be improved (UNESCO/Library of
Congress Bibliographical Survey, 1950a). An appen-
dix by Murra (1950) on the development of the con-
cept of national bibliography accompanied the report.
National bibliographical working groups in 41 coun-
tries then considered the report and formulated
responses in terms of what was desirable from their
various points of view for the improvement of biblio-
graphical services. Their suggestions were quickly
synthesized in the UNESCO Secretariat into a further
report for distribution to the conference (UNESCO/
Library of Congress Bibliographical Survey, 1950b).
This conference in Paris in 1950 was, in fact, a
replacement and rebadging of the third International
Congress on Librarianship and Bibliography that had
been planned by IFLA and FID to be held in the USA
in 1950 but had to be abandoned for financial reasons.
The conference was important. The membership was
wide and its recommendati ons were influential in
future planning. Jesse Shera (1950: 145), one of the
US representatives at the conference, was of the opin-
ion that, in the four days of the conference, “a general
understanding about the objectives of bibliographic
organization was achieved and the groundwork was
laid for effective and permanent action.”
The conference recommendations at the national
level focused on the requirement that, among other
things, each nation should publish complete current
national bibliographies and should have a permanent
planning body to promote and coordinate bibliogra-
phical and information services. This body should
serve as a point of contact for international organiza-
tions. Luther Evans (1954: 96–99), director general of
UNESCO at the time and a former librarian at the US
Library of Congress, observed that the acceptance of
such national roles and responsibilities, as encouraged
by UNESCO, was the most effective means available
to UNESCO to contribute to the improvement of bib-
liographic organization. How effective the initiative
provided by the conference and its documents were is
attested to by the number of countries that actually
began to issue complete national bibliographies soon
afterwards. Seven (with a possible eight), all begin-
ning between 1950 and 1952, are listed in what is an
extremely comprehensive follow-up survey on theimprovement of bibliographic organization by Clapp
and Murra (1954: 97), the authors of the original con-
ference working documents.
Carter reported that, as early as 1951, through the
United Nations Programme of Technical Assistance
for developing countries, UNESCO was helping to
create a number of documentation centers in these
countries. For him, these centers were “perhaps the
most positive and practical effort which is being made
to stimulate bibliographic work not only in separate
countries but in whole regions” (Carter, 1951: 259).
By the mid 1960s, UNESCO was supporting national
scientific or documentation centers in 21 countries. It
was even proposed that these centers might form a
worldwide network, eventually to become the basis
for a “world Centre for scientific information”
(Kasiske, 1967: 13–15).
At the international level, it was agreed that a
permanent international committee for the coordina-
tion and promotion of bibliographic developments
should be created. Following the discussions of a pro-
visional committee, UNESCO formally set up the
International Advisory Committee on Bibliography in
1953. Carter (1954: 2) described it as “a child of the
1950 conference” and “at the centre of UNESCO’s
interest in bibliography as a whole.” It was, in his
view, an expression of UNESCO’s commitment to
IFLA and FID, as mentioned above, not only by per-
manent formal representation from each of these
organizations, but also because most of the members
of the Advisory Committee were active members or
office-holders of the two organizations. It was to have
oversight of UNESCO’s activities related to national
bibliographic centers. Under its mandate, regional
meetings on national libraries and the planning of
library services were arranged over more than a 10-
year period. The Advisory Committee had the respon-
sibility for arranging for the preparation of annual
reports nationally and internationally on bibliographi-
cal developments throughout the world. These reports
were published regularly and a number of cumula-
tions were undertaken until 1984.
Finally, in 1954, the Advisory Committee funded a
study on standardization in documentation, represent-
ing a summation of decades of work by ISO relevant
to both IFLA and FID. Published in 1954, this docu-
ment led to further discussion over a number of years
and to proposals for letting contracts related to biblio-
graphic standardization. A recommendation was
made in 1958 that such a contract be awarded to IFLA
to continue the work of its group studying the coordi-
nation of cataloguing rules. This, in turn, led to the
planning of the International Conference on744 IFLA Journal 50(4)
Cataloguing Principle s, jointly sponsored by
UNESCO and the US Council on Library Resources
in 1961. All of this activity involved the idea that the
creation of similar, if not fully standardized, infra-
structures was necessary as the basis of a generalized
international system for bibliographical control.
International Conference on Scientific
Information, 1958
In 1958, the US National Science Foundation, the
National Academy of Sciences, and the American
Documentation Institute sponsored the International
Conference on Scientific Information. The last gen-
eral conference of this kind had been that of the Royal
Society 10 year earlier. The conference was one of the
many soul-searching responses in the USA to the
launch of Sputnik in 1957 by the USSR as part of its
space program—a defining moment in US–USSR riv-
alry in the Cold War (e.g. see Geiger, 1997; Lapidus,
1970; Wooster, 1987).
The conference was preceded by the distribution of
a series of preprint papers prepared to stringent
requirements, which were to be used as the basis for
the conference’s deliberations. These papers were
intended to be as succinct as possible; the information
in them was not to have been previously published;
and, the conference being aimed at specialists, they
were to contain only information that would be rele-
vant to the participants. The conference, similar in
organizational thoroughness and scope to that of the
Royal Society, and supported by the US equivalent
of the Royal Society, presented a remarkable collec-
tive survey of such issues as scientists’ needs for
information; the effectiveness of abstracting and
indexing services; new or ganization opportunities
for information storage and searching; issues related
to the design of new systems; and the relative
responsibilities of governm ents, professional societ-
ies, universities, and industry for information
research and service improvements.
In summing up the position of indexing and
abstracting services in the 1930s, Clapp (1950:
197) had written: “There was ...no attempt at
comprehensive organization of bibliographical
services; and among the bibliographical services
themselves there was no such organization, no
interrelation, no coordination, but, on the con-
trary, duplication, overlapping, gaps, uncontrolled
multiplication.”4Now, more than 50 years later,
the International Conference on Scientific Infor-
mation unexpectedly and unwittingly echoed
these conclusions:As it stands now, major abstracting services in the
subject fields use different classification systems, differ-
ent indexing systems, differe nt abbreviation lists for
journals, different translation assistance. Certainly this
is an area for cooperative effort, and such is already in
progress—in the field of physics and chemistry under
the ICSU Abstracting Board. (National Research
Council, 1959: 1552)
While new technologies, especially computers, were
the subject of many papers and much discussion at the
conference, it recognized the current limitations to the
use and effectiveness of these new computer-based
systems and methods, along with the imperfections
of the current processes used in evaluating them. But
its conclusion about the fu ture was clear: all new
information-handling developments must be related “to
the most modern techniques for programming digital
computers.” (International Research Council , 1959:
1560) There was general skepticism about the possi-
bilities of finding solutions at a global level. What
was needed was increased experimentation at a local
level (National Research Council, 1959: 1560).
Even so, there was a renewed sense that interna-
tional cooperation was necessary to deal with the con-
tinuing—and fundamental—problem of
organisation, including integration of services both
nationally and internationally and negotiation between
organisations and countries as to what shall be done and
in what manner to meet the needs of different kinds of
scientists and institutions more carefully and precisely
than hitherto. (National Research Council, 1959: 1561)
A comment such as this suggests how valuable the
emergence of UNESCO’s UNISIST and NATIS
programs might be.
UNISIST and NATIS
What seems to be a natural culmination of all of the
long series of conferences, recommendations, propos-
als, reports, and other activities outlined in this article,
and of the work of various intergovernmental and
non-governmental organizations struggling separately
or collaboratively for a period of over 30 years with a
range of information-related issues, was two separate
programs centered in UNESCO. They represent the
ultimate expression of the bifurcation of UNESCO
activity between scientific information and bibliogra-
phical organization in libraries, as mentioned above.
The setting up by UNESCO of the International Advi-
sory Committee on Documentation in the National
Sciences in 1953 following the 1949 International
Conference on Science Abstracting points to one745 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
program. The setting up, coincidentally in 1953, of
the International Advisory Committee on Bibliogra-
phy following the UNESCO/Library of Congress
International Conference for the Improvement of Bib-
liographical Services in 1950, points to the other. One
program, UNSIST, was developed by UNESCO
jointly with ICSU and grew out of a major intergo-
vernmental conference in 1971. The other, NATIS,
also jointly organized and supported by UNESCO but
in cooperation with IFLA and FID, grew out of an
intergovernmental conference in 1974. Taking a step
back from individual preoccupations with libraries,
bibliography, and scientific information, one might
be forgiven for thinking that the two programs cov-
ered so many of the desiderata that had been formu-
lated and repetitively debated for decades about the
organization of information internationally, espe-
cially scientific and technical information, that, taken
together, they finally presented the rationale and
framework for a coordinated, even integrated, inter-
national information order.
UNISIST
UNISIT (a non-acronym) came into formal existence
by way of the Intergovernmental Conference for the
Establishment of a World Science Information Sys-
tem in Paris in 1971. The idea had originated, it has
been suggested, in an informal comment made by the
president of ICSU to the UNESCO director general,
Ren´e Mahue, that something needed to be done about
the “messy situation” that had resulted from the pro-
liferation around the world of incompatible technical
and scientific information services (Tocatlian, 2000:
4). In 1966, the General Assembly of ICSU created
a special committee to study the feasibility of estab-
lishing a world science information system in colla-
boration with UNESCO and other international
organizations and specialists (UNESCO, 1971: 22–
23). With support from UNESCO, a substantial fea-
sibility study was undertaken over a 10-year period
with input from various working groups. In submit-
ting a summary of the study to the director general of
UNESCO and the president of ICSU, Harrison
Brown, convenor of the UNISIST Central Committee,
informed them that there was unanimous agreement
that a world science information system, considered as a
flexible network evolving from an extension of volun-
tary cooperation of existing and future services, is fea-
sible. Further, from the point of view of the needs of
scientific and technological communities, such a flex-
ible network is both desirable and necessary. (Interna-
tional Council for Science, 1971: ix)The conference’s discussions revolved around a num-
ber of fundamental issues that were thought to form
necessary aspects of a UNISIST program, such as
improving the tools of system interconnection;
strengthening the functions and improving the perfor-
mance of the individual components of the informa-
tion transfer chain, including libraries, information
analysis centers, and abstracting, indexing, and trans-
lating services; increasing the number of personnel
essential to the planning and operation of future
information networks; encouraging governments to
provide the optimal economic and political environ-
ments for the development of systems interconnect-
ability and cooperation; providing assistance to
developing countries to create basic information
infrastructures; and developing pilot projects in coop-
eration with other United Nations agencies (UNESCO
1971 UNISIST; UNESCO 1971 Synopsis; UNESCO
1979, UNISIST II).
As the conference progressed, and later during
UNISIST’s life as an established frame of reference
for the international management of scientific infor-
mation, there were some differences of orientation
and of expectations among the participants. Tocatlian,
for example, commented on international tensions in
the development of UNISIST:
It was during the Cold War. I think—this is personal—
the Soviets thought they could acquire some important
international technical inf ormation through the UNI-
SIST. So they were very favorable, but they were lean-
ing towards a system rather than a program. The
UNISIST became a loose program to stimulate interna-
tional cooperation, leading towards better access to sci-
entific and technical information. Arutiunov [the USSR
member of the UNISIST Feasibility Committee] and the
Eastern Block wanted a system ...The Soviets also
wanted technology rather than science. They insisted
on technology. Then, later, as the UNISIST was in exis-
tence as a program, the developing countries began
wanting technology as well. They considered science
elitist, for the industrialized countries only. So there was
a little bit of tension. (Tocatlian, 2000: 5–6)
In fact, UNISIST was often seen not as a general
program but as “the set of internationally developed
methods, norms, standards, principles, and techniques
governing the processing and transfer of information”
(Rose, 1989: 232).
Nevertheless, unanimous agreement had been
reached by conference representatives from a very
broad international scientific community that the idea
of creating a world science information system was
possible, if the idea of a “system” were not too strictly
interpreted. As it developed, UNISIST became an746 IFLA Journal 50(4)
active and popular program, especially focused on the
needs of developing countries. The first UNISIST
conference was followed by a second in 1979 where
this focus was explicit (UNESCO, 1979).
Reflecting on the importance of the UNISIST
program within UNESCO itself and its continuing
positive international reverberations, Adam Wysocki,
who had responsibility for the program in the
UNESCO Secretariat and was later to become direc-
tor of the UNESCO General Information Programme,
noted that the secretary general of the United Nations
himself had acknowledged the important role of
UNISIST for the whole family of United Nations
organizations:
There is within the United Nations system one informa-
tion programme of a general nature designed to provide
a conceptual framework for the establishment of
national and international scientific and technological
information systems and services to facilitate access
to the world information resources and to create the
necessary conditions for systems interconnection and
compatibility. This is Unesco’s UNISIST. (Wysocki,
1978: 300)
NATIS, IFLA, and Universal Bibliographic
Control
The Intergovernmental Conference on the Planning
of National Documentation, Library and Archive
Infrastructures (NATIS), which was held in Paris in
September 1974, arose in part from a desire within the
UNESCO Secretariat to find a parallel organizational
program for libraries and related agencies to the
UNISIST program (Toca tlian, 2000: 11). Concep-
tually, the formation of the NATIS program ulti-
mately owed a great deal to IFLA’s program for
Universal Bibliographic Control (UBC). This had a
long development. It is important for the background
to the NATIS conference.
UBC dealt with the problem of the unification of
cataloguing rules and, eventually, the creation of stan-
dards for the machine transfer of bibliographic data
shaped by those rules. At the first post-war meeting of
IFLA in Oslo in 1947, as has been mentioned, Andrew
Osborn reported to the Sub-Committee on the Unifi-
cation of Cataloguing Rules on developments in the
USA. He suggested that there was now a sense that the
situation of cataloguing had become fluid in a way
that might allow IFLA considerable influence in the
movement toward the unification of international cat-
aloguing practices (Comit´ e international des bib-
lioth`eques, 1947: 28). UNESCO gave IFLA a push
in this direction in 1954 when it provided financial
support for IFLA’s Committee on CataloguingPrinciples to carry out a study on the standardization
of cataloguing rules. This was thought, in general, to
be a good idea but the Committee was cautious, insist-
ing that such a study should deal with the comparison
of principles and practices in different countries rather
than working toward anything that might be consid-
ered too extensive or wide-ranging. In 1954, it set up a
large working party to deal with the main entries for
anonymous works and works with corporate author-
ship, and to come up with a subsequent list of prio-
rities for study (Conseil de la FIAB, 1955: 85–87). In
fact, the Committee’s work expanded quickly to take
in other issues (Conseil de la FIAB, 1957: 37–39).
Two events mark high points in the movement
that led from IFLA’s early work in its Committee (and
later Working Party) on Cataloging to its far-reaching
program for UBC. The first was the Conference on
Cataloguing Principles held in Paris in 1961; the sec-
ond was the International Meeting of Cataloguing
Experts in Copenhagen in 1969.
The Council on Library Resources in Washington,
DC provided IFLA with what was for the time a large
grant to meet most of the costs of organizing the
Conference on Cataloguing Principles. This included
setting up and staffing an office, and providing travel
and living support for about 100 participants for the
10 days that the conference was expected to last.
Arthur Chaplin (1963: 44), executive secretary of the
conference (its organizi ng secretary was Dorothy
Anderson), suggested that there were three elements
in this extensive organizational process that ensured
the successful outcome of the conference: first,
enough time was given to the preparation and discus-
sion of the working papers; second, there was enough
time to gather and collate comments on these papers;
and third, enough time was also allowed for extensive
“direct discussions with various interested parties.”
The result of the conference was less a set of princi-
ples than a set of guidelines that would ensure
increased consistency in the creation of national cat-
aloguing codes. The principles covered, for example,
the desirable functions and structure of catalogs, the
different kinds of entries that they had to accommo-
date, and the choice and form of headings for those
entries (IFLA, 1961). That they had been generally
agreed to almost unanimously was considered to be a
remarkable achievement. C Sumner Spalding, for
example, who was an official representative of the
Library of Congress at the conference and was to edit
the 1967 Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules, which
reflected the principles, wrote: “It would be hard to
imagine a more completely successful international
conference than the one held in Paris in 1961.” It
was extraordinary that “voting representatives747 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
from twelve international organizations and from
fifty-three countries, with varying cataloging
traditions” could arrive at near unanimity on “a final
agreement not only on cata loguing principles but
on basic rules for cataloguing” (quoted in Miksa,
2021: 125).
The principles were used in the years that followed
in the creation of new cataloguing codes and the revi-
sion of existing codes, but their use revealed a range
of limitations and inadequacies that needed attention.
Moreover, two developments in the USA had impor-
tant international compl icating implications for
achieving improvements in and extensions of the
principles, and the possibilities of international bib-
liographic control. In 1965, the Library of Congress
introduced its National Program for Acquisitions and
Cataloging, also referred to as the Shared Cataloguing
Program. The Library was authorized and funded to
acquire from around the world materials of value, and
to compile and distribute to participating libraries bib-
liographic data for these materials, with the data being
based where possible on what appeared in the relevant
national bibliographies. Within a year, 68 libraries
were participating and receiving the Library of
Congress cataloguing data through this program
(Ishimoto, 1973: 127). IFLA became very interested
in how this program might be extended internationally.
The second development, which was ultimately to
transform all aspects of library organization, manage-
ment, and services, was the development, only then in
its infancy, of electronic data processing in libraries.
This can be said to have really got underway in 1963
when a feasibility study at the Library of Congress
recommended that “a group be established to design
and implement the procedures to automate the catalo-
ging, searching, indexing, and document retrieval
functions” of the Library (Avram, 1975:6). Following
a relatively brief period of experimentation, in March
1969, the machine-readable cataloging (MARC) sys-
tem of the Library of Congress was launched, cover-
ing all English-language monographs cataloged by
the Library, including titles acquired through the
National Program for Acquisition and Cataloguing”
(Avram, 1975: 9). Libraries both in the USA and
abroad began increasingly to subscribe to MARC
tapes to support their own library cataloguing and to
themselves become involved in the ongoing evolution
of the MARC formats as fundamental “standards for
the representation and communication of biblio-
graphic and related information in machine-readable
form” (MARC 21 Formats, 2023).
Once again, the Council on Library Resources in
Washington, DC, recognizing the importance of these
and other developments, was willing to providea grant to support the work of a preparatory
committee of library experts—and the subsequent
formal meeting of an enlarged body of experts—“to
review progress in cataloguing since the Paris Con-
ference of 1961” (IFLA, 1969: 106). This was very
much a working meeting, with participation limited to
cataloguing experts from various countries drawing
on a number of working papers that had been distrib-
uted for comment. It was here that a commitment was
made to the idea of creating internationally accepted
codes to standardize the bibliographic description of
various formats of publications—International Stan-
dard Bibliographical Descriptions. These Descrip-
tions were to provide “a framework designed to
establish international consistency in the content,
order, and punctuation of descriptive metadata.” As
was the case for the Paris principles, they “were cre-
ated to guide subsequent national [catalog] code revi-
sion, bringing international descriptive cataloging
practices further in line and facilitating international
record sharing” (Dobreski, 2021: 229; see also IFLA,
1969: 111–112). Among the final resolutions of the
meeting was a statement of general policy that was to
guide further development:
Efforts should be directed towards creating a system for
the international exchange of information by which the
standard bibliographical description of each publication
would be established and distributed by a national
agency in the country of origin of the publication. The
means for distribution in such a system would be
through the medium of cards or machine readable
records. The effectiveness of the system will be depen-
dent upon the maximum standardisation of the form and
content of the bibliographical description. (IFLA, 1969:
115–116)
It was also decided that a permanent body—an
international secretariat—was now required to be a
focus of support and coordination for the develop-
ments that were foreshadowed at the meeting.
The 1961 and 1969 meetings and the agreements
that came from them created a kind of librarians’
philosopher’s stone—a set of principles and some of
the detail needed to flesh them out for establishing the
international standardization of the major elements
needed to create and exchange bibliographical records
in an increasingly computer-based network environ-
ment. They also affirmed the idea that national
libraries, especially those where the national biblio-
graphical service was located, were the logical agen-
cies to drive forward the work of standardization at
a national level.
As the IFLA program elaborated at the Interna-
tional Meeting of Cataloguing Experts began to748 IFLA Journal 50(4)
achieve identity and scale, it lacked only a name,
according to Dorothy Anderson, the figure who was
the most active in creating, rationalizing, and manag-
ing it. In 1971, Herman Liebaers, the then president of
IFLA, named it rather grandiosely “Universal Biblio-
graphical Control” (Anderson, 2000: 209). With a
grant from the US Council on Library Resources and
the provision of accommodation by the British
Library, an IFLA Cataloguing Secretariat was set up
under the leadership of Anderson. Its name was
changed to the UBC Office following the UNESCO
NATIS conference in 1974. It began to publish the
International Standard Bibliographical Descriptions
in 1971 as among its first tasks and to tackle other
issues involved in the search for international biblio-
graphic standardization, including the international
adoption and modification of the MARC formats ini-
tially developed at the Library of Congress. Its
extraordinary range of achievements under the dyna-
mism and experience of Anderson has been widely
acknowledged (e.g. Anderson and Myall, 1998;
Downing, 1983).
NATIS
The 1974 NATIS conference was explicitly organized
in cooperation with IFLA, FID, and the International
Council of Archives, but it had the IFLA program for
UBC at its base. It was seen as the culmination within
UNESCO of a number of regional meetings held
between 1966 and 1974 (NATIS, 1974:2) 1974: 1–
2). Among the conference’s conclusions was the
observation that
achieving NATIS involves formulation of a national
information policy based on the analysis of users’ needs,
determination of priorities among those needs, and the
consequent allocation of available resources, supported
by appropriate legislation, financing, qualified man-
power and modern information technology (NATIS
1974:2).
Many of the conference’s recommendations and
observations reflected the IFLA UBC program, and
it was noted:
There was wholehearted support of Universal Biblio-
graphic Control, a programme put forward by the Inter-
national Federation of Library Associations, which aims
to achieve the universal availability, in an internation-
ally accepted interchange form, of basic bibliographic
data on all publications, and it was considered that
Unesco should study ways by which it can assist in ful-
filling the UBC programme. (NATIS, 1974: 2)Anderson, who had written the IFLA document on
UBC for the conference, which was later published
under her name, observed that the UBC program was
accepted because it “[s]eemed relevant to all libraries
no matter their stage of development and easily coor-
dinated with national programs.” She saw the out-
come of the conference as indicating that the concept
of UBC “will be promoted by UNESCO, in cooper-
ation with IFLA as a major policy objective to create
a worldwide system for the control and exchange of
information” (Anderson, 1994: 369).
Insofar as the international objectives of the pro-
gram could only be met by effective national policies
and programs, the NATIS meeting recommended a
follow-up conference on the improvement of national
bibliographic control be held in 1977. Here, it was
hoped that agreement might be reached on a whole
range of technical issues related to the creation and
sharing of bibliographic records, and to the standardi-
zation of the activities of national bibliographic agen-
cies in relation to the compilation and publication of
national bibliographies (International Congress on
National Bibliographies, 1978). The working paper
for this meeting was prepared by Anderson and the
staff at the UBC Office in London. It reaffirmed the
importance of the UBC program within the NATIS
framework as the basis for a worldwide system for the
control and exchange of information.
UNISIST, NATIS, the General
Information Programme, and
Information for All
Thus, on the face of it, the programs emerging from
the two UNESCO-supported intergovernmental con-
ferences in 1971 and 1974 might be considered to
have created the possibility of a complementarity that
would underpin the framework of a new world infor-
mation order. As mentioned above, in 1971, it was
understood with regard to UNISIST that “a world
science information system ...is feasible. Further,
from the point of view of the needs of scientific and
technological communities, such a flexible network is
both desirable and necessary” (International Council
for Science, 1971: ix). The two men responsible for it
in the UNESCO Secretariat, Wysocki and Tocatlian
(1971), echoed this in the title of their article “A world
information system: Necessary and feasible,” while,
through NATIS, it was understood that a “worldwide
system for the control and exchange of bibliographic
information was possible” (Anderson, 1974: 369).
For Tocatlian, assessing the relative strengths of
the UNSIST and NATIS programs from within the
UNESCO Secretariat, there were administrative749 Rayward: The attempt to create a post-World War II international information order
tensions that lay behind the NATIS conference and its
outcomes. He noted that, originally, relatively small
provision had been made within the Secretariat for
UNISIST, but it had very quickly gained much posi-
tive attention both internationally and within the
UNESCO General Conference, the main governing
body of UNESCO. By contrast, UNESCO’s large
Department of Documentation, Libraries and
Archives did not have a general comprehensive pro-
gram with the reach, international strength of interest,
and commitment within UNESCO itself that
UNISIST had quickly achieved. This was so even
though the department had been in existence for a
great many years at the time of the NATIS meeting
and was closely supported by, and collaborated with,
the three then relatively strong non-governmental
organizations—IFLA, FID, and the International
Council of Archives (ICA). He believed that there
was an element of organizational rivalry lying behind
the development of the NATIS program and that,
despite what was positive about it, it had an important
drawback in that “it exacerbated the fight between
librarians and information scientists. It was a nega-
tive, and as such, a waste of time and energy” (Toca-
tlian, 2000: 11).
Nevertheless, for both the UNISIST and NATIS
programs there was an early period of considerable
activity, especially in terms of regional meetings,
workshops, contracts for experts to compile manuals
to codify standards and provide curricula for educa-
tional workshops, and so on. Each program developed
a strong focus on the needs of developing countries
and involving them in its work. Both were responsible
over the years of their existence for an extensive bib-
liography of an operational and discursive literature
aimed at their different audiences.
In 1977, the UNESCO General Conference, how-
ever, took a major decision that altered the nature of
its commitment to its information programs. It recom-
mended that they be rationalized into a single
program—the General Information Programme/Pro-
gramme G´ en´eral d’Information. Wysocki, appointed
as director, outlined in detail at the 1977 International
Congress on National Bibliographies the deliberations
and recommendations that had led to its creation. He
indicated that, within the UNESCO Secretariat, the
organizational arrangements for the new program
would include most of the activities of the former
Division of Scientific and Technological Documenta-
tion and Information, where UNISIST was situated,
and the Division of Documentation, Libraries and
Archives, which was responsible for the NATIS
program (International Congress on National Biblio-
graphies, 1978: Annex D). The two advisorycommittees for these programs were to be replaced
by a single Intergovernmental Council for the Gen-
eral Information Progra mme. It was understood that
the creation of the General Information Programme
involved the complex and difficult task of the con-
solidation of the existing programs. It was also
recognized, however, that UNESCO’s programmatic
emphasis needed to focus more directly on the infor-
mation needs of developing countries, and to respond
more effectively to the emergence and increasing
sophistication of the digital or online world. Even so,
the UNESCO General Conference, at the moment of
creating the General Information Programme, did call
for continuity in the work of both UNISIST and NATIS
(Wysocki, 1978: 302).
Eventually, although their activities and publica-
tions continued for a period as the new unified program
was being formulated, debated, voted on, and imple-
mented, both the UNISIST and NATIS programs even-
tually lost their identity within UNESCO. In 2001, the
General Information Programme morphed into the
Information for All Programme. A search on its web-
site under both UNISIST and NATIS reveals no
results. But even so, this ongoing program, squarely
situated in the digital world and with a strong orienta-
tion to developing countries, describes itself as “a
unique UNESCO intergovernmental programme that
supports Member States in fostering equitable societies
through promoting universal access to information and
knowledge for sustainable development” (UNESCO,
2023). So perhaps some aspects of the philosophy and
programs of UNISIST and NATIS may be thought to
continue to influence UNESCO’s information pro-
grams as they have evolved over subsequent decades.
Caveats and conclusion
In this article, I have been dealing with what might be
considered a very limited range of organizations and
developments. Not considered are the post-World
War II lives of individual “traditional” indexing and
abstracting services that were provided by various
disciplinary organizations, some with long histories
that go back to the 19th century, such as, for example,
Chemical Abstracts ,Physics Abstracts ,Biological
Abstracts , and even Nuclear Science Abstracts
(Clapp, 1950; Cooper, 1982; Manzer, 1977). All have
undergone major—sometimes pioneering—technical
developments as they have transitioned from what
were once “simple” print-based journals to complex
online bibliographic and data-based services. Nor do I
trace the emergence of what one might call global
“accumulator sites” and the complex services their
search engines now offer to subscribers, such as the750 IFLA Journal 50(4)
World of Science and Clarivate, or BASE, the Biele-
feld Academic Search Engine, which its home page
claims has access to 346,529,602 documents,5or the
library-based OCLC Inc. (2023), which, as
of September 2023, indicated that it contained
548,338,915 bibliographic records recording
3,357,676,790 library hol dings from around the
world. Nor do I touch on the information activities
of other intergovernmental organizations apart from
UNESCO, such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organi-
zation, the International Atomic Energy Agency,
Euratom, the European Union, and the large family
of United Nations-related organizations. All were—
and are—concerned, sometimes incidentally, some-
times centrally, with creating information systems
and services that now form a crowded, multifarious,
confusing patterning of international information
interests and activities.
In the final analysis, one has to acknowledge that
the long march of bibliographic events from the end
of World War II to what seemed like the opening of a
new information world order based on UNESCO’s
UNISIST and NATIS programs inevitably kept stea-
dily moving on beyond them. Since the late 1960s and
the 1970s, there seems to have been a constantly
accelerating impetus for change in information sys-
tems and services from the trajectory I have traced
from the end of World War II. A revolution has gath-
ered force around them (Lancaster and Neway, 1982).
There has been an epistemic break from the past. It is
reflected in the dynamism of international political
arrangements, in rapidly transformative digital com-
munications technologies, and in the massive com-
mercial formations that are associated with their
ownership and exploitation. Information has become
a commercial resource that is subject to the vast and
constantly moving interplay of geopolitical and cor-
porate economic interests as never before. It is now
caught up in a kind of never-ending international
institutional shape-shifting. All the major information
services have been restructured, and sometimes rein-
vented, to become complex electronic portals into
digital worlds in which new kinds of organizational
relationships of members, clients, and competitors
interact in a global, borderless marketplace.
